Nodes.Title: Procedural order for a remote hearing in international arbitration
Nodes.BodyContent:
Produced in partnership with Phillip Clifford, QC and Samuel Pape of Latham & Watkins LLP

PROCEDURAL ORDER NO. [insert number]

Having considered the parties’ submissions, the Tribunal orders as follows:

  1. 1

    Hearing by video-conference

    1. 1.1

      The [insert hearing description] (the Hearing) shall be conducted by video-conference, using [insert name of video-conferencing platform] as the video-conferencing platform (the Platform). The Tribunal considers that this is a reasonable alternative to an in-person hearing [eg, in light of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, lockdown measures, social distancing orders and travel limitations.] It will provide the parties with a fair and reasonable opportunity to be heard and allow the arbitration to proceed in accordance with [insert reference to any duties set out in the applicable rules of arbitration or under the arbitral law of the seat to conduct proceedings expeditiously, efficiently and without unnecessary delay].

  3. 2

    [Prior directions concerning the Hearing]

    1. 2.1

      [This Procedural Order supersedes [insert references to any prior directions to the extent inconsistent with this Procedural Order or no longer applicable].]

    2. 2.2

      [[Insert references to any provisions of prior Procedural Orders or other directions by the Tribunal concerning the Hearing that are to continue to apply] shall continue to apply.]

  5. 3

    Hosting [and technical support]

    1. 3.1

      [[The institutional case manager/tribunal secretary/case monitor/other person] shall act as the host for the Hearing (the Host). The Host shall liaise with the Tribunal and parties to ensure that the Hearing is held in accordance with this Procedural Order and as directed by the Tribunal. In particular, prior to and during the Hearing, the Host shall assist the Tribunal to manage the participants and the settings for the Platform.

      2. AND/OR

    2. 3.2

      The parties shall retain [insert name of third party service provider] (the Support Provider) to assist with, support the participants and resolve any issues in relation to the Platform, including prior to and during the Hearing. The Support Provider shall be instructed to provide such support as may reasonably be required by the parties, the Tribunal[, the Host] or any other participant.

      3. OR

    3. 3.3

      [The Tribunal OR Chair of the Tribunal] shall act as the Host for the Hearing (the Host). In this capacity, the [Tribunal OR Chair] shall have the power to manage the participants and the settings for the Platform, and to do all things necessary to ensure that the proceedings are conducted in accordance with this Procedural Order.]

  7. 4

    Access to the Platform

    1. 4.1

      By [date], each party shall submit to the Tribunal a list of all persons (counsel, witnesses, experts, client representatives, technical personnel or otherwise) to attend the Hearing, including their names, affiliations, roles at the Hearing, e-mail addresses and telephone numbers at which they may be contacted during the Hearing (the Participant Lists).

    2. 4.2

      By [date], the [Host/Tribunal] shall invite all persons on the Participant Lists to join the Hearing through the Platform by email including the connection link, password and instructions for connecting to the Hearing.

    3. 4.3

      In order to protect the security and confidentiality of the Hearing, the Platform shall be password-protected and access to it limited to those on the Participant Lists, the Tribunal members, [the Host] [and the Support Provider]. Hearing attendees shall not forward or otherwise share the Platform connection link or password.

    4. 4.4

      At the beginning of each Hearing session, any Hearing attendee who has been joined by any other person in the same room shall disclose the identity of that person to the other attendees. Should any other person join an attendee during a session, the presence and identity of that person must be notified to the other attendees as soon as practicable. The Tribunal shall have the power to direct that any person whose presence has been notified to the other attendees in accordance with this provision shall absent themselves for the duration of all or part of the Hearing.

  9. 5

    Testing of the Platform

    1. 5.1

      Each party shall test the Platform with each of the participants set out in its Participant List. The Platform shall be made available for such purpose between [time] and [time] for the Claimant on [date] and between [time] and [time] for the Respondent on [date].

    2. 5.2

      At [time] on [date], counsel for each party and the Tribunal will connect to the Platform in order to test it jointly and to make any necessary technical adjustments to the Platform or equipment of the arbitrators and counsel.

  11. 6

    Hearing schedule and allocation of time

    1. 6.1

      The Hearing shall begin at [time] on [date], and shall proceed in accordance with the timetable set out in the Appendix to this Procedural Order (the Timetable).

    2. 6.2

      The participants shall access the Platform [15 minutes] prior to the scheduled start time on each day of the Hearing to ensure that any technical issues are resolved in advance of the beginning of each day (where relevant).

    3. 6.3

      The Hearing shall commence on each day (where relevant) upon the Tribunal being satisfied that all necessary counsel, parties and other participants are satisfactorily connected to the Platform.

    4. 6.4

      The Tribunal may order that additional breaks be taken and adjust the Timetable, in its discretion, to facilitate an efficient Hearing.

    5. 6.5

      [The allocation of Hearing time shall be subject to the discretion of the Tribunal but shall initially be split equally between the parties, subject to [one hour] per day being reserved for the Tribunal. The Tribunal and the parties’ allotted time will be administered with a chess clock system. The [Tribunal Secretary] will control and maintain a record of the time used by each party and the Tribunal throughout the Hearing. At the close of each Hearing day, the [Tribunal Secretary] will inform the Tribunal and the parties by e-mail of the total time used and the remaining time for each party and the Tribunal.]

  13. 7

    Management of the Platform during the Hearing

    1. 7.1

      Upon joining the Platform, participants will be admitted to a virtual waiting room. The Tribunal will [admit or seek to procure the admission of] all participants to the Hearing at the same time.

    2. 7.2

      In the interest of avoiding delay or difficulties in reconnecting, participants should remain connected to the Platform during the breaks. However, participants may mute their lines and turn off their video projection during this time, and the Tribunal may direct that participants move to virtual “break-out” rooms.

    3. 7.3

      The Tribunal may [disable or procure the disablement of] the private “chat” function in the Platform.

    4. 7.4

      The Tribunal may use a virtual “break-out” room to confer privately. The Tribunal may also direct the use of virtual “break-out” rooms for private conversations between other participants as it deems appropriate including, upon request, to allow members of a party’s legal team to confer between themselves.

  15. 8

    Participation in the Hearing

    1. 8.1

      Participants shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that that their video and audio transmission is clear throughout the duration of the Hearing and seek to minimise any technical incidents. In particular, and without limitation, participants shall:

      1. 8.1.1

        connect to the Platform using a high-speed and stable internet connection if this is reasonably available to them (a wired connection may be preferable to a wireless one where possible);

      2. 8.1.2

        seek to ensure that their audio facilities are adequate, that they can mute themselves when not speaking and eliminate background noise to the extent practicable;

      3. 8.1.3

        seek to ensure that their video transmission is reasonably clear, including by making appropriate adjustments to camera orientation or positioning and lighting;

      4. 8.1.4

        ensure that any chargeable devices used are sufficiently charged and that power cables or back-up batteries are available if necessary; and

      5. 8.1.5

        not join the Hearing from a public place or using an unsecured, public wireless connection.

    3. 8.2

      During the Hearing, any participant who is speaking shall remain in view of the camera and shall not use a “virtual background” or otherwise take steps to obscure or modify the remote venue from which they are speaking.

    4. 8.3

      Participants shall speak as directed, one at a time, taking care not to speak over one another, other than as may be required to interpose an objection as may be appropriate or to alert other participants of any technical difficulties where necessary.

    5. 8.4

      All participants who are not speaking shall maintain their audio on mute at all times.

  17. 9

    Documents

    1. 9.1

      The Parties shall jointly agree and prepare a single electronic document bundle (the Electronic Bundle) containing copies of all pleadings, witness statements, expert reports, ex...

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—implications for structured products and securitisation transactions
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note discusses the implications of the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak for structured products and securitisation transactions and includes practical tips for lawyers working in these areas. For regular updates of news and analysis on the outbreak relevant to structured products and securitisation transactions, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19) implications for Banking & Finance lawyers.

Coronavirus (COVID-19)

Lawyers across the world are currently grappling with many common areas of concern in connection with the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The Coronavirus (COVID-19) toolkit has been created to assist lawyers with easy access to news, practical guidance and Q&As from across a number of practice areas that relate to these key areas of concern. In addition to coronavirus-specific content, the toolkit also highlights additional guidance and support materials of general relevance to each of these areas.

There are a number of areas that are particularly relevant to banking and finance lawyers. For more detail and analysis on these, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19) implications for Banking & Finance lawyers, which is updated regularly with news, practical guidance and analysis covering the impact of COVID-19 developments and covers subject areas such as force majeure in lending transactions and execution of documents as well as setting out the implications for different types of banking and finance lawyers.

This Practice Note focuses on the implications for structured products and securitisation transactions and practical steps to be taken by lawyers working in these areas. See Practice Notes: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—implications for derivatives transactions and Coronavirus (COVID-19)—implications for debt capital markets for crossover areas.

Issues affecting securitisations

Securitisation Regulation—reporting

The pandemic and the measures put in place to restrict its spread have disrupted economies and slowed economic growth around the world. This has the potential to impact individual securitisation transactions in many ways. For example:

  1. •

    the value of underlying assets may be significantly reduced

  2. •

    cash flows from underlying assets may be interrupted

  3. •

    the ability to enforce security over underlying assets may be affected by (initially) temporary measures introduced at a national level

  4. •

    underlying assets, and/or the securitisation itself, may be downgraded or put on negative watch by credit rating agencies (CRAs)

  5. •

    there may be breaches of the tests included in the securitisation documents which relate to the underlying asset pools, such as overcollateralisation tests, interest coverage tests and borrowing base tests, or other events may be triggered, such as margining events, and cure rights may be exercised

Events of this kind may require to be reported under Regulation (EU) 2017/2402 (the Securitisation Regulation). The Securitisation Regulation requires:

  1. •

    regular provision of information on the underlying assets (quarterly for transactions which are not asset-backed commercial paper (ABCP) securitisations, monthly for ABCP securitisations)

  2. •

    ad hoc reporting, without delay, of inside information and significant events

The reporting requirements may be fulfilled by the originator, sponsor or special purpose securitisation entity (SSPE) of a securitisation (the reporting entity).

The information to be made available quarterly or monthly is highly detailed and is specified in the Annexes to Commission Delegated Regulation of 16 October 2019 supplementing the Securitisation Regulation with regard to regulatory technical standards specifying the information and the details of a securitisation to be made available by the originator, sponsor and SSPE. It includes information for each individual underlying asset. The impact of the pandemic may potentially add significantly to the burden on reporting entities. For example, in relation to residential mortgage-backed securitisations, the information to be reported for each underlying mortgage includes the following, which would have to reflect payment holidays granted by lenders in accordance with the Financial Conduct Authority’s (FCA) guidance to firms on mortgages and the coronavirus:

  1. •

    restructuring, which means any changes made to the contractual terms of the underlying asset due to forbearance, including payment holidays, arrears capitalisation, change of interest rate basis or margins, fees, penalties, maturity and/or other generally-accepted measures of restructuring due to forbearance

  2. •

    arrears (amounts due less amounts actually paid, regardless of the reason why a payment has not been received), and

  3. •

    number of days in arrears

The requirement to report inside information applies to securitisations which are within the scope of Regulation (EU) 596/2014 (the Market Abuse Regulation)—that is, securitisations:

  1. •

    admitted to trading on an EU-regulated market or for which a request for admission to trading has been made

  2. •

    traded on a multilateral trading facility (MTF), admitted to trading on an MTF or for which a request for admission to trading on an MTF has been made

  3. •

    traded on an organised trading facility (OTF)

For information on regulated markets, MTFs and OTFs, see Practice Notes: Regulated Markets under MiFID II and MiFIR, Multilateral Trading Facilities (MTFs) and Organised Trading Facilities (OTFs).

Inside information is defined in Article 7(1) of the Market Abuse Regulation and includes any information of a precise nature, which has not been made public, relating, directly or indirectly, to the SSPE or the securitisation, which, if it were made public, would be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the securitisation notes.

The requirement to report significant events applies to all securitisations within the scope of the Securitisation Regulation.

Article 7(1)(g) of the Securitisation Regulation sets out a non-exhaustive list of events which would be considered significant events:

  1. •

    a material breach of the obligations provided for in the transaction documents, including any remedy, waiver or consent subsequently provided in relation to such a breach

  2. •

    a change in the structural features that can materially impact the performance of the securitisation

  3. •

    a change in the risk characteristics of the securitisation or of the underlying exposures that can materially impact the performance of the securitisation

  4. •

    in the case of simple, transparent and standardised (STS) securitisations, where the securitisation ceases to meet the STS requirements or where competent authorities have taken remedial or administrative actions, and

  5. •

    any material amendment to the transaction documents

Examples of events which may potentially constitute significant events in relation to a securitisation are:

  1. •

    test breaches such as overcollateralisation tests, interest coverage tests, borrowing base tests, margining events and the exercise of any curerights

  2. •

    material breaches of transaction or warehouse documents

  3. •

    a material increase in defaulted or downgraded underlying assets rated

  4. •

    the passing of resolutions by holders of securitsation notes, and

  5. •

    a refinancing or reset

The following practical points may be noted:

  1. •

    to comply with the requirement to report inside information, the reporting entity is required to make an assessment as to whether the information in question would be likely to have a significant effect on the prices of the securitisation notes—this assessment may be difficult to make in, for example, a situation where the number of restructured underlying loans in arrears changes daily, and where prices generally, and the price of the securitisation notes specifically, may in any case be highly volatile

  2. •

    the requirement to report inside information or a significant event may be triggered by an accumulation of individual events, such as payment holidays and arrears on underlying loans, which are also required to be included in the information to be reported quarterly or monthly—however there is no provision in the Securitisation Regulation for delaying the reporting of the inside information or significant event until the quarterly or monthly report is made

For further information on reporting requirements under the Securitisation Regulation, see Practice Note: Securitisation Regulation—essentials — Ongoing transparency requirements for originators, sponsors and SSPEs.

Securitisation Regulation—monitoring

One of the aims of the Securitisation Regulation is to make institutional investors take responsibility for evaluating the securitisations they invest in. The requirement for reporting entities to report detailed information on a periodical basis and inside information and special events as they occur is balanced by a requirement for institutional investors to carry out ongoing monitoring of their investments in securitisations.

Detailed monitoring requirements are set out in Article 5(4) of the Securitisation Regulation and include a requirement to perform regular stress tests on the cash flows and collateral values supporting the underlying assets or, in the absence of sufficient data on cash flows and collateral values, stress tests on loss assumptions, having regard to the nature, scale and complexity of the risk of the securitisation position.

Institutional investors should therefore be taking a proactive approach to the pandemic and the information provided by reporting entities.

For further information on monitoring requirements under the Securitisation Regulation, see Practice Note: Securitisation Regulation—essentials — Due diligence, risk assessment and ongoing monitoring.

MAC clauses and force majeure

Material adverse change (MAC) and force majeure clauses are sometimes found in securitisation documents, for example, in servicing agreements where they relate to the servicer’s capacity to perform under the servicing agreement. Typically, the triggering of a clause of this kind would be grounds for terminating the servicing agreement. Where they are found, there is no standard wording. It is therefore advisable to review existing transaction documents to see if they contain MAC or force majeure clauses, or clauses with similar effect which are not specifically identified as MAC or force majeure (for example, ‘disruption events’) and, if a clause of this kind is found, consider very carefully the language used and its application to the specific circumstances of the servicer or other party to which it relates against the background of the pandemic.

The wording of a MAC clause in a servicing agreement will typically focus on a deterioration in the financial or other condition of a specified party—eg the servicer—while a force majeure clause will typically focus on external events which impair the ability of specified party to perform under the contract. However, both could potentially be triggered by a major external event such as the pandemic.

For general guidance on the interpretation of MAC clauses, see Q&A: What are the implications of coronavirus (COVID-19) for MAC clauses in facility agreements?

For general guidance on the interpretation of force majeure clauses, see News Analysis: Coronavirus (COVID-19), force majeure and frustration—Key legal principles and industry implications.

Nodes.Title: The Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 and other developments in insolvency and restructuring—key issues and discussion points for lenders
Nodes.BodyContent:
An introduction to the legislation

Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020

Expedited by the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020) was introduced to the House of Commons on 20 May 2020 and received royal assent on 25 June 2020. Most of its provisions are in force from 26 June 2020.

The aim of CIGA 2020 is to promote a rescue culture to ensure companies in financial difficulties have greater opportunities to restructure and avoid formal (more often than not, terminal) insolvency processes during the coronavirus crisis and beyond. It is therefore a comparatively debtor friendly piece of legislation. It legislates for temporary measures announced by the government as part of its coronavirus response but, more significantly, it introduces permanent new tools into the UK corporate insolvency and restructuring framework, including:

  1. •

    a new stand-alone moratorium which will impact on secured lender enforcement rights

  2. •

    a new restructuring plan which includes cross-class cram down provisions which can be used as an alternative to schemes of arrangement or company voluntary arrangements (CVAs), and

  3. •

    the restriction of the use of termination clauses allowing for a contract for supply of goods or services to a company to be terminated in the event of the company entering an insolvency process

As such, it is one of the most significant pieces of legislation in this arena this century.

The government previously consulted on the permanent changes to the UK’s insolvency regime and its response was published on 26 August 2018 (see News Analysis: Exploring the government’s response to the insolvency and corporate governance consultation and Practice Note: Reform of UK insolvency laws). CIGA 2020 largely follows the conclusions set out in that response in terms of the permanent measures. Because it was enacted on an accelerated timetable and will not have been put through the usual level of scrutiny, it contains powers for the Secretary of State to amend and add to the legislation as necessary to take account of drafting or practice issues.

In this Practice Note, we provide summary information on the changes to insolvency and restructuring law set out in CIGA 2020 with a view to drawing out key issues and discussion points for lenders and provide further reading links for those wishing to dig into the detail of the new legislation. For an overview, see: News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 and Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—overview.

Other legislation

By way of a refresher, we also comment on the potential impact on lenders (particularly floating charge holders) of (i) the increase in the prescribed part (from 6 April 2020) introduced in the Insolvency Act 1986 (Prescribed Part) (Amendment) Order 2020, SI 2020/211, and (ii) the proposal in the Finance Bill 2019–2021 to re-introduce Crown preference (from 1 December 2020).

CIGA 2020—temporary coronavirus measures

Temporary suspension of winding up petitions

This part of the legislation was originally conceived to stop landlords using statutory demands and winding up petitions as an alternative method of rent collection as a result of the temporary restriction on forfeiture of commercial leases for non-payment of rent in England and Wales introduced by section 82 of the Coronavirus Act 2020 (which took effect from 26 March 2020). However, CIGA 2020 goes further than this by restricting the use of winding up petitions in relation to all debts (not just debts under leases).CIGA 2020, s 10 and Sch 10 provide that:

  1. •

    a winding up petition cannot be presented on or after 27 April 2020 on the ground that the company has failed to satisfy a statutory demand where the statutory demand was served between 1 March 2020 and 30 September 2020. This does not prevent a statutory demand being served per se, but a winding up petition cannot be presented on the basis of one

  2. •

    a creditor should not present a petition for winding up on the basis of inability to pay debts between 27 April 2020 and 30 September 2020, unless the creditor has reasonable grounds for believing that:

    1. ◦

      coronavirus has not had a financial effect on the company, or

    2. ◦

      the company would have been unable to pay its debts even if coronavirus had not had a financial effect on the company

  3. •

    a petition on the grounds of inability to pay debts which is invalidly presented during this period can be removed by the court and the court has a wide power to make orders restoring the position to what it would have been had the petition not been presented

  1. •

    if such a petition is validly presented, in summary, the court can only make a winding up order if satisfied that the company would have been insolvent in spite of coronavirus

  2. •

    winding up orders already made after 27 April and the coming into force of Schedule 10 will be deemed void unless it can be shown the order would have been made had the provisions already been in force at the time the order was made

Where a company has been wound up based on a petition issued between 27 April 2020 and 30 September 2020, two further consequences will be relevant for banks and lenders:

  1. •

    section 127 of the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986) will only apply from when the winding up order is made, rather than from the date of the winding up petition. Banks normally put a stop on transactions out of a company’s bank account as soon as the bank becomes aware that a winding up petition has been presented against the company to avoid the consequences of allowing void transactions to be conducted via the company’s bank account in breach of IA 1986, s 127. In relation to petitions presented in the relevant period, only transactions made from the date of the winding up order are void (rather than from the date of the winding up petition), meaning banks may continue to allow transactions to be conducted through the bank account of a customer facing a winding up petition without the need for a validation order

  2. •

    the look back period when considering transactions at an undervalue, preferences and void floating charges are altered as follows to take into account lengthy delays anticipated between the issue of the winding up petition and the order:

    1. ◦

      for transactions at an undervalue or preferences to connected persons, the look back period begins on the later of two years before the petition was presented and two years and six months before the date of the order to wind up, and ends on the date of the order

    2. ◦

      for preferences to unconnected persons, the look back period begins on the later of six months before the petition was presented and 12 months before the date of the order to wind up , and ends on the date of the order

    3. ◦

      for preferences to unconnected persons, the look back period begins on the later of six months before the petition was presented and 12 months before the date of the order to wind up, and ends on the date of the order

    4. ◦

      in relation to avoidance of floating charges granted to connected persons, the look back period begins on the later of two years before the petition was presented and two years and six months before the date of the order to wind up, and ends on the date of the order

    5. ◦

      in relation to avoidance of floating charges granted to unconnected persons, the look back period begins on the later of 12 months before the petition was presented and 18 months before the date of the winding up order, and ends on the date of the order

For further reading, see News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—temporary changes to winding-up petitions (the analysis remains relevant save that the end date of the provisions are now 30 September 2020).

There have already been at least three reported cases in which presentation or advertisement of a winding up petition has been restrained by the court on the basis that if the CIG Bill were in force, the winding up petition would be void or fail. See News Analyses:

  1. •

    The need for restraint—winding-up petitions and coronavirus (COVID-19) (Travelodge v Prime Aesthetics)

  2. •

    Restraining presentation of a winding-up petition on grounds of an anticipated change in the law (Re A Company)

  3. •

    A decision on the impact of the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill (Re A Company (Application to restrain advertisement of a winding up petition))

  Key issues/discussion points
 
  1. •

    Events of default and insolvency events—while the exact analysis will depend on the wording of the events of default/insolvency event clause in each case, lenders should carefully consider whether to accelerate debt (or take other action) on the basis of an event of default or insolvency event triggered by the presentation of a winding up petition (or the making of a winding up order) which falls in the relevant time period. Even if there has in fact been an event of default or insolvency event, could the relevant winding up petition or winding up order be deemed void by the legislation? If there are cure provisions or a grace period within which a winding up petition can be discharged, stayed or dismissed before an event of default/insolvency event is triggered, would the event be cured by the the legislation, by the court making an order to dismiss the petition or by the court making an order to restore the position to what it would have been had the petition not been presented?

  2. •

    Unsecured debt/ guarantee debt collection—unless a lender can show that the case falls within one of the exceptions, this avenue of recovery may be temporarily be unavailable to lenders (see News Analysis: A decision on the impact of the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill (Re A Company (Application to restrain advertisement of a winding up petition)) which concerns a case involving winding up petitions based on unpaid statutory demands for loan repayment)

  3. •

    Real estate finance—the provisions are likely to have an obvious impact in the context of rental income and cashflow in investment facilities. For further information, see Practice Notes: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—implications for real estate finance transactions—Rental income and cashflow in investment facilities and Coronavirus (COVID-19)—implications for property—Coronavirus Act 2020—restrictions on forfeiture, protection from eviction etc

Other temporary measures

CIGA 2020 sets out further temporary coronavirus measures including:

  1. •

    power for the Secretary of State to make further regulations extending the time period for filing company charges to a maximum of 42 days. The Companies etc (Filing Requirements) (Temporary Modifications) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/645, which came into force on 27 June 2020 and expire on 5 April 2021, extend the period for filing company charges to 31 days beginning with the day after the date of creation of the charge (up from 21 days)

  2. •

    a temporary extension to the period which a public company has to file accounts and reports with Companies House and temporary provision for virtual AGMs and general meetings, and

  3. •

    a temporary suspension of wrongful trading liability

For further information, see News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—company meetings and company filings and Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—Temporary changes to the wrongful trading regime which remain relevant.

CIGA 2020—Permanent measures—Termination (ipso facto) clauses

An ipso facto clause is a clause in a contract which provides that a party can terminate the contract or do any other thing (for example, withhold or terminate supply) if the counterparty is subject to an insolvency process. CIGA 2020, s 14 inserts a new section 233B into IA 1986, which provides that a supplier under a contract for the supply of goods or services will no longer be able to terminate supply under the contract or do any other thing in reliance on an ipso facto clause if the counterparty enters an insolvency process or is subject to the new moratorium or the new restructuring plan (see below). Set off and netting will continue to be available (paragraph 20 of Part 4 of new schedule 4ZZA to IA 1986). Safeguards are provided to protect suppliers where a supplier can demonstrate that they will suffer hardship as a consequence of the measure, and there is also a temporary exemption for small suppliers until 30 September 2020.

Persons involved in financial services and financial services contracts are exempted—lenders can, for example, still accelerate loan agreements on the basis of a borrower entering an insolvency process and rely on drawstops based on insolvency events. In addition, commodities contracts and futures and forward contracts are excluded from the restrictions on ipso facto clauses.

For further reading, see Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—restrictions on ipso facto clauses.

  Key issues/discussion points
 
  1. •

    Acceleration and drawstop provisions—lenders are still permitted to rely on drawstops and acceleration clauses in facilities agreements, as well as provisions allowing the charging of fees and default interest in the event of insolvency

  2. •

    Trade and commodity finance—this development will be of interest to trade financiers as it may impact on recoveries where a contract counterparty goes into an insolvency process and because there may be a knock on effect on trade credit insurance. However, the continued availability of set off and netting will provide some comfort. Commodities contracts and futures and forward contracts are excluded from the restrictions on ipso facto clauses

CIGA 2020—Permanent measures—Stand-alone moratorium procedure

CIGA 2020 abolishes the moratorium procedure for small companies under IA 1986, Sch A1 (small companies moratorium where directors propose a CVA) and inserts a new Part 1A to the IA 1986 providing for a new standalone moratorium which would be available to most companies which are, or likely to become, unable to pay their debts. The aim is to give the company breathing space to allow a restructuring to be implemented (for example, through a scheme of arrangement, a restructuring plan (see below), CVA or informal restructuring). The directors would remain in charge of the company but the process and company conduct during the moratorium is overseen by a monitor (an insolvency practitioner) who is required to certify that it is likely that the moratorium will result in the rescue of the company as a going concern.

The moratorium will not be available if the company has been subject to an insolvency procedure/moratorium within the past 12 months and a court order would be required to commence the moratorium where the company is currently subject to a winding up petition. Some of these criteria have been relaxed on a temporary basis until 30 September 2020 on account of the impact of coronavirus on businesses. Certain companies (eg most parties to capital markets arrangements, public-private partnership project companies, and some financial institutions) cannot use the moratorium procedure. In addition, the Insolvency Act 1986 Part A1 Moratorium (Eligibility of Private Registered Providers) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/652 ensure that the standalone moratorium does not apply in relation to companies which are private registered providers of social housing given housing legislation already contains measures to deal with businesses that get into financial difficulty—including a moratorium. Foreign companies will be able to use the procedure but must apply to court and be able to show sufficient connection to the jurisdiction.

The moratorium provides the company with a payment holiday from certain debts which fell due before the moratorium or fall due during the moratorium but relate to obligations incurred pre-moratorium. However, some debts are excluded and must be paid as they fall due (Non-Payment Holiday Debts) including liabilities arising under a contract or instrument involving financial services—this includes bank facilities, capital market arrangements, commodities contracts, derivatives contracts, guarantee commitments and any contract secured by a financial collateral arrangement.

The process will be commenced by the filing of forms at court without the requirement for a court hearing and initially lasts for 20 business days, with the possibility of extension by the directors for a further 40 business days and, thereafter, further extensions can be made with the consent of certain creditors (pre-moratorium creditors whose debt is subject to a payment holiday) and/or the permission of the court. The moratorium is extended while a CVA is pending and can be extended by the court until such date as the court orders where a scheme of arrangement or restructuring plan is proposed. The monitor is required to file documents at Companies House confirming the entry, extension or end of the moratorium, and is also required to notify known creditors. There is no requirement to notify qualifying floating charge holders (QFCHs) or to obtain their consent to the moratorium.

The monitor must terminate the moratorium if they think the company is unable to pay Non-Payment Holiday Debts. In addition, the company must pay the Non-Payment Holiday Debts to obtain an extension (unless the extension triggered by a restructuring procedure).

If the company goes into an insolvency process within 12 weeks of the end of the moratorium, unpaid Non-Payment Holiday Debts have super priority in any distribution from the insolvency process. Provision is made temporarily (until the later of 30 September 2020) for the order of priority to be:

  1. •

    amounts owed in respect of goods and services supplied during the moratorium where the supplier was not able to use an ipso facto clause to terminate supply

  2. •

    wages and salary

  3. •

    other debts and liabilities apart from the monitor’s remuneration and expenses, and then

  4. •

    the monitor’s remuneration and expenses

Additional provision is made for the Insolvency Rules 2016 to be amended to set out the priority in which super priority debts are to be treated among themselves.

A restructuring plan, CVA or scheme of arrangement commenced within 12 weeks of the end of a moratorium cannot apply to a Non-Payment Holiday Debt without the consent of the relevant creditor. This could give lenders veto rights in relation to any scheme or CVA.

Restrictions are placed on the company’s ability to enter into transactions during the moratorium, including:

  1. •

    no new credit can be incurred in excess of £500 unless the lender is informed about the moratorium

  2. •

    the company cannot enter into certain financial instruments (market contracts or financial collateral arrangements, transfer orders, market charges or a system-charges, or collateral security)

  3. •

    new security can only be granted with monitor consent

  4. •

    secured property may only be disposed of (i) if the disposal is in accordance with the terms of the security/agreement, or (ii) with the permission of the court if the court thinks such sale would support the rescue of the company as a going concern. Where the court gives permission:

    1. ◦

      if the property is subject to a fixed charge, the company must apply the net proceeds (which the court may determine as net proceeds which would be realised on a sale at open market value) towards discharging the secured debt, and

    2. ◦

      if the property is subject to a floating charge, the floating charge holder will receive the same priority in respect of the sale proceeds as they had in the floating charge asset

Where monitor consent is required for such transactions, it can only be given on the basis that the action will support the rescue of the company as a going concern.

The moratorium is similar to the administration moratorium as far as action against the company is concerned:

  1. •

    no insolvency proceedings may be commenced, other than on an application by the directors or on public interest grounds

  2. •

    except with court permission (which cannot be sought to enforce a pre-moratorium debt for which the company has a payment holiday):

    1. ◦

      no steps may be taken to enforce security—though enforcement of financial collateral arrangements, such as security over shares is permitted, as is enforcement of security which was granted with monitor consent during the moratorium

    2. ◦

      no proceedings/legal process may be commenced or continued against the company or its property; no landlord may exercise any forfeiture right; no steps may be taken to repossess goods under any hire-purchase agreement

In contrast to the administration moratorium, a creditor looking to enforce its debt must apply to court—there is no provision to allow the directors or the monitor to consent to enforcement of debt. Further, only creditors in respect of Non-Payment Holiday Debts may apply to court to lift the moratorium (therefore lenders can apply to court to enforce their debt and/or security, but creditors whose debts are subject to payment holidays cannot).

In addition, in relation to floating charges:

  1. •

    a provision in a floating charge instrument is void if it provides for the obtaining of a moratorium, or anything done with a view to obtaining a moratorium, to be (a) an event causing the floating charge to crystallise, (b) an event causing restrictions which would not otherwise apply to be imposed on the disposal of property by the company, or (c) a ground for the appointment of a receiver

  2. •

    no floating charge may be crystallised by a floating charge holder, nor can a floating charge holder place any new restrictions on the company’s disposal of its assets (and a floating charge holder cannot apply to court for permission to take such action)

  3. •

    if a floating charge document requires notice of crystallisation to be given within a set time frame which ends during the moratorium, the notice can be served as soon as practicable after the later of the end of the moratorium or the date the charge holder is notified of the date of the end of the moratorium. The event will be treated as occurring on the date the crystallisation notice is given

For further reading on the moratorium, see: Moratorium—overview and Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—moratorium.

See also Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—impact on CVAs.

  Key issues/discussion points
  Impact of the moratorium on lenders:
  1. •

    Companies which are parties to agreements forming part of a capital markets arrangement of more than £10m—these companies are unable to use the moratorium

  2. •

    Loan repayment—the company will still be required to make loan payments (interest, charges and capital) as they fall due during the moratorium

  3. •

    Events of default and acceleration—the moratorium itself will (in most cases, depending on the drafting of the events of default clause) trigger an event of default giving the lender the ability to accelerate the debt. Acceleration and demand of debt is not prevented by the moratorium nor by the new the restriction on use of termination clauses (see above)

  4. •

    Interaction with lenders prior to the moratorium—the legislation does not provide for any advance notification to or consent from secured lenders/ QFCHs to enter the moratorium, which means that QFCHs do not have the same formal control over the process as they would have in respect of administration (see Practice Note: Floating charges—advantages and disadvantages—Advantage: Appointment of administrator and/or administrative receiver). However, in practice lenders are likely to still have influence and some control. This is because, if the lender accelerates the debt during the moratorium, the full debt (not just payments falling due before or during the moratorium period (eg interest, charges, capital repayment due in the ordinary course) will fall due for payment as a Non-Payment Holiday Debt. If the company is not able to pay the full debt, the moratorium must terminate. To avoid that, the company will want ...

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—key regulator and court guidance for corporate crime practitioners
Nodes.BodyContent:
As part of the response to the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, the courts and various regulatory bodies have issued guidance to users and businesses explaining how daily court activity and the usual regulation of business activities have been adapted to account for the necessary restrictions implemented by the government to combat the impact of COVID-19.

This Practice Note highlights key guidance which will be of interest to lawyers advising on a range of corporate crime and regulatory issues during the pandemic and is intended to provide a convenient and accessible collection of guidance relevant to corporate crime practitioners.

Criminal courts in England and Wales

The work of the criminal courts has been disrupted as a result of COVID-19 and HM Courts and Tribunal Service (HMCTS) continually reviews and prioritises the work being conducted in magistrates’ courts, Crown Courts, High Courts and the Court of Appeal, Criminal Division. The conduct of jury trials has been a particular area of focus as adaptations are made to ensure that criminal trials can take place while social distancing measures remain in force.

HMCTS publishes, and updates, details of priority courts, changes to court and tribunal hearings and guidance on telephone and video hearings.

Practitioners will be interested in the following guidance issued by HMCTS and the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) for criminal cases in England and Wales.

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—impact on private M&A transactions
Nodes.BodyContent:
Factors affecting deal activity

The Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic will have an effect for its duration on many aspects of corporate law for legal practitioners and their clients. The impact on private M&A transactions will probably go beyond the period of the pandemic itself as regards the impact on the economy and individual businesses. Specific consequences that directly result from the pandemic include:

  1. •

    financial viability of conducting an acquisition—given the economic upheaval and shock to the world economy, will buyers have the necessary available funds to carry out a private M&A transaction? A potential buyer may look to maintain or bolster its cash reserves rather than seek out acquisition opportunities as a means of prudent financial management to weather the challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic

  2. •

    heightened transaction risk—there is increased risk for a buyer in concluding a transaction during a time of extreme volatility, which could lead to the buyer overpaying for its acquisition target or acquiring what transpires to be a flawed asset. Distressed sales once the effects of the pandemic have played out may provide better valuations and decreased risk

  3. •

    valuation difficulties—this is linked to the point above and covers the difficulty the buyer will face in carrying out an accurate assessment of the value of the target company or business/assets (target) it looks to acquire (as per comments above, valuation may be easier to determine at a later date and/or under a distressed sale)

  4. •

    delays in deal activity—as described above, rather than proceed with a purchase of a given target while the COVID-19 pandemic is ongoing, buyers may opt to wait for the value of such target to decrease over time owing to the effects of the pandemic and then acquire the relevant target at a discounted price, ie wait for the target to become a distressed asset

  5. •

    increased focus on existing business—companies may find themselves more occupied with ensuring during the COVID-19 pandemic that their existing operations remain on a sound financial footing rather than pursuing any deal activity (although it could prompt sales if the seller’s group is under financial pressure as a result of COVID-19)

From a practical standpoint, the various ‘lockdown’ or ‘stay at home’ measures which have been imposed across the world by various governments due to COVID-19 will have an effect on how private M&A transactions are conducted. Negotiations will have to be conducted virtually over telephone and video conference, although it is also likely that in many circumstances negotiations between principals to agree headline terms at the outset of the transaction will simply be delayed until meetings can occur face to face. As considered in this Practice Note, the eventual execution of the transaction documentation would need to occur entirely remotely. Looking to a post-coronavirus environment, remote execution may become more standard as parties adapt to the ‘new norm’.

For a general overview of the key issues that may arise for corporate practitioners in relation to the COVID-19 pandemic, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—key issues for Corporate lawyers.

Due diligence

Before acquiring the shares in a private limited company/unlisted public company or a business and its assets, a potential buyer will want to carry out due diligence to gather information about the target it is seeking to acquire. As part of this due diligence exercise, the potential buyer may also want to carry out a specific COVID-19 due diligence exercise concerning the exposure of the target to COVID-19 risks, both in the short-term and the longer-term. This exercise, in tandem with the buyer’s due diligence findings on other aspects of the target, will provide the required information for the buyer to decide whether or not to proceed with the acquisition based on the risks, liabilities and value identified through this due diligence exercise.

Data rooms

From a purely practical standpoint, the various ‘lockdown’ or ‘stay at home’ measures which have been imposed across the world by various governments mean that while the COVID-19 pandemic is ongoing, the prospect of a buyer conducting due diligence through the use of physical data rooms will be highly unlikely. The same will apply to certain steps which a buyer may typically undertake as part of its due diligence process, such as site visits to the target’s various premises and physical meetings with target management. It is therefore likely to be necessary for the seller to put in place a virtual data room to house due diligence material, ie an online (often cloud-based) repository and document sharing platform to give the buyer and its advisers access to the documents and information that they need to conduct their due diligence exercise in relation to the target. There may also be practical challenges for the seller in compiling this virtual data room, ie the seller may need to arrange for its personnel to access target premises which have been closed due to COVID-19 restrictions, in order to access and physically upload onto the virtual data room site due diligence materials relating to the target.

Where a data room is not envisaged, there will still potentially be many practical difficulties that the seller would face in collating responses and appropriate documentation in response to the buyer’s due diligence enquiries while lockdown measures are in place (or while movement and access to all the target’s sites and offices is restricted or hampered).

Issues to focus on in due diligence

Key issues that the buyer will seek to explore during due diligence include:

  1. •

    financial impact of COVID-19 on the target—the buyer should explore in due diligence the viability of the target’s continuing operations due to the effects of COVID-19. In particular, the buyer may look to explore the extent to which the target benefits from governmental schemes to aid businesses during the pandemic, such as the UK’s Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme and the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)

  2. •

    operational and trading impact of COVID-19 on the target’s suppliers/customers—this will be linked to the point above and will involve a buyer exploring to what extent the operations of the target’s business will be affected, eg the extent to which the following may be compromised:

    1. ◦

      suppliers' continuing ability to provide goods and/or services to the target, and

    2. ◦

      customers’ continuing ability to buy goods and/or services from the target

  3. •

    financing arrangements—the buyer should examine the terms of the target’s credit facilities carefully, to assess whether the economic effects of COVID-19 may cause the target to breach the terms of its facility agreement (any prior or potential breaches of financial covenants may lead to the target ceasing to have access to credit funds post-acquisition) and therefore consider whether the buyer would be able to fund any resulting financing shortfall from its own cash/financing arrangements

  4. •

    material contracts—the buyer should examine key contracts entered into by the target, eg with key clients and suppliers, to ascertain whether the terms of such contracts have been breached and assess the risk attached to any future breach of contract (by any one contract party) flowing from COVID-19 impact. This is always an important element of due diligence in an acquisition but the level of risk is likely to be heightened (potentially for a prolonged period) and therefore may pose substantial risk to the target and the acquisition (depending on the nature of the target’s business and contracts involved)

  5. •

    IT infrastructure—given the need for the vast majority of businesses to have effective remote/virtual working capabilities in place (both immediately in response to the COVID-19 pandemic and potentially more generally in the future if working patterns continue to be altered), the buyer will need to examine the target’s IT arrangements to ensure that the business is properly equipped to function in an environment where its personnel work remotely from home. Other areas which the buyer would seek to cover as part of this review include, the examination of the target’s business continuity arrangements, disaster recovery plans and insurance arrangements (see Practice Note: Business continuity plan—BCP—a practical guide)

  6. •

    employees—in addition to ensuring the target’s staff are able to work remotely from home, the buyer will wish to review any arrangements the target has put in place in relation to its employees due to the economic effects of COVID-19, eg plans to furlough employees, offer unpaid leave, offer sabbaticals, reduce working days/hours, etc. Here, the buyer will look to assess the risks of the target undertaking these arrangements

Many of the assessments that any buyer must make while conducting due diligence are fraught with multiple uncertainties, in particular as regards the length of time that the COVID-19 pandemic impacts on all forms of economic activity and behaviour and the time that it will take for these impacts to play out as regards impact on the target’s business.

For further information on the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Job Retention Scheme (CJRS), see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020). For further information on the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme, see Q&A: What is the Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme and how can borrowers access it?

For further information on due diligence in a private M&A context, including on the use of physical and virtual data rooms, see Practice Notes: Due diligence—share and asset purchases and Data rooms—share and asset purchases.

Consideration

The following factors, among others, are likely to be relevant in determining the level of consideration the parties agree on in respect of the target:

  1. •

    difficulties in valuing the target—valuing the target is likely to be more difficult given all the uncertainties in the economy and therefore poses an increased risk for the buyer. The buyer is likely to place a greater emphasis on the most up to date financial information relating to the target, to assess how the target is coping financially as near as possible to the time of the deal’s conclusion. The buyer may therefore insist on more fulsome management accounts relating to the target and push for more comprehensive warranties. In addition, the buyer is likely to have a higher degree of difficulty in valuing targets engaged. Acquisitions in sectors that are disproportionately affected by the pandemic, such as travel, restaurants and the retail sector will pose the greatest risk for any buyer, not least because of uncertainty as to whether the business will remain financially viable throughout the course of the pandemic and beyond. Distressed sales may ultimately prove more likely therefore

  2. •

    deal structuring adjustments—due to various uncertainties flowing from the pandemic, including the overall impact on a potential target, the buyer may look to defer a portion (or a greater portion than typically seen) of the consideration, as a means in some instances for the buyer to defer questions of valuation until after the transaction’s completion, thus permitting the buyer to form a more accurate picture of the target’s value which takes into account the post-completion effects of COVID-19. The buyer may therefore seek to include provisions for post-completion adjustments to the consideration. Conversely, the seller will be likely to argue for as much of the consideration as possible to be in the form of cash, especially if it is a distressed seller due to the ravages of the pandemic. The buyer may look therefore to pay part of the consideration up front and the rest in instalments post-completion or may opt to have part of the consideration subject to an earn-out, whereby part of the purchase price is calculated by reference to the future profits and performance of the target for a specified period following completion. For further information on such consideration adjustment mechanisms, see Practice Note: Consideration adjustments (completion accounts, locked box and earn-outs)—share and asset purchases

  3. •

    difficulties in raising acquisition finance—due to COVID-19, there is far less credit available in the market for potential buyers. This is likely to affect the ability of a buyer to raise acquisition finance and likely to have an effect, in particular, on management buyout transactions where bank debt often forms a key part of the transaction. Buyers with significant retained cash reserves are therefore more likely to be active in the market and favoured by sellers looking to dispose of shares or assets. For further information on such matters, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19) implications for Banking & Finance lawyers and the sections dealing with General lending and Leveraged finance

  4. •

    share consideration and equity finance—if the buyer is a listed company and is looking to allot/issue shares to the seller as either full or partial consideration for the acquisition of the target, this will pose a risk to the seller because the volatility of the markets due to COVID-19 may act to reduce the value of the shares offered to the seller (and indeed the buyer’s own share price may be underperforming relative to the market as a whole). Sellers are therefore likely to prefer cash consideration more than in normal market conditions. Similarly, if the buyer is looking to conduct an equity capital raise, such as a rights issue or open offer, to raise funds for the purchase of the target, this may also prove difficult due to current market conditions. However, the buyer’s shares could still prove an attractive form of consideration for the seller if the buyer’s prospects have improved for whatever reason (including where the buyer’s strong balance sheet/cash reserves make it a relative safe haven). Similarly, if such companies are looking to raise funds in the capital markets to fund acquisition opportunities, such equity raises may prove attractive

  5. •

    buyer’s ability to fulfil obligations—given the disruption to the world economy caused by COVID-19, the seller may have concerns about the buyer’s ability to meet its obligations in any deal, especially in cases where some or a substantial part of the consideration is deferred post-completion. In this respect, the seller is likely to be more insistent on including mechanisms in the deal documentation to allay any such concerns The seller may insist on part of the consideration being placed in an escrow account post-completion to meet future buyer payment obligations under the documentation or that the buyer’s parent company (if any) provides a guarantee for the buyer’s obligations

Conditions to completion

A buyer is more likely to insist that any deal to acquire a target is carried out on a conditional basis (the SPA/APA setting out the conditions that must be satisfied before completion can take place, with a gap in time between exchange/signing, at which time the SPA/APA is signed, and the later completion of the acquisition). Bolstering the conditionality of the agreement allows the buyer to assess the effects of COVID-19 on the business post-signing and prior to completion and allows it, subject to the drafting of such conditions, to either amend the deal agreed or withdraw from the transaction. Conversely, the seller will be keen for signing and completion to be simultaneous, to avoid any risk that the deal is amended or terminated post-signing, especially if it is in a distressed situation due to COVID-19. In this regard, the seller may be thwarted in this desire due to the severity of the pandemic’s effects on the world economy (for example if it needs the sale proceeds to bolster its own finances). For information on the issues that normally arise in private M&A transactions where there is a split exchange and completion, see Practice Note: Issues arising where there is split exchange and completion—share and asset purchases.

Regulatory approvals

If the transaction is subject to regulatory clearance, such as merger control laws at a national or at an EU level, the buyer will typically seek to include a condition in the SPA/APA for such transaction to be approved by the relevant authorities prior to the transaction completing. Merger review processes are being impacted worldwide as merger control authorities adapt to take account of the consequences of COVID-19. Given the turmoil caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, many cases may face changes in approach and practice. For example, there could be delays in certain circumstances in obtaining regulatory approval for such transactions, it being highly likely that extended review timetables will be imposed by the relevant authorities in respect of such transactions. This may need to be factored into the transaction planning and documentation, perhaps by having a later long stop date (see below) or by ensuring such date can be easily extended. If any such delays are likely to be significant, a seller may be less willing to sell to a buyer who is required to seek such regulatory approvals.

At the EU level, the Commission is encouraging merging parties to delay notifications and discuss timing of transactions with the relevant case teams, as the Commission is facing difficulties in collecting information from the parties and the market (eg customers, competitors and suppliers). Requests for information that stop the clock or instances of ‘pull and refile’ cannot be excluded. However, the Commission will review cases in which parties can show very compelling reasons to proceed with a merger notification without delay (the Commission has been accepting simplified filings).

At the UK level, the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) will continue to progress ongoing merger investigations and has issued guidance on its approach to merger assessments during the COVID-19 pandemic. The CMA is not asking merging parties to delay notifications, but is encouraging parties to consider whether some filings could be postponed (eg if a merger is not particularly well-advanced and may not ultimately proceed). Pre-notification talks may take longer because of difficulties in obtaining information from the merging parties and from third parties. The CMA will continue to use its power to issue mandatory information requests with deadlines. However, the CMA recognises that staffing shortages or remote working environments may make it harder for companies to meet mandatory deadlines for producing information. The CMA is unlikely to exercise its statutory finding power in such cases. However, the CMA may stop the clock if merging parties are unable to provide information in due time. In terms of substance, the CMA has confirmed that its review standard will not be relaxed and that interim measures will still be imposed when necessary. Given the economic impact of COVID-19, the CMA has also restated its approach to the ‘failing firm’ defence (the CMA expects firms to claim more frequently that the target is failing, but will maintain the established (demanding) standard for establishing that a firm is ‘failing’). All meetings are being conducted remotely via videoconferencing or telephone, and the CMA is well prepared for remote working following a recent upgrade in technology infrastructure.

For further information on how the review process from a UK competition perspective may be affected by the coronavirus pandemic, see News Analysis: Coronavirus (COVID-19) and application of UK competition law.

Material adverse change (MAC)

A buyer may wish to insert a material adverse change (MAC) clause into any SPA/APA it concludes for the transaction, thereby giving it a right to terminate the agreement if there is a MAC which affects the business between exchange and completion.
