Nodes.Title: Limitation—the principal limitation periods
Nodes.BodyContent:
The principal limitation periods

The following table includes the principal types of action and details the number of years within which such a claim can be brought under the Limitation Act 1980 (LA 1980), noting relevant statutory provisions and authorities as appropriate.

Note that the table is not exhaustive. It focuses on the actions that are most likely to be of interest to a dispute resolution practitioner and does not cover certain very specific claims, for example subsequent conversions of goods (LA 1980, s 3), although these are set out in the LA 1980.

For further information on the principal types of claims, see Practice Notes:

  1. •

    Limitation—contract claims

  2. •

    Limitation—tort claims

  3. •

    Limitation—professional negligence claims

  4. •

    Limitation—constructive trust claims

See also Practice Notes:

  1. •

    Limitation Act 1980—general application, for guidance on how to determine a limitation period (ie when time runs from and when time stops running), and

  2. •

    Limitation—extensions of time under the Limitation Act 1980, Limitation—latent damage and Limitation—fraud, deliberate concealment and mistake for potential ways in which the limitation period applicable to a claim might be postponed or extended under LA 1980

Type of claim Limitation period Reference Additional information
Simple contract Six years LA 1980, s 5 LA 1980, s 5 is broadly understood to apply by way of default, when no other specific provision (under the LA 1980 or as agreed between the parties) applies to a contract.
It has also been held that LA 1980, s 5 applies to a restitutionary claim for unjust enrichment (a claim for ‘money had and received') (see below).
For further information on limitation in relation to contracts, see Practice Note: Limitation—contract claims.
Certain loans Six years from the date of demand LA 1980, s 6 Where a loan agreement does not provide for repayment of the debt on or before a fixed or determinable date and does not make the obligation to repay dependent on demand, LA 1980, s 6 essentially provides that the six-year period under LA 1980, s 5 runs from the date of demand.
For further information, see Practice Note: Limitation—contract claims, together with the Q&A: What is the limitation period for recovering monies loaned to another party?
Speciality 12 years LA 1980, s 8 LA 1980, s 8(1) is primarily cited in respect of contracts executed under seal (ie deeds)—see Practice Note: Limitation—contract claims.
In addition, an Act of Parliament can define an obligation as being a ‘speciality’ plus the 12-year limitation period under LA 1980, s 8 will also apply to any claims concerning non-monetary statutory rights (ie those not covered by LA 1980, s 9, or any other provision of the LA 1980 (for example, LA 1980, s 2)) since statutes are also a form of speciality (Collin v Duke of Westminster [1985] 1 All ER 463). As set out in Claimants in the Royal Mail Group Litigation v Royal Mail Group Ltd [2020] EWHC 97 (Ch) (at para [187]), both ‘the right to claim and the appropriate remedies’ must derive from statute in order for the claim to fall within LA 1980, s 8.
Note that LA 1980, s 8(2) states that LA 1980, s 8(1) ‘...shall not affect any action for which a shorter period of limitation is prescribed by any other provision of [the LA 1980]’.
Sums recoverable by statute Six years LA 1980, s 9 The case Rowan Companies Inc v Lambert Eggink Offshore Transport Consultants [1999] All ER (D) 703 held that LA 1980, s 9 was not confined to claims for liquidated sums, but rather the six-year limitation period applied to any claim for money made pursuant to a statute. The term was further construed in R v Secretary of State for Transport ex parte Factortame Ltd (No. 7) [2001] 1 WLR 942, [2000] All ER (D) 2082 as referring to sums ‘specified in or directly ascertainable from the enactment. This is to be contrasted with damages recoverable under [LA 1980, s 2] which are compensatory damages assessed under common law principles and which cannot therefore be directly ascertained from the statute’ (para [185]).
Note that, if LA 1980, s 9 applies, it will form an exception to the general rule described above about specialities (see LA 1980, s 8(2)).
Note further that LA 1980, s 9 only applies when there is a sum of money recoverable as a result of a statutory provision. For example, it has been held that claims for sums due under a liability order (or equivalent) will be recoverable by virtue of that order and not as a result of any statutory provision (Bolsover District Council v Ashfield Nominees [2012] EWCA Civ 1129, [2010] All ER (D) 177 (Oct)).
In some cases, it is difficult to ascertain whether LA 1980, s 8 or s 9 applies, or indeed if LA 1980, s 2 or s 5 might be more appropriate (for example, for claims concerning data breaches or pursuant to the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986)—see below). In such circumstances, the courts will tend to look at the substance or ‘essential nature’ of the relief being sought by a claimant (Re Priory Garage (Walthamstow) Ltd [2000] Lexis Citation 13), although increasingly actions made pursuant to statutes will be held to fall under LA 1980, s 9 (see Bhattacharya v Omni Capital Partners Ltd [2020] EWHC 1644 (Ch).
Claims under the Consumer Protection Act 1987 in respect of defective products Three years from date of knowledge, subject to a ten-year longstop provision LA 1980, s 11A For more detail on such claims and relevant limitation periods, see Practice Note: Defences to a claim under the Consumer Protection Act 1987.
Claims under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 Six years / 12 years LA 1980, ss 5, 8 Section 7(3) of the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 states that LA 1980, ss 5 and 8 (depending on the type of contract) respectively include references to an action brought in reliance of section 1 of the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 (unless a shorter limitation period under the LA 1980 applies).
For further information on limitation in relation to contracts, see Practice Note: Limitation—contract claims.
Recovery of land 12 years LA 1980, s 15 For further information, see, Practice Note: Establishing adverse possession of land.
Recovery of arrears of rent Six years LA 1980, s 19 For further information, see, Practice Note: Recovering rent arrears.
Recovery of money secured by a mortgage or other charge secured on property 12 years LA 1980, s 20 Typically claims for a mortgage or charge debt are governed by LA 1980, s 20 (and not LA 1980, ss 5 and 8). This is so even if the mortgagee has exercised its power of sale before issuing proceedings seeking the recovery of arrears of principal and interest (Bristol & West plc v Bartlett; Paragon Finance plc v Banks; Halifax plc v Grant [2002] EWCA Civ 1181).
For further information, see, Practice Note: Mortgagee’s power of sale—Enforcement, and the Q&A: Where a charge over a tenanted property is granted by agreement during proceedings brought by the chargor for debt recovery, when does time begin for the purposes of limitation and what is the limitation period?
However, note that LA 1980, s 20 does not apply to charging orders. For further information, see Practice Note: Order for sale—how to enforce a charging order—Limitation bars to obtaining an order for sale, and more generally, see: Introduction to enforcement—overview.
Recovery of trust property and breach of trust Six years LA 1980, s 21(3) For more information on the application of the LA 1980 to trust claims, see Practice Note: Trust disputes—defences to breach of trust—Limitation, as well as the section below on breaches of fiduciary duty and the Practice Note: Limitation—constructive trust claims. In particular, the starting position for claims in knowing receipt and dishonest assistance is considered to be six years pursuant to LA 1980, s 21(3): see Williams v Central Bank of Nigeria [2014] UKSC 10, News Analysis: Fraudulent breach of trust and the limits of the Limitation Act 1980, as well as Q&A: What is the limitation period for knowing receipt?
Fraudulent breach of trust None, but the equitable defences of laches or acquiescence might still bar such claim LA 1980, s 21(1) For more information on fraudulent breaches of trust by constructive trustees, see Practice Note: Limitation—constructive trust claims.
In respect of the equitable defences of laches or acquiescence, see also Practice Note: Trust disputes—defences to breach of trust—Laches, as well as Trust disputes—defences to breach of trust—Release/acquiescence.
An action to enforce a judgment Six years LA 1980, s 24 An ‘action' in this context means any fresh proceedings (for example, to enforce a foreign judgment under the common law—see para [41] of Tasarruf Mevduati Sigorta Fonu v Demirel [2007] EWCA Civ 799) brought in connection with a judgment, and the six years will start from the date on which the judgment or order became enforceable.
However, as made clear in Lowsley v Forbes [1998] 3 All ER 897, there is a distinction between enforcement of a judgment obtained in England and Wales and bringing an action on it. The LA 1980 only applies to the latter, since the former is purely a procedural matter. The LA 1980 accordingly has no relevance to the general execution or enforcement of a judgment already obtained in England or Wales. A winding-up, statutory demand or bankruptcy petition based on a judgment debt is not regarded as an action on a judgment on this basis—see Ridgeway Motors (Isleworth) Ltd v ALTS Ltd [2005] EWCA Civ 92.
The court’s permission is nonetheless required to enforce a writ or warrant of execution six or more years after the date of a judgment or order (CPR 83.2(3)(a)), and the judgment creditor will be required to explain the reason for the delay. Note also that LA 1980, s 24(2) applies to bar recovery of interest by execution after six years in respect of all judgments. For further information, see the following Q&As:
  1. •

    Is permission of the court required to enforce a judgment over six years old and, if so, what rules or protocols apply to such application?

  2. •

    Is there a time limit on making an application for a charging order? In particular, does section 24 of the Limitation Act 1980 limit the court’s jurisdiction to make a charging order more than six years post judgment?


In addition, the enforcement of a charging order or third party debt order will not be regarded as an ‘action to enforce a judgment’ for LA 1980 purposes (see Practice Note: Order for sale—how to enforce a charging order—Limitation bars to obtaining an order for sale and more generally, Introduction to enforcement—overview).
Note that, despite the LA 1980 being held to have no application to the making of such orders, it is possible that the court could take any delay into account when exercising its discretion, for example, if such delay has caused undue prejudice.
Tort Six years LA 1980, s 2 A tort is essentially a civil wrong that occurs when someone unfairly causes another person to suffer loss or harm. The most common form of tort is that of negligence. However, note that the default limitation period of six years (applied to negligence, non-contractual breaches of confidence, negligent misstatement claims, conversion of goods etc), does not apply to all torts. For example, specific shorter limitation periods apply in respect of personal injury or defamation claims (see below).
Note also that the limitation period for claims under the Patents Act 1977 and section 2(1) of the Misrepresentation Act 1967 have been held to fall under LA 1980, s 2 (Green v Eadie [2011] Lexis Citation 93) rather than LA 1980, ss 5, 8 or 9. The rationale for the latter claims being considered as ‘founded on’ tort (consistent with common law misrepresentation claims) is that they have been regarded as a statutory extension of the law of deceit.
For further information, see Practice Note: Tort, negligence and nuisance claims—overview and News Analysis: Limitation: what is the limitation period for a misrepresentation claim? (Green v Eadie), as well as Q&A: What is the limitation period for a non-contractual claim for breach of confidence?
For more focused guidance on the limitation periods applicable to torts, see also Practice Notes: Limitation—tort claims, Limitation—professional negligence claims and Limitation—latent damage.
Defamation and malicious falsehood One year LA 1980, s 4A For further information, see Practice Note: Defamation—limitation.
Personal injury Three years LA 1980, s 11 For further information, see Practice Note: Time limits under the Limitation Act 1980—personal injury claims.
Claims under the Fatal Accidents Act 1976 Three years LA 1980, s 12 For further information, see Practice Note: Specific time periods for different types of personal injury claim—Fatal accidents (under the Fatal Accidents Act 1976).
Claims for contribution under the Civil Liability (Contribution) Act 1978 Two years LA 1980, s 10 For further information on contribution claims, see Practice Note: Making an additional claim under CPR 20—contribution and indemnity claims and below.

In addition to the above, note the position on limitation for the following types of claims.

Claims for equitable remedies

LA 1980, s 36 provides that if you are seeking a form of equitable relief, the time limits under the LA 1980 are not to be applied automatically when pursuing one of the following actions:

  1. •

    tort (six years)

  2. •

    libel, slander, slander of title, slander of goods or other malicious falsehood (one year)

  3. •

    simple contract (six years)

  4. •

    to enforce awards where the submission is not by an instrument under seal (six years)

  5. •

    speciality (12 years)

  6. •

    sums recoverable by virtue of any statute (six years)

  7. •

    to enforce a judgment (six years)

Equitable remedies are those which before the Judicature Acts 1873–1875 would have been available in the court of equity only, such as injunctions and orders for specific performance, both of which are specifically referred to by LA 1980, s 36. Other discretionary remedies which did not exist prior to the Judicature Acts 1873–1875 (for example, freezing orders) will likewise be included as ‘equitable relief’ for the purposes of LA 1980, s 36.

Even if it is clear that LA 1980 does not apply (in particular, to claims for specific performance or an injunction), it is important to act promptly since any delay or ‘laches’ can be taken into consideration by the courts (LA 1980, s 36(2)). As set out in P&O Nedlloyd BV v Arab Metals Co (No 2) (at para [52], and which was also discussed at para [69] of Volumatic Ltd v Ideas for Life Ltd—see News Analysis: Contractual formation, remedies and defences (Volumatic Ltd v Ideas for Life Ltd)):

‘The equitable doctrine of laches…provides the court with ample power to refuse relief when delay on the claimant’s part would make it inequitable to grant it and I should be surprised if there were many cases in which, in the absence of fraud, the court would be willing to grant relief by way of specific performance if the claim had not been made within six years after the contract was due to be performed.’

For further information, see Commentary: Effect of unconscionable delay ('laches') or acquiescence: Halsbury's Laws of England [906] and for more general information on equitable remedies, see Practice Note: Equitable remedies in contractual disputes.

Further, LA 1980, s 36(1) also includes the statement that the applicable limitation periods under the LA 1980 shall not apply ‘except in so far as any such time limit may be applied by the court by analogy in like manner as the corresponding time limit under any enactment repealed by the Limitation Act 1939’ (LA 1939). In short, the statutory limitation periods may be relevant if the courts prior to the LA 1939 would have applied the equivalent limitation period to a particular equitable remedy.

As elucidated more broadly in: Equity acts on the analogy of statutes of limitation: Halsbury's Laws of England [262]:

‘In certain cases, the Limitation Act 1980 applies expressly to equitable claims, as in the case of equitable claims to land [LA 1980, s 18(1)]; and a court of equity acts in obedience to the statute, and applies, in regard to such claims, the express bar of the statute. Moreover, when claims are made in equity which are not, as regards equitable proceedings, the subject of any express statutory bar, but the equitable proceedings correspond to a remedy at law in respect of the same matter which is subject to a statutory bar, a court of equity, in the absence of fraud or other special circumstances, adopts, by way of analogy, the same limitation for the equitable claim.’

For examples of how the courts have approached the application of LA 1980, s 36 in such context, see:

  1. •

    National Private Air Transport Services Company v Kaki, in which the court applied by analogy the statutory limitation period for torts in respect of a claim seeking rescission for misrepresentation. The cause of action would accordingly have become time barred six years after the damage had been sustained

  2. •

    Wood v Commercial First, in which the court indicated that equitable claims for compensation based on Commercial First’s accessory liability concerning a breach of fiduciary duty would be barred by analogy as a result of the application of LA 1980, s 36 in the event that such claims could not properly be characterised as claims for money had and received (and thereby would be barred as a direct result of LA 1980, s 5 (see below)). For further details of this case, see News Analysis: Mortgages—validity—mortgage broker receiving payment from both lender and borrower (Wood v Commercial First Business Ltd (in Liquidation))

Declarations

Claims for declarations in respect of debts or damages are not divorced from the causes of action (in contract or tort etc) forming the basis of the declarations sought.

In Woodeson v Credit Suisse, the Court of Appeal upheld a decision to grant summary judgment on claims against a bank for declarations arising out of cross-claims for damages for breach of statutory duty and negligence. If the underlying causes of actions are time barred, as they were found to be in this case, so too will be the claim for a declaration. For further information, see News Analysis: Limitation—declarations and concealment (Woodeson and another v Credit Suisse).

This point was further considered in Claimants in the Royal Mail Group Litigation (at para [207]). The approach set out in Woodeson v Credit Suisse was expressly followed.

Breaches of fiduciary duty claims

The courts application of LA 1980, s 36 has additionally been considered in a series of cases concerning breaches of fiduciary duty.

Nodes.Title: Limitation Act 1980—general application
Nodes.BodyContent:
In this Practice Note, the Limitation Act 1980 is referred to as LA 1980.

The function of limitation periods

Statutory limitation periods seek to regulate the balance between interests which compete and sometimes conflict:

  1. •

    the interest of the claimant in having the most extensive opportunity to pursue claims for legal redress, and

  2. •

    the interest of the defendant in not having to defend stale proceedings because:

    1. ◦

      it is unfair for the 'sword of Damocles' to hang over him indefinitely

    2. ◦

      the passage of time causes memory to fade and evidence to be lost

When does the Limitation Act 1980 apply?

LA 1980 is the key statutory framework setting out the circumstances when a limitation defence may or may not be taken.

LA 1980, Part I sets out the time limits, broadly identifying how long a claimant has to 'bring actions' against another party. For an overview of the principal limitation periods under LA 1980, see Practice Note: Limitation—the principal limitation periods. Note also that 'actions' includes 'any proceeding in a court of law, including an ecclesiastical court' (LA 1980, s 38(1)), and LA 1980 applies to arbitral proceedings as it applies to legal proceedings (under section 13 of the Arbitration Act 1996 (AA 1996)).

LA 1980, Part II sets out the circumstances under which the ‘ordinary time limits’ provided by LA 1980, Part I can be extended or excluded (see below) and LA 1980, Part III includes a number of miscellaneous provisions, including:

  1. •

    LA 1980, s 37, which concerns the application of LA 1980 to the Crown. In general, and without prejudice to LA 1980, s 39 (see below) plus the exceptions listed in LA 1980, s 37(2), LA 1980 applies to proceedings by or against the Crown as it would against any other party

  2. •

    LA 1980, s 39, which makes clear that the general provisions of LA 1980 shall not apply where another statute provides a specific limitation period for a claim. For more information, see the Practice Note: Limitation—the principal limitation periods—Saving for other limitation enactments

It has been said that LA 1980 was intended to constitute a complete code, such that it provides exhaustively for the circumstances in which limitation defences may or may not be taken (Chagos Islanders v A-G, see para [45]) subject to the express saving for ‘other limitation enactments’ at LA 1980, s 39 and the defences which are peculiar to equity (see LA 1980, s 36 and Practice Note: Limitation—the principal limitation periods—Claims for equitable remedies).

However, it is important to be aware that the parties might have agreed to vary a limitation period applicable to a claim. For example, parties can seek to agree a shorter limitation period (subject to any appropriate controls concerning the limitation of liability, as to which, see Practice Note: Exclusion and limitation of liability). In addition, it is possible that a defendant will be precluded from relying on a technically available limitation defence since, for example:

  1. •

    the defendant might have contracted not to take any such defence, or have specifically agreed to a longer limitation period than would otherwise apply. In particular, the parties might have entered into a standstill agreement to suspend or extend limitation (see below)

  2. •

    the defendant might be otherwise estopped from invoking such a defence. In Saunders v Caerphilly County Borough Council, the court held that it would be unconscionable for the defendant to take a limitation defence since it was implicit in the correspondence that no limitation point would be taken

  3. •

    likewise, the court held that it would be an abuse of process to permit Pakistan’s limitation defence to certain restitutionary claims in High Commissioner for Pakistan in the UK v Prince Mukkaram Jah (see paras [280]–[285]). The abuse was said to arise out of a combination of: i) Pakistan’s assertion of sovereign immunity, which had previously prevented the defendants’ claims from being made; ii) Pakistan’s waiver of that immunity by the bringing of a claim over the same property which the defendants’ had a claim; and iii) the assertion against those rivals claim of a limitation defence that it had been open to Pakistan not to take. The paragraphs in Pakistan’s statements of case asserting the limitation defence were struck out accordingly. For further information on that case, see News Analysis: After more than 70 years, the heirs of a beneficiary are entitled to his trust fund (High Commissioner for Pakistan in the United Kingdom v Prince Mukarram Jah, His Exalted Highness The 8th Nizam of Hyderabad and others)

Determining the limitation period

It is important to determine when a limitation period expires and therefore it is critical to understand when the limitation period started and whether that date can be postponed under LA 1980.

When time runs from

Time will start to run at different points for different causes of action. Typically, the date that a cause of action accrues will be pertinent: for example, time runs from the date of breach in simple contract claims.

In considering what is meant by the phrase a cause of action, the Court of Appeal in Read v Brown affirmed the definition 'every fact which it would be necessary for the plaintiff to prove, if traversed, in order to support his right to the judgment of the court'. As set out in Hayes v Butters, ‘a cause of action is, in modern parlance, a set of facts that entitles the claimant to relief’ (see para [56]). To determine the date from which limitation runs, you will often therefore need to understand all the legal ingredients of your claim and identify the point from when it could be said that each of those elements (ie every fact which is necessary to be proved) had been fulfilled. Depending on the nature of your claim, such process can be difficult and/or open to argument (see, by way of example, McLoughlin v Chief Constable of West Yorkshire at paras [52]–[54]).

For more information on the limitation periods for the different types of claims, see Practice Notes:

  1. •

    Limitation—the principal limitation periods

  2. •

    Limitation—contract claims

  3. •

    Limitation—tort claims

  4. •

    Limitation—professional negligence claims

  5. •

    Limitation—constructive trust claims

Certain general principles for the computation of time have also emerged. In particular, when calculating the expiry of a limitation period, parts of days are typically ignored. In Marren v Dawson Bentley, the claimant had been hurt in an accident at 1.30 pm on 8 November 1954 and issued proceedings on 8 November 1957. Havers J held that the claim had not become time-barred at the end of 7 November 1957 since, when a cause of action accrues during the course of a day, that day is disregarded when calculating the running of time.

However, in the event that a cause of action accrues on the stroke of midnight, and so is completely constituted at the very first moment of a particular day, that day should not be excluded from the calculation for LA 1980 purposes—see the Court of Appeal judgment in Matthew v Sedman, upholding the findings of HHJ Hodge QC in the High Court, and referencing Gelmini v Moriggia as good law on this point. There are no ‘fractions of days’ to be disregarded in ‘midnight deadline’ cases. For more information, see News Analyses:

  1. •

    Limitation and the stroke of midnight (Matthew v Sedman)

  2. •

    High Court considers limitation when cause of action accrues at midnight (Matthew v Sedman)

When does time stop running?

Once time starts to run, the general long-standing rule is that nothing can interrupt it (Purnell v Roche), despite the fact that such principle can have some seemingly harsh consequences. However, time may be interrupted if, for example:

  1. •

    there is a statutory provision to that effect (for example, AA 1996, s 13(2))

  2. •

    there is a deliberate concealment by the defendant of a material fact after the cause of action has accrued (Sheldon v Outhwaite). If after the accrual of the cause of action a defendant takes steps to conceal relevant facts, the claimant will have the full limitation period applicable to that cause of action within which to bring their claim, starting from the date of discovery of the concealment. For further information, see Practice Note: Limitation—fraud, deliberate concealment and mistake

Time stops running for limitation purposes when the claim is 'brought'. It is important to be aware that this is the date the claim form (together with the correct court fee, discussed further below) is received by the court for the purposes of issuing it and not the issue of the claim form itself, which is the start of the proceedings for most purposes (CPR PD 7A, paras 5.1, 5.2 and Barnes v St Helens). In the event that the expiry of a limitation period is imminent, it is therefore sensible to request that a duplicate copy of the claim form and/or covering letter be stamped by the court office, and to retain such stamped copy as evidence of the date when the claimant’s request for the issue of a claim form had been received (Secretary of State for Trade and Industry v Vahora).

Further, as a general rule, if the last day of the prescribed limitation period falls on a day when the court office is closed for the whole day (for example, a Saturday), the statutory period will be construed as ending not on that day, but on the next day when the court office is open (Pritam Kaur v S Russell).

The same principle was applied in Calverton Parish Council v Nottingham City Council, which concerned the time period for bringing a claim under the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004, and in Yadly Marketing Company Ltd v Secretary of State for the Home Department, about the statutory period for bringing an appeal pursuant to the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006. In the later case, the Court of Appeal rejected the argument that the time for filing an appeal could be construed as ending on a day when the court office was closed, because the act in question was the filing of a document, which required no involvement of the court and so the document could be filed by inserting it through a letterbox or under a door of the court. In rejecting this submission, the Court of Appeal stated that not only were the documents in question required to be taken to the court office (as opposed to being posted through a letterbox), but that to encourage the filing of documents in this manner would create uncertainty (not least, the court in question might not have a letterbox) and risk the documents being mislaid.

However, Croke v Secretary Of State For Communities and Local Government provides a reminder not to leave the issue of a claim to the last minute. In that case, the claimant sought to issue the claim by attending court five minutes before the office closed on the last day of the limitation period, and alleged that he had been refused entry to the court building by security. The claimant relied on Calverton to suggest that, since he was denied entry to the court while the court office was open, it was not functioning and he should therefore have been permitted to issue proceedings on the next day when the court office was fully accessible. Robinson HHJ rejected this argument, relying on comments of Lord Neuberger in Mucelli v Government of Albania, in which he stated, obiter, that, in contrast to where the court office is closed for a whole day, where the court office is open during normal office hours but is closed before midnight on the final day of a limitation period (as will always be true of the court), a litigant can have no cause for complaint that he was unable to file the claim outside normal office hours, and time is not extended until the next day, so long as the court office was open during normal office hours. Robinson HHJ noted that litigants whose claims are subject to strict time limits must make arrangements to ensure that they attend the court office in good time so that they are not thwarted by any unexpected problems.

For further information on how to issue a claim form, see Practice Note: Claim form—filing and issuing.

Failure to pay the correct court fee

Following the Court of Appeal case Barnes, a number of authorities have considered if a claim has been brought for limitation purposes where an incorrect court fee has been paid. In particular, in Page v Hewetts Solicitors, it was held that the claimants had not done all that was required to commence proceedings before the limitation period expired since the claimant had failed to pay the correct court fee on issue and the mistake was not spotted until after the limitation period has expired. For more information on this decision, see News Analysis: Claims time-barred due to wrong fee and failure to follow up (Page v Hewetts).

Where the underpayment of the court fee is due to court staff error, the claimant may nevertheless be able to show that he has brought the claim for limitation purposes. In Bhatti v Asghar, Warby J reviewed the previous authorities dealing with a failure to pay the correct court fee, including Page, and concluded that they identified a clear principle by which the court is to determine whether a claim has been brought for the purposes of stopping the limitation period from running. In particular, he considered that principle to be that a claim is brought ‘when the party concerned has done all that is in his power or to set the wheels of justice in motion' and this will ordinarily include 'proffering the correct fee to the court office at the same time as presenting the claim form’, but if there has been a failing on the part of the court (for example, if the court assumed the burden of calculating the correct fee and made an error) this might lead to the claim having been brought in circumstances where the correct fee was not paid. For more information, see News Analysis: Underpayment of court fee and effect on limitation (Bhatti v Asghar).

However, note the criticism of Warby J's summary of this principle in Dixon v Radley House Partnership, in which Stuart-Smith J concluded that payment of 'the appropriate fee' at the time of issue as calculated by reference to the value of the claim set out in the original claim form (and particulars of claim if served together) is sufficient to stop time running for limitation purposes and that, in the absence of abusive behaviour, the appropriate fee is not to be determined by reference to claims articulated at a later stage, whether or not the claimant intended to bring those later claims at the time of issue. For a more detailed consideration of this case, see News Analysis: Claim not statute barred because of payment of incorrect court fee (Dixon v Radley House).

In the later decision of Wells v Wood, the County Court reviewed all of the above authorities and concluded that none of these cases supported the view that a claim form issued and sealed by the court (regardless of the fee paid) is ineffective to stop the limitation clock. The judge referred to the distinction between bringing a claim for limitation purposes and starting a claim (as elucidated in CPR PD 7A, paras 5.1, 5.2) and concluded that:

‘…while there may be questions yet to be answered on how payment of the incorrect court fee affects the bringing of a claim for limitation purposes where the Claim Form is issued outside the limitation period, that is not what I am dealing with here. In the application before me the Claim Form was issued within the limitation period and in my judgment with that step the claim was both brought and started…

In my judgment questions of payment of court fees are primarily between the paying party and HMCTS. Such matters may become of interest to other parties where it is alleged that there is abuse of process or in the particular circumstances of investigating whether a party has done all in its power to set the wheels of justice in motion so as to have brought the claim before issue…

In the current case, the payment of the wrong fee at issue had no effect on the validity of the Claim Form or its stopping of the limitation clock. It was a matter which needed correcting and that has now happened.’

For more information, see News Analysis: Effect of payment of incorrect court fee on limitation (Wells v Wood).

The misgiving expressed by Stuart-Smith J about the course embarked on by the courts post Page were also echoed in the case of Atha & Co Solicitors v Liddle. Despite the claimant's solicitor's apparent abuse of court process in those proceedings, by deliberately undervaluing the claim to pay a smaller court fee, Turner J concluded that the claim had nonetheless been ‘brought for limitation purposes at the time the claim form was received by the court and not when it was later issued’. He added ‘by way of postscript’ to his judgment though that ‘…the proliferation of irreconcilable first instance decisions over the last few years is such that the time is now ripe for authoritative guidance from the Court of Appeal’. For further information, see News Analysis: Limitation and deliberate underpayment of court fee (Atha & Co Solicitors v Liddle).

Note also that the court in Glenluce Fishing Company v Watermota referred to the evolving case law concerning the effect of underpayment of the court issue fee and the significance of this in considering whether the claim has been brought for limitation purposes and stated that such authorities should be limited to applications to strike out claims and was not to be extended to cases concerning applications to amend a claim under CPR 17.4. For more information, see News Analysis: Payment of the incorrect court fee, limitation and applications to amend (Glenluce Fishing Company v Watermota) and Practice Note: Limitation—amendments to statements of case and counterclaims.

For further information on the payment of court fees, see Practice Note: Court fees in civil proceedings.

Abuse of process

There is authority to suggest that it can be considered an abuse of process if a claimant deliberately understates the value of a claim so as to reduce the court fee payable on issue (Lewis v Ward Hadaway). If the limitation period expires before the appropriate fee is paid, the claimant might also be found not to have brought the claim within the limitation period for the purposes of LA 1980 and the claim may therefore be summarily dismissed. For more information, see News Analysis: Dangers of deliberate understatement of claim value to reduce court fee (Lewis v Ward Hadaway).

However in Wiseman v Marston's, the County Court allowed an appeal against a decision to refuse a claimant permission to amend a claim form to increase the quantum of damages sought (which increased the court fee payable) after the expiry of the limitation period. In this case the court held that there was no abuse of process. The solicitor had issued the claim close to the limitation period where counsel had been unable to advise on quantum prior to the effluxion of the limitation period and, once the increased value was known, an application to amend was made promptly. In addition, with liability having been admitted by the defendant, the injustice to the claimant in not permitting the amendment would have been significant. For more information on this case see News Analysis: Paying the correct court fee: strike out or amendment? (Wiseman v Marston’s). Also of note is the refusal of Jackson LJ to permit a second appeal of this decision, in which he stated that this case was ‘quite unlike’ Lewis, in which there was ‘deliberate conduct designed to avoid paying the correct fee’.

Further, in Atha, Turner J expressly declined to follow the reasoning in Lewis in a case where it appeared that the claimant's solicitors had deliberately understated the value of the claim in order to reduce the court fee. He noted that the court retains the power to strike out a claim ‘in the event that the abuse is sufficiently egregious’, but that the conduct in the present case fell ‘very short of such a level’. He concluded that the incorrect payment of the court fee, even though deliberate and an apparent abuse of process, had no impact on the timing of the issue of the claim and ‘it would be wrong to permit the provisions of [LA 1980] to be deployed as a tool of retrospective and disproportionately draconian discipline’. For further information, see News Analysis: Limitation and deliberate underpayment of court fee (Atha & Co Solicitors v Liddle), as well as Practice Note: Strike out for abuse of process (civil) (CPR 3.4(2)(b)).

Note that it may in addition be considered an abuse of process to issue a protective claim for limitation purposes when, at the time of issue, there is no valid basis for the claim being made other than to stop time running (Nomura International v Granada Group). In contrast, it is not abusive to bring a claim that is prima facie time-barred, since limitation is a matter to be raised in defence and there could be cause to argue that the standard limitation period should not apply in the circumstances (see the comments of Nicklin J at para [53] of Churchil v Open College Network South Eastern Region, as well as below for further information on the effect of a limitation period expiring).

Standstill agreements

In the event that there is a prospective claim and the end of the limitation period is approaching, the parties should consider entering into an agreement, known as a standstill agreement, to suspend the running of the limitation period or extend the limitation period to a specific date. These agreements are frequently encountered in (but by no means restricted to) the sphere of professional indemnity litigation. Their purpose is usually to permit time for investigation, compliance with a pre-action protocol and/or to allow negotiations to take place without the need for the claimant to issue what might later turn out to be unnecessary, or at least premature, protective proceedings. They will commonly preserve any crystallised limitation defence and be subject to termination on a specified period of notice and/or date.

Where parties enter into negotiations prior to the bringing of a claim, it is important for the claimant to be aware of any potential limitation defence and to consider whether a standstill agreement might be necessary. Nodes.Title: Standstill agreements to suspend or extend limitation
Nodes.BodyContent:
As observed by Coulson J in Russell v Stone, ‘standstill agreements have become much more common than they ever used to be’ and yet, as that case demonstrated, they are often far from straight forward agreements to negotiate and document. This Practice Note considers certain issues relating to the use of standstill agreements and provides links to precedent agreements.

For details of the issues that arose in Russell v Stone, see News Analysis: In brief: Claim not statute barred despite standstill agreement being poorly drafted (Russell v Stone (trading as PSP Consultants)).

For guidance on limitation more generally, see Practice Note: Limitation Act 1980—general application and related content.

Suspending or extending limitation—what is the difference and why is it important?

There is an important distinction between on the one hand suspending the running of time for a defined period, and on the other hand extending the period of limitation to a specific date:

  1. •

    when the running of time is suspended—the unexpired portion of the limitation period as at the date of the agreement will typically re-commence after the period of suspension ends

  2. •

    when the limitation period is extended—the limitation period will typically end on the date when the period of extension ends. This will usually be a date later than when the original limitation period was due to end, however this type of agreement can also be used in cases where there is uncertainty or a dispute about when the limitation period will end in order to clarify the limitation position rather than meaningfully extend the period within which any relevant claim(s) can be brought

Using a limitation suspension agreement—a practical illustration

The following is an illustration of how a limitation agreement to suspend the running of limitation can work.

The limitation period by which Party A must bring their claim against Party B expires on 31 January 2021, and the limitation period within which Party B could bring its claim against Party A expires on 15 February 2021. In late November 2020, say, Party A and Party B might still be investigating their claims and still attempting to resolve some, if not all, of the issues in dispute. Neither party will want to incur the cost and time of issuing claims and/or counterclaims if they can help it.

The parties could enter into a suspension agreement on, say, 30 November 2020 by which they agree to suspend the running of limitation from that date until either:

  1. •

    some future unspecified date when the suspension ends pursuant to service of a termination notice of the suspension agreement, or

  2. •

    15 April 2021

whichever is the earlier of the two dates.

If they choose this suspension option, it means that time will start to run again once the suspension ends, such that the portion of the limitation period which was unexpired as at 30 November 2020 would continue to run once more. In the above scenario, if the suspension period ends on 15 April 2021, then Party A would have (roughly) two months from 15 April 2021 in which to commence proceedings and Party B would have (roughly) two and a half months in which to issue its claim against Party A.

This scenario appears relatively straightforward. However, it is important to ensure that the provisions concerning the method of service of a termination notice are clear and are understood. The parties should have in mind the risk of a termination notice not being received, especially if deemed service of a termination notice by way of a single communication is agreed. It is possible that the agreement could be terminated, and the limitation period may re-commence, without the notice of termination actually having been received by the appropriate person (for example, if the notice is lost in the post or is signed for by an inappropriate person).

The key points in relation to suspension agreements are generally:

  1. •

    ensuring clarity on the scope of the dispute(s) to be covered by the agreement and in identifying the relevant parties

  2. •

    ensuring that the drafting makes clear that neither party can issue proceedings during the period of suspension

  3. •

    identifying the period of the suspension and the mechanism for, as well as the consequences of, terminating that period

  4. •

    ensuring that the risk of non-receipt of a termination notice has been considered

It is additionally useful to keep in mind section 35 of Limitation Act 1980 (LA 1980) and the limitation position on bringing counterclaims. For further information, see Practice Note: Limitation—amendments to statements of case and counterclaims—Limitation and set-offs or counterclaims.

Using a limitation extension agreement—a practical illustration

Using the same assumed claims scenario as above, the following is an illustration of how a limitation agreement to extend the running of limitation can work.

The limitation period by which Party A must bring their claim against Party B expires on 31 January 2021, and the limitation period within which Party B must bring its claim against Party A expires on 15 February 2021. In late November 2020, say, Party A and Party B might still be investigating their claims and still attempting to resolve some, if not all, of the issues in dispute. Neither party will want to incur the cost and time of issuing claims and counterclaims if they can help it.

The parties could agree to enter into a standstill agreement to extend the limitation period.

They could enter into an extension agreement on, say, 30 November 2020 by which they agree to extend the limitation period from that date until either:

  1. •

    some future unspecified date when the extension ends pursuant to service of a termination notice, or

  2. •

    15 April 2021

whichever is the earlier of the two dates.

It is assumed that the rationale for entering into an extension agreement (as opposed to a suspension agreement) is that the parties do not wish to pause the running of time but recognise that, when the limitation period does end, neither may be ready to take immediate action to issue proceedings just to prevent a limitation bar being raised and accordingly they agree to give themselves a longer period of limitation. For this reason, agreements to extend limitation usually specify a fixed date when the extension will end, rather than some unspecified point dependent on service of a notice to terminate the extension period.

    Introduction

    1. 1.1

      This policy sets out an overview of the Company’s temporary arrangements for ensuring workers stay healthy and safe while they are working in the Company’s premises during the coronavirus (or COVID-19) pandemic. It supplements, but does not replace, the Company’s health and safety policy.

    2. 1.2

      This policy does not form part of any contract of employment and the Company may amend it at any time.

    3. 1.3

      This policy applies to all employees, workers and contractors.

    4. 1.4

      The risk of coronavirus infection increases the closer you are to another person with the virus, and the amount of time you spend in close contact with them. Evidence suggests that the virus can exist for up to 72 hours on surfaces. For this reason, Public Health England recommends trying to keep two metres away from people outside your household as a precaution, or one metre when you can mitigate the risk by taking other precautions. Current government guidance also recommends:

      1. 1.4.1

        keeping your hands and face as clean as possible;

      2. 1.4.2

        working from home if you can;

      3. 1.4.3

        avoiding being face-to-face with people if they are outside your household or support bubble;

      4. 1.4.4

        reducing the number of people you spend time with in a work setting;

      5. 1.4.5

        avoiding crowded spaces;

      6. 1.4.6

        thinking about how and when you travel;

      7. 1.4.7

        washing your clothes regularly;

      8. 1.4.8

        avoiding shouting or singing close to people outside your household or support bubble;

      9. 1.4.9

        following the advice on site;

      10. 1.4.10

        keeping indoor places well-ventilated; and

      11. 1.4.11

        wearing a face covering in an enclosed space where social distancing is not possible and where you will come into contact with people you do not normally meet.

    6. 1.5

      The government guidance is updated frequently. We strongly recommend that all staff familiarise themselves with the guidance on the GOV.UK website and check regularly for updates. We will also issue updates to staff, typically by email, if changes to the government guidance affect this policy.

  3. 2

    Health and safety risk assessment

    1. 2.1

      The Company has carried out a Coronavirus health and safety risk assessment in consultation with [union-appointed health and safety representatives OR workforce-elected safety representatives OR employees]. The Company will continue to ensure that [those representatives OR employees] are involved in the development and review of this policy as circumstances change during the coronavirus pandemic.

    2. 2.2

      The purpose of this risk assessment is to identify the risks from Coronavirus to employee health and safety while working on-site and to ensure that we do everything reasonably practicable to minimise them.[ The Company’s Coronavirus health and safety risk assessment is published on the Company’s website.]

    3. 2.3

      In summary, the Company’s risk assessment has identified the following risks: [insert description of main risks identified by the risk assessment].

    4. 2.4

      The Coronavirus risk assessment will be regularly reviewed[ at least every [month]] during the pandemic, and the Workplace safety plan set out in the Schedule will be updated accordingly.

  5. 3

    Who should return to the workplace

    1. 3.1

      The Company will carry out an assessment of which employees it needs to work on-site, based on:

      1. 3.1.1

        whether they are working in a role that is critical to the business (eg for business and operational continuity, safe facility management or regulatory requirements) or not; and

      2. 3.1.2

        whether they can work from home (ie remotely).

    3. 3.2

      In determining whether you can work remotely, we will consider:

      1. 3.2.1

        the nature of your work;

      2. 3.2.2

        whether it is possible to connect safely to the Company’s systems;

      3. 3.2.3

        any home circumstances of which we are aware, eg available desk/office space, whether you live in shared accommodation; and/or

      4. 3.2.4

        any mental or other health issues that may make it more challenging for you to work from home, rather than on-site.

    5. 3.3

      Before asking you to return to the workplace, the Company will also take into account:

      1. 3.3.1

        whether you are considered clinically extremely vulnerable (in which case you may be shielding), because you have a specific underlying health condition that makes you extremely vulnerable to severe illness if you contract coronavirus;

      2. 3.3.2

        whether you are considered clinically vulnerable, ie at increased risk from coronavirus, eg because you are aged 70 or over and have an underlying health condition;

      3. 3.3.3

        whether you live with someone who is considered clinically extremely vulnerable;

      4. 3.3.4

        the nature of your commute to work, in particular whether you rely on public transport, or whether it is possible for you to walk or cycle;

      5. 3.3.5

        any protected characteristic that may increase the level of risk, eg age or disability, or other factors such as pregnancy; and

      6. 3.3.6

        childcare or other caring responsibilities.

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—returning to the workplace
Nodes.BodyContent:
UPDATE (7/7/20): On 3 July 2020, the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) expanded its 12 work-place specific guides to ‘Working safely’ during coronavirus COVID-19’ to add guidance on local lockdowns, discouraging shouting, keeping records of staff shift patterns (and, where relevant, customers and visitors) and what to do in the event of a coronavirus outbreak. For further information, see News Analysis: BEIS ‘Working safely during coronavirus’: all 12 work sector guides updated again. This Practice Note has been updated to take account of the updated guidance.
UPDATE (7/7/20): On 23 and 24 June 2020, BEIS expanded its guidance on ‘Working safely’ during coronavirus COVID-19’ to cover four further workplaces ('Close contact services', 'Heritage locations', 'Hotels and other guest accommodation' and 'The visitor economy') and updated the original eight workplace-specific sets of guidance. For further information, see News Analysis: BEIS ‘Working safely during coronavirus’ guidance fully updated plus four new sectors. This Practice Note has been updated to take account of the updated guidance.

On 23 March 2020, the government first published guidance on the closure of certain businesses and venues in England, as part of social distancing measures introduced to minimise or delay the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19). There followed a number of measures designed to provide economic support for individuals and businesses, including the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) and the Self-Employment Income Support Scheme (SEISS)—see Practice Notes:

  1. •

    Coronavirus (COVID-19)—dealing with issues in the workplace—Government initiatives to provide economic support for individuals and businesses

  2. •

    Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020) and Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (revised version from 1 July 2020), and

  3. •

    Self-Employment Income Support Scheme

On 16 April 2020, the Foreign Secretary, Dominic Raab announced the government’s ‘five-point test’ which would need to be satisfied before the coronavirus lockdown measures can be relaxed:

  1. •

    the NHS’s ability to cope protected

  2. •

    a sustained and consistent fall in the daily death rates

  3. •

    rate of infection decreasing to manageable levels

  4. •

    ability to meet demand for testing capacity and personal protective equipment (PPE)

  5. •

    adjustments will not risk a second peak

It was anticipated that the government might start to lift the coronavirus lockdown, with the Prime Minister saying at Prime Minister’s Questions on 6 May 2020 that he hoped to ‘get going on some of these measures’ on Monday 11 May. In his speech on Sunday 10 May 2020, the Prime Minister announced that, to chart progress, there would be a new Covid Alert System, run by a new Joint Biosecurity Centre, with five alert levels; having been in Level Four during lockdown, he announced then that we were ‘now in a position to begin to move in steps to Level Three’. The first such step is a ‘change of emphasis’, from saying ‘you should work from home if you can, and only go to work if you must’ to saying 'work from home if you can, but you should go to work if you can’t work from home’; anyone who cannot work from home, eg in construction or manufacturing, should be ‘actively encouraged to go to work’. The Cabinet Office guidance published the following day, 11 May 2020, clarified that:

  1. •

    for the foreseeable future, workers should continue to work from home rather than their normal physical workplace, wherever possible, but

  2. •

    all workers who cannot work from home should travel to work if their workplace is open

The guidance was updated on 12 June, but this wording remains unchanged.

The government has since relaxed the rules set out in the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350 relating to which businesses and venues must remain closed, and replaced those Regulations with the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (No 2) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/684 (see: Current restrictions on businesses below).

This change of emphasis was taken into account in updates to the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (Acas) advice for employers and employees made on 13 May which, in a section headed ‘If someone does not want to return’ says:

  1. •

    some people might feel they do not want to go to work, or might be unable to return yet, eg because they are:

    1. ◦

      worried about catching coronavirus

    2. ◦

      at high risk of getting a severe illness if they catch coronavirus

    3. ◦

      caring for children, or

    4. ◦

      living with someone who is 'shielding'

  2. •

    an employer should listen to any concerns staff may have and should take steps to protect everyone, eg they could:

    1. ◦

      offer extra car parking where possible so that people can avoid using public transport

    2. ◦

      keep someone on furlough if they are temporarily unable to work

    3. ◦

      arrange for someone to work different hours temporarily to avoid peak time travel

  3. •

    if an employee still does not want to go in, they may be able to arrange with their employer to take the time off as holiday or unpaid leave. The employer does not have to agree to this

  4. •

    if an employee refuses to attend work without a valid reason, it could result in disciplinary action

The equivalent guidance: ‘If an employee does not want to go to work’ previously formed part of the first section of the guidance: ‘Working safely and social distancing’. The current guidance differs from that previous guidance in following respects:

  1. •

    the previous guidance only referred to people who might feel they do not want to go back to work ‘if they're afraid of catching coronavirus. This could particularly be the case for those who are at higher risk.’ It did not refer to those who were caring for children or living for someone who is shielding

  2. •

    in relation to steps the employer might take to protect everyone, the previous guidance did not give the examples of keeping someone on furlough if they are temporarily unable to work, or arranging for someone to work different hours temporarily to avoid peak time travel

For further information, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—guidance tracker for employment—Acas: Coronavirus (COVID-19): advice for employers and employees.

The section of the Acas guidance formerly entitled ‘Good practice’ was also modified to ‘Working safely and social distancing’.

This Practice Note looks at the issues an employer will need to consider where the business or workplace has been closed, and is to be re-opened.

It considers the following guidance published as at 7 July 2020:

  1. •

    the government’s guidance on the closure of certain businesses and venues in England

  2. •

    the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) guidance on working safely during coronavirus (COVID-19), for further information on which, see: BEIS guidance on working safely below

  3. •

    the TUC report Preparing for the return to work outside the home

  4. •

    the Acas guidance on coronavirus and mental health at work published on 19 May 2020, for further information on which, see: Acas mental health guidance

Five key steps

Although the five steps to working safely were only added to the guidance on 19 May, they were set out in the announcement of the guidance on 11 May (see News Analysis: Coronavirus (COVID-19): government publishes eight guidance documents on making workplaces safe (12/5/20)—Key points).

The five steps for employers are:

  1. •

    carry out a coronavirus risk assessment (see: Coronavirus risk assessment below):

    1. ◦

      in line with the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) guidance

    2. ◦

      in consultation with workers or trade unions

    3. ◦

      sharing the results of the risk assessment with its workforce and on its website

  2. •

    develop cleaning, handwashing and hygiene procedures, to increase the frequency of handwashing and surface cleaning:

    1. ◦

      encouraging people to follow the guidance on hand washing and hygiene

    2. ◦

      providing hand sanitiser around the workplace, in addition to washrooms

    3. ◦

      frequently cleaning and disinfecting objects and surfaces that are touched regularly

    4. ◦

      enhancing cleaning for busy areas

    5. ◦

      setting clear use and cleaning guidance for toilets providing hand drying facilities—either paper towels or electrical dryers

  3. •

    take all reasonable steps to help people to work from home by:

    1. ◦

      discussing home working arrangements

    2. ◦

      ensuring they have the right equipment, eg remote access to work systems

    3. ◦

      including them in all necessary communications

    4. ◦

      looking after their physical and mental wellbeing

  4. •

    where possible, maintain two metres social distancing between people by:

    1. ◦

      putting up signs to remind workers and visitors of social distancing guidance

    2. ◦

      avoiding sharing workstations

    3. ◦

      using floor tape or paint to mark areas to help people keep to a two-metre distance

    4. ◦

      arranging one-way traffic through the workplace if possible

    5. ◦

      switching to seeing visitors by appointment only if possible

  5. •

    where people cannot be two metres apart, manage transmission risk by:

    1. ◦

      considering whether an activity needs to continue for the business to operate

    2. ◦

      keeping the activity time involved as short as possible

    3. ◦

      using screens or barriers to separate people from each other

    4. ◦

      using back-to-back or side-to-side working whenever possible

    5. ◦

      staggering arrival and departure times

    6. ◦

      reducing the number of people each person has contact with by using ‘fixed teams or partnering’

This section of the BEIS guidance has not been updated since it was first published on 19 May, and does not reflect the current social distancing guidelines reflected in each of the workplace-specific guides, ie two-metre social distancing, or one metre with risk mitigation where two metres is not viable.

Health and safety considerations

An employer must ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare at work of their employees. Failure to do so is a criminal offence. This core duty extends to the provision of plant and systems of work that are safe and without risks to health, and the provision of such information, instruction, training and supervision as is necessary to ensure the health and safety at work of employees. It is important to remember that this duty extends to both physical and mental health.

An employer must also conduct their business in such a way as to ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, that people not in their employment who may be affected by it are not exposed to risks to their health or safety. Failure to do so is a criminal offence.

'Reasonably practicable' means that the courts will recognise that the duty is qualified. A balance needs to be achieved between the degree of risk in a particular job or workplace against the time, cost and physical difficulty of taking measures to avoid or reduce the risk. At one extreme, if it would take a lot of time, cost or effort to reduce a very small risk, then the measure would not be reasonably practicable. At the other, if the time, cost or effort would be minimal to prevent a high-risk event from happening, then the step would be reasonably practicable. The grey area in between is where most focus should be given, and in practice businesses will need to conduct a risk assessment to identify the hazards which may arise from the activity, the likelihood of the event occurring and identify the steps which could be taken to eliminate or reduce that risk to an acceptable level. The assessment will assist in determining whether a particular step would be reasonably practicable—as well as providing evidence to justify that decision should it subsequently be questioned.

For further information, see: Health and safety—overview and Practice Note: Safety and the risk to safety under the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974.

For information on the Acas guidance on coronavirus and mental health at work, see: Acas mental health guidance below.

An employer’s duties in relation to health and safety are non-delegable; the employer cannot leave it to an employee to decide whether a situation is safe or not, nor is it sufficient for the employer simply to say that they followed government guidance. However, if an employer does not follow government guidance as a minimum, that might constitute evidence of failure by the employer to comply with its health and safety duties.

BEIS guidance

According to the BEIS announcement, the stated purpose of the BEIS guidance on working safely during coronavirus (COVID-19) is to help UK employers get their businesses back up and running and workplaces operating as safely as possible. Separate guidance sets out which non-essential shops and public venues are required to close.

Each set of workplace-specific guidance makes it clear that all employers must carry out a coronavirus health and safety risk assessment, in order to assess and manage the risks of coronavirus. The employer’s risk assessment must address the risks of coronavirus, using the workplace-specific guidance to inform its decisions and control measures.

For further information on a coronavirus risk assessment, see: Risk assessment below.

Employers are, in any event, required to consult with employee representatives and/or employees direct, in relation to certain health and safety matters. Awareness of this long-standing obligation is not necessarily widespread among employers generally. For further information, see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives.

Where workplaces have been closed and workers who have been have consistently urged to ‘stay home’ are now being asked to ‘stay alert’ and return to work if their workplace is open, such workers may be reluctant to return unless they are confident that health and safety matters have been prioritised.

TUC report

The TUC report: Preparing for the return to work outside the home set out a number of steps that it considers the government and employers must now take to ensure a safe transition from lockdown, including:

  1. •

    every employer must carry out a specific coronavirus risk assessment (see: Risk assessment below).

  2. •

    PPE must be provided where necessary, and no-one should be asked to re-use PPE inappropriately

  3. •

    the government must provide specific advice and protection for those groups most at risk. This includes workers advised to ‘shield’ and those who are pregnant. If these workers cannot work safely, their livelihoods must be protected. Black and ethnic minority workers have suffered disproportionate harm from the impact of the virus. The EHRC must ensure that the return to work strategy seeks to prevent this disproportionate impact and complies with the public sector equality duty

  4. •

    unions should be consulted when the government prepares sector-specific guidance, and when employers seek to implement it (according to the TUC blog: The government’s back to work plans still won’t make workplaces safe—here’s why, BEIS did consult unions on the first draft of its return to work guidance; the first draft was poor, and the unions demanded immediate and substantial changes; although the published guidelines ‘aren’t everything unions wanted, they are a step in the right direction’)

  5. •

    the HSE must run a public information campaign to ensure workers know their rights. To support this, the HSE and local authority regulators who inspect workplaces need additional resources and inspectors to act swiftly on reports of unsafe working practices

  6. •

    no worker should face a sanction for refusing to work in an unsafe workplace. Employees have the right to withdraw from and to refuse to return to an unsafe workplace, and legal protection from dismissal, disciplinary or any other detriment for raising a health and safety issue (see Practice Note: Health and safety—employee protection from detriment and dismissal). Employers must be reminded of this and workers must have this right guaranteed

  7. •

    the HSE must act quickly to apply sanctions to employers that do not risk assess for coronavirus, or that fail to provide safe working arrangements. Coronavirus is spread by people displaying no symptoms, and so it is not appropriate to wait for workers to be infected before action is taken. The HSE needs to take action, including prosecutions, against employers who do not take safety seriously

PHE guidance

The PHE guidance on the most common symptoms of coronavirus was updated on 18 May 2020 to include a loss of, or change in, a person’s normal sense of taste or smell (anosmia), as well as a new continuous cough or a high temperature.

Whistleblowing considerations

Where a worker raises a specific health and safety concern, this is likely to amount to a protected disclosure, which will give them additional protection from whistleblowing detriment and dismissal. See Practice Notes: Whistleblowing—protected disclosures and Types of whistleblowing claim.

Toolkit produced by Society of Occupational Medicine and partners

As mentioned above, SOM, Acas, CIPD, Business in the Community, and Mind launched a toolkit on 18 May 2020, to assist employers in creating a safe workplace for employees to return to during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.

The SOM toolkit makes the following key points:

  1. •

    no industry or sector has been unaffected by the coronavirus outbreak. Many people have had to make significant changes to their daily lives, at relatively short notice, including how they work—whether that is hours, location, or even being able to do their job at all. Nobody knows how long this situation will last, but it is clear that the impact will be felt for years to come

  2. •

    employers cannot force their employees to return to work if it is unsafe. There is a duty on employers, HR, occupational (OH) professionals, and employees to understand how to make the workplace safe, their role in that process, and the need to be involved and work together in making those decisions. Decisions about return to work should occur in a non-discriminatory way

  3. •

    a risk assessment should link clinical vulnerability risk to specific workplace risks. Employers also need to be aware of the risks of increased workplace tensions and disputes, arising from changes to workplace practices and working arrangements, and from fear of infection on return to work

  4. •

    occupational health and other professionals can assist managers with risk assessments, eg with advice on cleaning, disinfection, ergonomic and hygiene or ventilation systems and how ‘stringent social distancing’ can be applied in the workplace

  5. •

    the role of the manager and ‘doing things in a compassionate way’ is critical. Consulting with employees in this unprecedented situation is also highly important, and legally required where there are recognised trade unions. Employees having an active and valued voice in this situation will be absolutely critical to businesses adapting successfully. The relationship between employer and employee needs to be strengthened to inform decisions that will facilitate practical solutions and support the effective work of the organisation
