Acas mental health guidance

Acas published guidance on coronavirus and mental health at work on 19 May 2020, to help employers support the mental health of their staff during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The guidance comprises:

  1. •

    guidance for staff on looking after their mental health

  2. •

    guidance for employers on supporting and managing their staff’s mental health, and

  3. •

    links to mental health resources

The supporting staff’s mental health guidance makes the following points:

  1. •

    staff may need additional mental health support during the coronavirus pandemic, particularly if they already have mental health problems

  2. •

    in some cases staff may need support such as time off or reasonable adjustments

  3. •

    an employer will need to be understanding towards the concerns and needs of its staff while they work in new or unexpected ways, eg working from home or managing childcare while working

  4. •

    an employer should also be understanding if staff need to take time off to look after someone else

  5. •

    when talking about any difficult changes in the workplace, eg putting staff on furlough, the employer should deal with matters sensitively. Staff may be feeling anxious or stressed so it is important to communicate in a clear and calm way

The supporting your staff’s mental health guidance also covers:

  1. •

    how a manager should support their team, including:

    1. ◦

      being approachable, available and encourage team members to talk to them if they’re having problems

    2. ◦

      adapting their management style to suit the needs of each person

    3. ◦

      keeping in regular contact with their team to check how they are coping

    4. ◦

      using 'wellness action plans' to put steps in place to support the team’s mental health, and

    5. ◦

      making sure the team has realistic targets and clear priorities, so they feel supported and motivated at work

  2. •

    supporting furloughed staff by asking them if they would like to keep in touch while they are on furlough, and agreeing how often they will catch up depending on the employee’s needs

  3. •

    how to spot possible signs of a mental health problem

  4. •

    how to talk to someone experiencing a mental health problem, and

  5. •

    getting support for themselves

The Acas managing staff’s mental health guidance highlights that, during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, an employer should do all it reasonably can to encourage positive mental health, eg by:

  1. •

    arranging mental health training for managers and staff

  2. •

    appointing mental health ‘champions’ who staff can talk to

  3. •

    promoting existing wellbeing support, such as counselling, and

  4. •

    reminding managers to communicate regularly with their team and support them if they need to have sensitive conversations with team members

The managing staff’s mental health guidance also sets out that employers should:

  1. •

    communicate regularly and openly with staff, so they can adapt quickly

  2. •

    reassure staff, and acknowledge their concerns, by:

    1. ◦

      communicating openly and sharing information in a highly visible location, eg on the intranet or by emailing all staff

    2. ◦

      ‘consulting’ with staff (by asking for and considering their views) so they can give feedback and share concerns

    3. ◦

      providing timely information so staff are regularly updated

  3. •

    brief managers so they can share information with their teams; if staff have concerns about mental health and wellbeing, they may be more likely to talk to their manager

  4. •

    communicate information and decisions in a clear and straightforward way, with empathy

  5. •

    know what resources and support it can offer and signpost them clearly, eg an Employee Assistance Programme (EAP) offering staff counselling or ‘drop-in’ sessions with someone from HR or a third party to talk through any issues

  6. •

    assess mental health in the workplace by talking to managers to understand how their teams are doing, which resources are helpful and if they need any more support

  7. •

    if there is an ‘online channel’ where staff can share updates, look through it to understand staff’s concerns and areas where they need more support

  8. •

    use wellbeing surveys to understand how staff are feeling at work

  9. •

    seek help from trade unions and other employee representatives to promote positive mental health

Coronavirus risk assessment

For general information on carrying out a risk assessment, see Practice Notes: Conducting a health and safety risk assessment and Formulating a health and safety plan. See also Precedent: Health and safety risk assessment, which is aimed at an office-based working environment.

As mentioned above, the government guidance states that employers must carry out a COVID-19 risk assessment:

  1. •

    in line with HSE guidance

  2. •

    in consultation with workers or trade unions, and

  3. •

    sharing the results of the risk assessment with its workforce and on its website

Each of the eight workplace-specific guides states:

‘Employers have a duty to consult their people on health and safety. You can do this by listening and talking to them about the work and how you will manage risks from COVID-19. The people who do the work are often the best people to understand the risks in the workplace and will have a view on how to work safely. Involving them in making decisions shows that you take their health and safety seriously. You must consult with the health and safety representative selected by a recognised trade union or, if there isn’t one, a representative chosen by workers. As an employer, you cannot decide who the representative will be.’

This is not strictly entirely correct, since:

  1. •

    if the employer recognises an independent trade union for collective bargaining purposes, the employer must consult the union-appointed safety representatives under the Safety Representatives and Safety Committees Regulations 1977 (1977 Regulations), SI 1977/500

  2. •

    if there is no recognised trade union or no trade union safety representatives have been appointed and/or there are employees who are not represented by safety representatives under the 1977 Regulations, SI 1977/500, the employer must consult the workforce either directly or through elected health and safety representatives (known as 'representatives of workplace safety'), under the Health and Safety (Consultation with Employees) Regulations 1996, SI 1996/1513

For further information, see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives.

The workplace-specific guides also state that the employer must share the results of its risk assessment with the workforce and, if possible, consider publishing the results on its website. Before 24 June (23 June in the case of the Restaurants, pubs, bars and takeaway services guidance) the guidance was that employers should do so—see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—guidance tracker for employment—BEIS guidance: Working safely during coronavirus (COVID-19). They go on to say that the government ‘would expect all businesses with over 50 workers to do so’. However, there is currently no legal obligation on employers to publish their risk assessments on their website.

The workplace-specific guides also state (since 15 June 2020) that the government would expect all businesses to demonstrate to their workers and customers that they have properly assessed their risk and taken appropriate measures to mitigate this, by displaying a notification in a prominent place in their business and on their website, if they have one.

This does not go as far as the demands set out in the TUC report, which sought that, before easing lockdown restrictions, the government would require all employers with more than five staff to carry out a specific COVID-19 risk assessment, and require them to publish that risk assessment.

In the absence of any penalty or other negative effect, some employers may decide not to meet the government’s ‘expectation’ in this regard, unless they take the view that doing so would enhance the reputation of the business, or raise confidence of employees, customers or clients visiting its premises. However, increased employee awareness of the government’s expectations may lead to workforce pressure for publication.

The guidance also prominently encourages workers to report suspected breaches of the guidance to the Health & Safety Executive (HSE).

The TUC report also set out that:

  1. •

    employers should work with unions and workers to assess the risks in the workplace, and set out specific steps, including enforcing social distancing, for how these can be mitigated and how workers can work safely

  2. •

    risk assessment should factor in the likelihood of continuing absences across any business, and the availability of any safety-critical staff; while the rate of absence remains high because of sickness, self-isolation or other factors, output may need to be adjusted to safeguard employees’ mental and physical health

  3. •

    the COVID-19 risk assessment should be approved by an accredited union health and safety representative or, where there is no such representative able to sign off a risk assessment, by an HSE inspector

  4. •

    once agreed, risk assessments and action plans must be sent or otherwise effectively communicated to the whole workforce before they are expected to return to work

  5. •

    if the risk assessment shows that PPE is necessary, employers must provide it; where the necessary PPE cannot be supplied, work should not recommence. No-one, including PHE, should require health and social care workers to re-use PPE; PHE and the HSE should also rescind their guidance allowing for the reuse of certain items of PPE in exceptional circumstances of scarcity

According to TUC blog: The government’s back to work plans still won’t make workplaces safe—here’s why, there are still big questions about how public transport can be managed safely for passengers and transport workers alike and that, without childcare, going back to workplaces will be impossible for many.

Other considerations affecting the decision to re-open

Now that most businesses and venues are able to re-open, the likelihood is that business will not immediately return to normal levels of customer or client demand, eg in the case of restaurants, pubs and bars:

  1. •

    workplaces are advised to make every reasonable effort to comply with the social distancing guidelines (ie two metres, or one metre with risk mitigation where two meters is not viable), which will almost certainly limit the number of customers that can be accommodated

  2. •

    having been warned of the serious implications of contracting the coronavirus and the need to ‘stay home’, it may take the public time to want to socialise, particularly if they think the venue will be too crowded

  3. •

    returning customers may be unwilling to meet the requirements identified in the relevant guidance or in the business’s own risk assessment, eg providing personal information so that the business can keep a record of its customers to assist NHS Test and Trace, or booking a table or queuing simply to have a drink at a pub

  4. •

    the economic impact of the coronavirus lockdown has, for many, been severe, and many households will not be able to afford to spend on ‘leisure’

Given the high level of staff and other costs involved in running a restaurant or pub, businesses in this sector usually need a certain amount of customer turnover in order to make a profit; additional staff costs may be incurred if they need to employ dedicated staff to encourage social distancing or manage security, as the Restaurants, pubs, bars and takeaway services guidance suggests. If reduced capacity or turnover means the business will not break even, they may choose to open for fewer days or hours than usual, or remain closed altogether until restrictions are eased further. In any event, employers may need fewer staff and/or staff working reduced hours.

Nodes.Title: Health and safety—employee protection from detriment and dismissal
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note considers the right of employees not to be subjected to a detriment, or dismissed, on certain grounds relating to health and safety in the workplace.

An employee, regardless of length of service, has the right:

  1. •

    not to be subjected to a detriment (eg denied promotion), and

  2. •

    not to be dismissed

on various grounds relating to health and safety.

For further information on health and safety representatives generally, see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives.

Key principles

The key points to note in relation to detriment and/or dismissal on health and safety grounds are:

  1. •

    the rights apply only to employees: those with worker status are not covered (see Who is protected, below)

  2. •

    there is no minimum qualifying period of continuous employment (see Qualifying period) below

  3. •

    the employee is not barred from bringing an unfair dismissal complaint if they were involved in industrial action at the relevant time (see Dismissal when taking part in industrial action, below)

  4. •

    dismissal on one of the specified health and safety grounds is automatically unfair (see Remedies—unfair dismissal, below)

  5. •

    selection for redundancy on one of the specified health and safety grounds is automatically unfair (see Selection for redundancy, below)

  6. •

    where the employee is a health and safety official, interim relief is available in an unfair dismissal claim, as an order for the continuation of the contract of employment (see Unfair dismissal—interim relief, below)

  7. •

    where the employee is a health and safety official, the basic award is subject to a statutory minimum limit (see Remedies—unfair dismissal, below)

  8. •

    there is no maximum limit on the amount of compensation that may be awarded in health and safety cases (see Remedies—unfair dismissal, below)

  9. •

    an individual making such a disclosure may enjoy whistleblowing protection as well as, or instead of, the protection against health and safety detriment and dismissal (see Whistleblowing, below)

Who is protected

Protection against detriment on the specified health and safety grounds extends only to those with the status of employee. Those with worker status are not protected.

As with unfair dismissal rights generally, the right not to be dismissed on the specified health and safety grounds is available only to employees.

For further information, see Practice Notes: Employee status and Entitlement to claim unfair dismissal.

Note, however, that in the particular context, where the individual has made a disclosure of information tending to show that the health and safety of any individual has been, is being, or is likely to be endangered, that will be a qualifying disclosure. If the individual makes this disclosure in the prescribed manner, it will be protected and the individual will enjoy protection as a whistleblower.

Whistleblowing protection applies to those within a wider definition of ‘worker’ and so an individual may be covered by the protection offered to whistleblowers, even if they are not protected by the health and safety detriment and dismissal provisions discussed in this Practice Note. For further information, see Whistleblowing, below.

The Independent Workers Union of Great Britain (IWGB) has brought (in May 2020) judicial review proceedings against the government in an effort to extend health and safety rights to ‘gig economy’ workers. According to the IWGB, workers in the gig economy are being denied adequate health and safety protections, including personal protective equipment (PPE), despite this being mandated by European law. The union also contends that the right to refuse to work in situations of imminent danger without fear of detriment or dismissal (see Leaving work in the face of serious and imminent danger and Taking protective steps to avert serious and imminent danger, below) should be extended to gig economy workers.

Qualifying period

No qualifying period of continuous employment is required for the right not to be subjected to a detriment on health and safety grounds.

Similarly, no qualifying period of continuous employment is required for the right not to be dismissed on health and safety grounds.

The specified health and safety grounds

The specified health and safety grounds are set out in section 100 of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (ERA 1996). They are considered in more detail in the sections of this Practice Note that follow (linked below):

  1. •

    Health and safety officials

  2. •

    Participating in consultations

  3. •

    Raising health and safety concerns

  4. •

    Leaving work in the face of serious and imminent danger

  5. •

    Taking protective steps to avert serious and imminent danger

Health and safety officials

It is unlawful to subject a health and safety official to a detriment, and a dismissal will be automatically unfair, where the reason (or, if more than one, the principal reason) for the detrimental treatment and/or dismissal is that:

  1. •

    having been designated by the employer to carry out activities in connection with preventing or reducing risks to health and safety at work, the employee carried out (or proposed to carry out) any such activities, or

  2. •

    being a ‘representative of workers on matters of health and safety at work’, the employee performed (or proposed to perform) any functions as such a representative or a member of such a committee

A 'representative of workers on matters of health and safety' would include any of the following:

  1. •

    a union-appointed safety representative under the Safety Representatives and Safety Committees Regulations 1977 (1977 Regulations)

  2. •

    representatives of workplace safety (also known as workplace-elected safety representatives) under the Health and Safety (Consultation with Employees) Regulations 1996 (1996 Regulations)

  3. •

    a member of a safety committee

For details of these representatives and their (wide-ranging) functions in relation to health and safety, see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives—Functions of health and safety representatives.

Participating in consultations

The 1996 Regulations enable the employer to choose to consult directly with its employees as individuals on health and safety matters if it wishes to do so, or to ask its employees to elect representatives for that purpose. For further information, see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives—Which Regulations apply under the heading ‘Workforce-elected safety representatives’.

In order to protect employees where they are consulted directly, it is unlawful to subject an ordinary employee (ie one who is not a safety representative) to a detriment, and a dismissal will be automatically unfair, where the reason (or, if more than one, the principal reason) for the detrimental treatment and/or dismissal is that they were participating or seeking to participate in:

  1. •

    consultations under the 1996 Regulations (see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives—Consultation)

  2. •

    the election of a workplace-elected safety representative under the 1996 Regulations, whether as a candidate or otherwise

There is no corresponding protection for ordinary employees where the 1977 Regulations apply to the employer in relation to them, as the employer is then obliged to consult with union-appointed safety representatives rather than with the employees direct. For further information, see Practice Note: Health and safety—employer consultation and employee representatives—Which Regulations apply under the heading ‘Union-appointed safety representatives’.

Raising health and safety concerns

It is unlawful to subject any employee (ie the employee does not need to be a safety representative in order to be protected) to a detriment, and any dismissal will be automatically unfair, if the reason (or, if more than one, the principal reason) for the detrimental treatment and/or dismissal is that they brought to their employer’s attention, by reasonable means, circumstances connected with their work which they reasonably believed were harmful or potentially harmful to health or safety where:

  1. •

    there are no official channels (ie no safety representative(s) or safety committee) or

  2. •

    where it was not reasonably practicable to raise the matter using the official channels

These provisions were considered by the EAT in Acheson. The case concerned a number of electricians on a large construction site. Working conditions at the site were far from satisfactory. It was very wet and there were insufficient facilities for the workers to dry out their work clothes. There was very heavy rain which produced wide areas of standing water on the marshy ground around the site. It was also very cold. During the lunch break, the workers expressed widespread and spontaneous concerns about the adverse effects of the weather on working conditions and they resolved to approach management to let them take the afternoon off in order to dry out. It was decided that C, the AEEU shop steward, and T, a spokesperson for the TGWU members, should approach management with their concerns. They did so but with no success. The project manager dismissed the requests out of hand, believing that the men were simply attempting to get money without work. The men then decided to leave the site. The men did not work on the following day (Wednesday), nor again on Thursday, although they attended the site in the morning. When they clocked in to work on Friday, they found that conditions, though improved, were still not satisfactory and they refused to go back to work. The employers had already decided that if the men failed to return to work on Friday, they would all be dismissed. Consequently, as they left the site at 1pm, they were all given letters of dismissal. They brought tribunal proceedings alleging automatically unfair dismissal, and general unfair dismissal, which the tribunal upheld.

The EAT allowed the employer’s appeal against the finding of automatically unfair dismissal. In order for this statutory provision to come into play:

  1. •

    it is necessary to show that it was not reasonably practicable for the employee to raise the health and safety matters through the safety representative or safety committee

  2. •

    the employee must have brought to the employer's attention by reasonable means the circumstances that they reasonably believe are harmful or potentially harmful to health or safety, and

  3. •

    the reason for dismissal, or at least the principal reason if there is more than one, must be the fact that the employee was exercising its right

In considering the first requirement, the EAT held that, although on its face the statute requires an employment tribunal to ask whether it was reasonably practicable to use a safety representative rather than asking whether it was reasonable for the employee to use some other means of communicating with the employer, it would be highly artificial if, when drawing matters of serious and imminent concern to the employer, the employees must concern themselves with the appropriate route by which that information is conveyed. The important thing is that the message is communicated quickly and succinctly. This is supported by the fact that Directive 89/391/EEC, the Framework Directive on Health and Safety (Framework Directive) provides in terms that workers must ‘immediately inform the employer’ of serious and immediate dangers to health and safety. It is clear that an employee exercising their obligations under Article 13 of the Directive cannot conceivably be lawfully dismissed under English law on that account.

The employment tribunal was therefore entitled to find that it was reasonable for the employees to raise their concerns through their union representatives, even though it would have been practicable to use the safety representatives as the channel of communication.

However, taking industrial action is not ‘reasonable means’ of bringing health and safety concerns to the employer’s attention. Nor can it amount to ‘informing’ the employer within the meaning of the Framework Directive. Although in exceptional circumstances, communication can be by action rather than words, the concept of informing the employer cannot extend to taking industrial action to impress upon the employer the gravity of the issue as perceived by the employees.

The employment tribunal had erred, therefore, in holding that the applicants had used reasonable means to draw their concerns about health and safety matters to the employers' attention by going out on strike and refusing to return to work. Accordingly, the applicants were not protected under the automatically unfair dismissal provisions.

Leaving work in the face of serious and imminent danger

It is unlawful to subject any employee (ie the employee does not need to be a safety representative in order to be protected) to a detriment, and any dismissal will be automatically unfair, if the reason (or, if more than one, the principal reason) for the detrimental treatment and/or dismissal is that, in circumstances of danger which the employee reasonably believed to be serious and imminent and which they could not reasonably have been expected to avert, the employee:

  1. •

    left or proposed to leave, or

  2. •

    (while the danger persisted) refused to return to

their place of work or any dangerous part of their place of work.

‘Dangers’ in this context are not limited to dangers arising out of the workplace itself, but also cover dangers caused by the behaviour of fellow employees.

In McCaffrey, the employee (M) left his workplace, where he was working a nightshift with one other employee (H), when H became very abusive. M had attempted to report this to his manager from the work office but had not felt safe to do so, as H stood over him very closely and shouted abuse at him. M immediately went home and telephoned his manager from there. M also subsequently spoke to a more senior person in the company. M said that he would only return to work if he had assurances about his safety, which in effect meant H being removed or dismissed. However, without speaking to M further, the employer decided to accept H’s account of the incident. M was told by phone that he had resigned by walking out in the middle of the shift and that he would be sent his P45. The EAT upheld the employment tribunal’s finding that M’s dismissal was automatically unfair.

Automatically unfair dismissal for leaving work in face in the face of serious and imminent danger was also claimed by the employees in Acheson, the facts of which are considered above (see Raising health and safety concerns, above).

The employment tribunal found that the conduct did not fall within the statutory terms. It concluded that there was indeed serious and imminent danger on the Tuesday, or at least that was what the employees reasonably believed, but that by the Friday the weather had improved to such an extent that the circumstances of danger no longer existed. There was no appeal against that finding and so it was not considered by the EAT.

The EAT noted, however, that the employees in that case could lawfully have taken industrial action without a ballot where they were, together, exercising their rights to leave work in face in the face of serious and imminent danger. It would also have been reasonable in all the circumstances for the employees to have impressed their views upon the employer in the way in which they did.

See also the discussion of Edwards, under the heading ‘Travelling to work’, below.

Taking protective steps to avert serious and imminent danger

It is unlawful to subject any employee (ie the employee does not need to be a safety representative in order to be protected) to a detriment, and any dismissal will be automatically unfair, if the reason (or, if more than one, the principal reason) for the dismissal and/or the detrimental treatment is that, in circumstances of danger which the employee reasonably believed to be serious and imminent, the employee took (or proposed to take) appropriate steps to protect themselves or other persons from the danger.

Whether steps which an employee took (or proposed to take) were appropriate is to be judged by reference to all the circumstances including, in particular, the employee’s knowledge and the facilities and advice available to them at the time.

However, if the employer shows that it was (or would have been) so negligent for the employee to take the steps which they took (or proposed to take) that a reasonable employer might have dismissed them for taking (or proposing to take) those steps, the dismissal will not be automatically unfair, but may still be unfair on normal principles.

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (revised version from 1 July 2020)
Nodes.BodyContent:
UPDATE (15/7/20): HMRC has updated eight guidance documents on 10 July relating to the revised Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS). For information, see News Analysis: BEIS ‘Working safely during coronavirus’: two new workplace guides and three guides updated. This Practice Note has been updated to take account of the revised HMRC guidance.
UPDATE (15/7/20): HMRC has updated nine guidance documents and one policy paper on 1 July relating to the revised Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) that will operate from 1 July 2020 until 31 October 2020. For information, see News Analysis: Further updates to HMRC guidance on the revised 1 July Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme. This Practice Note has been updated to take account of the revised HMRC guidance.
UPDATE (3/7/20): The Chancellor made a third Treasury Direction relating to the original and revised versions of the CJRS on 25 June (published on 26 June). The HMRC guidance on claiming for wages through the CJRS was updated on 26 June to explain how an organisation should contact HMRC to let it know if the organisation has overclaimed through the CJRS and how to make a payment where it does not plan to make any further claims. For information on the third Treasury Direction, see News Analyses: Treasury makes third Direction in relation to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) and Analysis of the third Treasury Direction relating to the original and revised Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS). This Practice Note has been updated to take account of the third Treasury Direction and the updated guidance.

This Practice Note considers the ‘flexible furloughing’, revised version of the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) that applies from 1 July 2020.

The original version of the CJRS was first announced by the government on 20 March 2020, to be in place for three months starting from 1 March 2020, but HM Treasury announced, on 17 April, that this was extended to 30 June, and then announced, on 12 May, that it was extended until 31 October 2020.

Changes to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS), with HMRC contributions to furloughed employee wages tapering progressively from 1 August until the scheme closes on 31 October, and flexible furloughing being possible from 1 July, were announced by the Chancellor of the Exchequer on 29 May 2020 and accompanied by a factsheet. See News Analysis: Chancellor details changes to Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) and Self-Employment Income Support Scheme (SEISS).

Further detail was provided regarding the revised CJRS that operates from 1 July 2020 on the evening of 12 June 2020 when HMRC published three new guidance documents and updated six existing ones. For full details of those publications and changes, see News Analyses: Revised 1 July Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme: HMRC publishes further and updated guidance and COVID-19: CJRS flexible furloughing.

The Treasury exercised its powers to make Treasury Direction No 3 on 25 June (published on 26 June). This Treasury Direction:

  1. •

    sets out certain transitional provisions relating to the original CJRS (see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020)—Which Treasury Direction applies to a claim, under the heading ‘ and

  2. •

    provides the legal underpinning for the revised version of the CJRS that operates from 1 July 2020, under which flexible furloughing is possible and the amount claimable under the scheme from the government will gradually taper on a monthly basis until the scheme closes altogether at the end of October 2020

For further information, see News Analyses: Treasury makes third Direction in relation to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) and Analysis of the third Treasury Direction relating to the original and revised Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS).

Job Retention Bonus

On 8 July, the Chancellor set out his Plan for Jobs 2020, including a ‘Job Retention Bonus’ of a one-off payment to UK employers of £1,000 for every furloughed employee who remains continuously employed through to the end of January 2021. Employees must earn above the lower earnings limit of £520 per month on average between the end of the CJRS (on 31 October 2020) and the end of January 2021, and payments will be made from February 2021.

Further detail about the scheme will be announced by the end of July.

A number of employers, including Primark, have already said they will not take advantage of the Job Retention Bonus.

It remains to be seen whether this level of bonus will be effective in persuading employers to retain staff they would otherwise have made redundant, given the cost of continuing to employ staff between August 2020 (when employers can no longer claim employer National Insurance contributions (NICs) or pension contributions as part of the CJRS grant) and January 2021.

Guidance on the revised CJRS

New and updated guidance on the revised version of the CJRS was published on 12 June 2020. This consisted of:

  1. •

    three new documents:

    1. ◦

      HMRC policy paper: Changes to the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

    2. ◦

      HMRC guidance: Steps to take before calculating your claim using the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

    3. ◦

      HMRC guidance: Calculate how much you can claim using the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

  2. •

    updates to the following six existing documents:

    1. ◦

      Guidance for employers: Check if you can claim for your employees’ wages through the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

    2. ◦

      Guidance for employees: Check if your employer can use the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

    3. ◦

      Check which employees you can put on furlough to use the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

    4. ◦

      Claim for wages through the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

    5. ◦

      Examples of how to calculate your employees' wages, National Insurance contributions and pension contributions

    6. ◦

      Reporting payments in PAYE Real Time Information from the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

On 10 July, guidance on individuals employers can claim for who are not employees was moved from the Check which employees you can put on furlough guidance into separate guidance: HMRC: Individuals you can claim for who are not employees.

For further information, see News Analysis: Revised 1 July Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme: HMRC publishes further and updated guidance.

Key points to note

Key points to note regarding the revised CJRS are:

  1. •

    the amendments to the stated purpose of the CJRS as set out in Treasury Direction No 3 (see: Pay during notice period below)

  2. •

    it closes to ‘new entrants’ on 30 June 2020: the new CJRS is only available in respect of employees who have been furloughed by that date for at least one three-week period under the original CJRS, with certain exceptions (see Which employees the employer can put on furlough and claim for, below)

  3. •

    if an employer wished to retain the ability to claim for an employee who has not yet been furloughed under the original CJRS, that employee must have been placed on furlough by no later than 10 June 2020, in order for them to have completed the minimum three-week furlough period by 30 June 2020

  4. •

    the number of employees an employer can claim for in any claim period under the revised CJRS cannot exceed the maximum number they have claimed for under any previous claim under the original CJRS, with certain exceptions (see Which employees the employer can put on furlough and claim for, below)

  5. •

    employers have until 31 July 2020 to make any claims in respect of the period to 30 June 2020 (see Making a claim, below)

  6. •

    the CJRS will end on 31 October 2020; however, it is expected that ‘run-off’ claims, in respect of the period to 31 October 2020, will be possible for a period (not yet specified) after 31 October

  7. •

    from 1 August 2020, the amount of the CJRS grant reduces on a tapering basis, with employers required to contribute towards furlough costs, in order to ensure that furloughed employees continue to receive 80% of their normal wages or salary, subject to a cap of £2,500 per month, while they are on furlough (see What the employer can claim and what they are liable for, below)

  8. •

    ‘flexible furlough’ is possible from 1 July 2020: employees are able to return to work on a part-time work/part-time furlough basis; this contrasts with the position under the original CJRS (see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020)—When employees are on furlough), where an employee is required to have ceased all work (ie been fully-furloughed) for the employer during the relevant claim period in order for the employer to be able to claim under the CJRS in respect of that employee (see When employees are on furlough, below)

Key dates

Key dates to note (in 2020) are:

  1. •

    10 June: last date by which an employee must have been furloughed under the original CJRS in order for a claim to be possible in relation to them under the revised CJRS

  2. •

    16 June: date by which minimum collective consultation period (45 days) where 100 or more employees proposed to be dismissed must have begun in respect of changes taking effect on 1 August

  3. •

    30 June: no employees who have not previously been furloughed may be claimed for; Treasury Direction No 2 expires (subject to the transitional provisions in Treasury Direction No 3)

  4. •

    1 July: flexible furloughing permitted from this date; CJRS claims under revised CJRS can be made; claims must be for minimum period of one week (unless claiming for first or last days in a calendar month); claim periods cannot span calendar months; date by which minimum collective consultation period (30 days) where 20 to 99 employees proposed to be dismissed must have begun in respect of changes taking effect on 1 August

  5. •

    31 July: last date for claims under original CJRS to be submitted

  6. •

    1 August: employers unable to claim for employer NICs and employer auto-enrolment pension contributions in respect of furloughed employees from this date

  7. •

    1 September: employers required to contribute 10% of the pay of furloughed employees, plus employer NICs and employer auto-enrolment pension contributions from this date

  8. •

    15 September: date by which minimum collective consultation period (45 days) where 100 or more employees proposed to be dismissed must have begun in respect of changes taking effect on 31 October

  9. •

    1 October: employers required to contribute 20% of the pay of furloughed employees, plus employer NICs and employer auto-enrolment pension contributions from this date; date by which minimum collective consultation period (30 days) where 20 to 99 employees proposed to be dismissed must have begun in respect of changes taking effect on 31 October

  10. •

    31 October: CJRS ends

  11. •

    31 January 2021: employees must have been continuously employed from 31 October 2020 to this date in order for an employer to claim the job retention bonus in respect of them

  12. •

    February 2021: job retention bonus payments can be claimed by employers in relation to qualifying employees

CJRS—original version

For further guidance on the version of the CJRS that has been running since March 2020, which is referred to in this Practice Note as the ‘original CJRS’, see Practice Notes: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020) and Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020)—FAQs.

Pay during notice period

One issue that was, until 10 July, uncertain is how the CJRS grant can be used where an employee’s employment is terminated by reason of redundancy or some other reason while they are on furlough. It has been relatively clear that:

  1. •

    an employer may make an employee redundant while they are on furlough (the employee guidance confirms this), but

  2. •

    the CJRS grant cannot be used to fund the employee’s statutory redundancy payment (the employer guidance confirms this)

What was not previously clear was whether the CJRS grant can be used to pay the employee’s wages during their notice period, as the HMRC guidance was silent on this point. We set out below the guidance from 10 July and the position as it may have been considered before 10 July, given the available guidance and the wording of the Treasury Directions.

The guidance from 10 July

From 10 July, the employer guidance states:

‘You can continue to claim for a furloughed employee who is serving a statutory notice period…’

From 17 July, that wording is amended in the check which employees you can put on furlough guidance to:

‘You can continue to claim for a furloughed employee who is serving a statutory or contractual notice period…’

Similar wording appears in the employee guidance.

It is therefore finally clear that, if an employee’s employment is terminated, whether by the employer or the employee, the employer can use the CJRS grant to pay the employee’s wages during their statutory or (longer) contractual notice period. This clarification is extremely welcome.

The guidance (and Treasury Directions) until 10 July

Prior to 10 July, it was thought that the HMRC guidance’s silence on this issue might mean that the CJRS grant could be used to pay notice pay, but that there was a risk that this would not be regarded as within the ‘spirit’ of the CJRS. See, for example, Q&As:

  1. •

    Can an employee who is currently on furlough under the coronavirus (COVID-19) job retention scheme be given notice of termination of employment? If so, can the employer claim a grant in respect of the employee’s notice pay? (7/4/20)

  2. •

    If an employee is made redundant while on furlough, can an employer continue to claim 80% of his salary during the notice period? (23/4/2020)

Treasury Direction No 2 read:

‘2.1 The purpose of CJRS is to provide for payments to be made to employers on a claim made in respect of them incurring costs of employment in respect of furloughed employees arising from the health, social and economic emergency in the United Kingdom resulting from coronavirus and coronavirus disease.

2.2 Integral to the purpose of CJRS is that the amounts paid to an employer pursuant to a claim under CJRS are only made by way of reimbursement of the expenditure described in paragraph 8.1 incurred or to be incurred by the employer in respect of the employee to which the claim relates.’

This did not assist (either way) on the question of whether the CJRS grant could be used to pay an employee’s notice pay, as paragraph 8.1 of the schedule to the Treasury Direction No 2 to which paragraph 2.2 refers covers (among other things) reimbursement of ‘the gross amount of earnings paid or reasonably expected to be paid by the employer to an employee’, which would include notice pay.

However, Treasury Direction No 3 made potentially significant changes to the stated purpose of both the original and revised CJRS. It reads:

‘2.1 The purpose of CJRS is to provide for payments to be made to employers on a claim made in respect of them incurring costs of employment in respect of employees who are within the scope of CJRS arising from the health, social and economic emergency in the United Kingdom resulting from coronavirus and coronavirus disease.

2.2 Integral to the purpose of CJRS is that the amounts paid to an employer pursuant to a CJRS claim are used by the employer to continue the employment of employees in respect of whom the CJRS claim is made whose employment activities have been adversely affected by the coronavirus and coronavirus disease or the measures taken to prevent or limit its further transmission.’ [our emphasis]

This wording might appear to have potentially a very different effect from the wording in the Treasury Direction No 2 set out above; if an employer gives a furloughed employee notice of termination of employment, can it be said that the employer is using the CJRS grant to ‘continue the employment of employees’ if the employer uses that grant to fund that employee’s pay during their notice period, which will bring their employment to an end, rather than continue it? In the absence of further guidance from HMRC, we were inclined to suggest that it could not.

Which employers are eligible

The revised CJRS from 1 July 2020 is only available to employers that have previously used the original CJRS, in respect of employees they have previously furloughed under the original CJRS.

More particularly, a claim under the revised CJRS may only be made:

  1. •

    by a qualifying employer, ie one who (as was the case under the original CJRS):

    1. ◦

      has a qualifying PAYE scheme, ie one that is registered on the RTI system, and was so registered on or before 20 March 2020, and

    2. ◦

      has made a qualifying CJRS claim on or before 31 July 2020, ie one that is made in accordance with the ‘original CJRS directions’ in respect of an employee who ‘ceased all work’ (ie was furloughed) for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June

  2. •

    in respect of a flexibly-furloughed employee as defined in paragraph 10.1 of Treasury Direction No 3 (see: Which employees the employer can put on furlough and claim for below)

  3. •

    in a CJRS claim period, which must:

    1. ◦

      begin and end in the same CJRS calendar month (ie July, August, September or October), and

    2. ◦

      relate to a period of seven or more consecutive days, or to an ‘orphan period’

The ‘original CJRS directions’ are defined as Treasury Direction No 1 and Treasury Direction No 2. Separately, the original CJRS directions are, although these are stated to continue to have effect as modified in the Schedule to Treasury Direction No 3. It is not absolutely clear whether this means that an employer who makes a claim to which the transitional provisions described in Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020)—Which employees the employer can claim for apply (eg because a relevant transfer under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (TUPE) takes place on or after 10 June) is treated as having made a claim in respect of an employee who ‘ceased all work’ for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June. This is because:

  1. •

    a qualifying CJRS claim under Part 2 of the Schedule to Treasury Direction No 3 (ie under the revised CJRS) is defined as a claim made ‘in accordance with the original CJRS directions’

  2. •

    the only definition of ‘the original CJRS directions’ is that which appears in paragraph 2 of Treasury Direction No 3

  3. •

    paragraph 1.3 of the Schedule to Treasury Direction No 3 states that the provision made by Part 2 is ‘without prejudice’ to any matter in connection with the provision made by the original CJRS directions or Part 1 of the Schedule

  4. •

    paragraph 1.4 of the Schedule to Treasury Direction No 3 states that, except as necessary to give effect to the revised CJRS as set out in Part 2, the provision made by the original CJRS directions and Part 1 is without prejudice to any matter in connection with the provision made by Part 2

  5. •

    there is nothing to indicate that, for the purposes of Part 2 of the Schedule, a claim is a qualifying CJRS claim if it is made in accordance with the modifications in Part 1 of the Schedule, rather than in accordance with Treasury Direction No 1 and Treasury Direction No 2 themselves

An employer can claim for any employees it has furloughed if the employer has:

  1. •

    furloughed that employee for at least three consecutive weeks between 1 March and 30 June 2020 (with certain exceptions—see: Which employees the employer can put on furlough and claim for below)

  2. •

    a UK PAYE scheme started on or before 19 March 2020

  3. •

    enrolled for PAYE online

  4. •

    submitted a report under the Real Time Information (RTI) reporting system for that employee on or before 19 March 2020, and

  5. •

    a UK bank account

Which employees the employer can put on furlough and claim for

With certain exceptions, the CJRS closes to new entrants from 30 June. From this point onwards, employers are only able to claim under the revised CJRS for employees that they have furloughed under the original CJRS for at least one full three-week period prior to 30 June.

The factsheet states:

‘The scheme will close to new entrants from 30 June. From this point onwards, employers will only be able to furlough employees that they have furloughed for a full three-week period prior to 30 June.

This means that the final date by which an employer can furlough an employee for the first time will be the 10 June, in order for the current three-week furlough period to be completed by 30 June.’ [Emphasis added]

The way the Schedule to Treasury Direction No 3 works is to define a flexibly-furloughed employee, in respect of whom the employer can make a claim under the revised CJRS, as:

  1. •

    a qualifying employee

  2. •

    who has been instructed by the employer to do no work in relation to their employment during the claim period, or not to work the full amount of their usual hours (see: What flexible furlough arrangements are possible below), because of:

    1. ◦

      circumstances arising as a result of coronavirus or coronavirus disease, or

    2. ◦

      ‘measures taken to prevent or limit its further transmission’ (this potentially broadens the scope of the CJRS specifically to cover measures such as self-isolation and shielding)

  3. •

    who in fact does no work or does not work their usual hours

  4. •

    in respect of whom there is an agreement (see: Flexible furlough arrangements with employees below)

For information on what are usual hours, see: Usual hours below.

The first category of qualifying employee is an employee:

  1. •

    in respect of whom the employer made a claim under the original CJRS on or before 31 July for a period ending on or before 30 June, and

  2. •

    who ceased all work (ie was furloughed) for a minimum three-week period (21 calendar days) beginning on or before 10 June

The two further categories of qualifying employee provide the exceptions to the requirement that an employee must previously have been furloughed under the original CJRS. For further information, see below, under the headings:

  1. •

    ‘Employees returning from family leave after 10 June 2020’

  2. •

    ‘Military reservists returning to work after 10 June’

In addition, there is a further category of ’exception’, employee transfers under TUPE and on a change in ownership, which is dealt with separately in the Treasury Direction No 3 (see: Employee transfers under TUPE and on a change in ownership below).

Subject to these exceptions, it is now clear that, in order to be eligible for grants under the revised CJRS, an employee must have previously been furloughed for at least three consecutive weeks taking place any time between 1 March and 30 June, and that the last day an employee could have started furlough for the first time was 10 June; it is not a requirement of the revised CJRS that, in order to be eligible to be furloughed under the revised CJRS, an employee must have been:

  1. •

    on furlough on 10 June 2020

  2. •

    on furlough on 30 June 2020, or

  3. •

    on furlough for the three-week period prior to 30 June, ie the period 10 to 30 June 2020 inclusive

It follows that, because employees must have been furloughed under the original CJRS, they must have complied with the other qualifying requirements under the original CJRS too. For further guidance on these requirements, see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020)—Which employees the employer can claim for.

Usual hours

As noted above, the qualifying employee must have been instructed either to do no work during the claim period or not to work their usual hours.

Usual hours are calculated:

  1. •

    on the fixed hours basis if the employee’s employment contract requires them to work a specific number of hours over a period of time and does not require their pay to vary according to the numbers worked in that period

  2. •

    in any other case, on the variable hours basis

This means that, where the employment contract requires an employee to work a specific number of hours eg per week, and their pay does not vary according to hours they in fact work in that week, their usual hours will be calculated on a fixed hours basis even if they have spent periods on furlough and periods on short-time working (working reduced hours for reduced pay).

The fixed hours basis is calculated by reference to the employee’s repeating shift pattern. The repeating shift pattern is the regular working pattern a contract requires an employee to undertake in a periodic cycle in the course of the employee's employment, that specifies:

  1. •

    the number of hours the employee must work over the course of the cycle before the next cycle begins, and

  2. •

    the number of calendar days in the cycle over which the hours must be worked (including days on which the employee is not required to work) before the next cycle begins

Therefore, an example of a repeating shift pattern could be 9am to 5pm, Monday to Friday (with Saturday and Sunday as non-working days), or 10am to 4pm, Tuesday to Thursday inclusive (with Friday to Monday inclusive as non-working days).

However, the repeating shift pattern that is used for the calculation is the one having effect at the end of the latest salary period ending on or before 19 March 2020.

This may mean for example that an employee who was placed on furlough under the original CJRS, then resumed work but on a short-time basis (ie with reduced hours) who is then furloughed again (flexibly) under the revised CJRS will have their pay for their furloughed hours calculated on the basis of their usual hours pre-19 March 2020, not the reduced hours they have been working more recently.

Employees on unpaid leave

As with the original CJRS, where an employee takes a period of unpaid sabbatical or other period of unpaid leave during the period beginning on 1 July and ending on 31 October, no claim may be made under the revised CJRS in respect of the period of unpaid leave.

Employees returning from family leave after 10 June 2020

Where an employee has been on maternity, adoption, parental, paternity or parental bereavement leave (family leave) for all or part of the period since the CJRS was first introduced, it may not have been possible (or necessary) for the employer to furlough them under the original CJRS; in that case, in the absence of some exception, they would be ineligible to be furloughed under the revised CJRS when they return.

HM Treasury announced on 9 June 2020 that parents on statutory maternity and paternity leave who return to work in the coming months ‘after a long period of absence’ will be eligible for furlough scheme even after 10 June cut-off date. The announcement stated that this would only apply where they work for an employer who had previously furloughed employees, and that this ‘applies to people on adoption leave, shared parental leave, and parental bereavement leave’.

The revised check which employees you can claim for guidance published on 12 June 2020 confirms that an employer may furlough an employee returning from statutory parental leave after 10 June even if it is furloughing them for the first time. An employer may do this provided that:

  1. •

    the employer has previously used the CJRS, ie it has previously submitted a claim for any other employee in its organisation in relation to a furlough period of at least three consecutive weeks taking place any time between 1 March 2020 and 30 June

  2. •

    the employee the employer wishes to furlough for the first time started maternity, shared parental, adoption, paternity and parental bereavement leave before 10 June and has returned from that leave after 10 June, and

  3. •

    the employee was on the employer’s PAYE payroll on or before 19 March 2020; this means an RTI submission notifying payment in respect of that employee to HMRC must have been made on or before 19 March 2020

The revised check which employees you can claim for guidance published on 1 July confirms that, where the employee starts a furlough period before 1 July this furlough period must be for a minimum period of three weeks, regardless of whether that three week period ends before or after 1 July.

As mentioned above, this exception is set out in paragraph 10.2 of the Schedule to Treasury Direction (No 3), which sets out that one of the categories of qualifying employee is a family leave returner, ie an employee:

  1. •

    who has taken a period of maternity, adoption, shared parental, paternity or parental bereavement leave:

    1. ◦

      beginning on or before 10 June, and

    2. ◦

      ending after 10 June

  2. •

    to whom a payment of earnings was made in the tax year 2019–20 shown in a PAYE return made on or before 28 February, or 19 March, and

  3. •

    in respect of whom a date of cessation of employment has not been reported on or before the date of that return

The number of employees an employer can claim for under the revised CJRS is adjusted in these circumstances (see: Maximum number of employees that may be claimed for below).

Military reservists returning to work after 10 June

An employer can furlough an employee who is a military reservist returning to work after a period of mobilisation that ends after 10 June 2020, even if the employer is furloughing them for the first time.

The employer may do this provided:

  1. •

    the employer has already claimed for another employee in its organisation for a furlough period of at least three consecutive weeks, between 1 March and 30 June 2020

  2. •

    the employee was away on a period of mobilisation that started before 10 June and returned from that mobilisation after 10 June 2020

  3. •

    the employee was on the employer’s r PAYE payroll and the employer submitted an RTI submission for them on or before 19 March 2020

The revised check which employees you can claim for guidance published on 1 July confirms that, where the employee starts a furlough period before 1 July this furlough period must be for a minimum of 3 consecutive weeks. This is the case regardless of whether the three consecutive week minimum period ends before or after 1 July.

As mentioned above, this exception is set out in paragraph 10.2 of the Schedule to Treasury Direction (No 3), which sets out that one of the categories of qualifying employee is an armed forces reservist employee, ie an employee:

  1. •

    who has been called out or recalled for service for a period beginning on or before 10 June and ending after 10 June

  2. •

    to whom a payment of earnings was made in the tax year 2019–20 shown in a PAYE return made on or before 28 February, or 19 March, and

  3. •

    in respect of whom a date of cessation of employment has not been reported on or before the date of that return

The number of employees an employer can claim for under the revised CJRS is adjusted in these circumstances (see: Maximum number of employees that may be claimed for below).

Employee transfers under TUPE and on a change in ownership

Broadly, the HMRC Check which employees you can put on furlough guidance sets out four sets of circumstances where there has been a transfer of employees from one employer to another, in which the new employer is eligible to claim under the revised CJRS:

  1. •

    where the new employer has previously submitted a claim under the original CJRS in relation to a minimum three-week furlough period taking place any time between 1 March and 30 June:

    1. ◦

      in respect of employees of a previous business transferred after 28 February if the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules apply to the change in ownership (see: the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules and Employee transferred and furloughed by new employer on or before 10 June below)

    2. ◦

      in respect of the employees associated with the transfer of a business after 28 February from the liquidator of a company in compulsory liquidation (see: Employee furloughed by new employer on or before 10 June, transfer from former employer (in liquidation) between 1 March and 30 June below)

  2. •

    where the employees being claimed for have previously had a claim submitted for them by their former employer in relation to a minimum three-week furlough period taking place any time between 1 March 2020 and 30 June:

    1. ◦

      in respect of employees transferred after 10 June if the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules apply to the change in ownership (see: Employee transferred after 10 June, furloughed by former employer on or before 10 June below)

    2. ◦

      in respect of the employees associated with a transfer of a business after 10 June from the liquidator of a company in compulsory liquidation (see: Employee furloughed by former employer on or before 10 June, transfer from former employer (liquidated) between 11 June and 31 October below)

The way this is achieved in Treasury Direction No 3 is set out that the new employer may make a CJRS claim in respect of a ‘relevant transferred employee’ by virtue of four separate sub-paragraphs.

For information on the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules, see: the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules below.

The number of employees an employer can claim for under the revised CJRS is adjusted in these circumstances (see: Maximum number of employees that may be claimed for below).

Transferees will therefore need to ensure that, where practicable, the pre-transfer due diligence process requests details of:

  1. •

    which transferring employees have had a claim under the original CJRS submitted in respect of them in relation to a period of at least three consecutive weeks taking place any time between 1 March 2020 and 30 June 2020

  2. •

    the maximum number of such transferring employees in relation to whom the transferor employer claimed under the original CJRS in any one claim ending on or before 30 June 2020

TUPE or PAYE business succession rules

As mentioned above, the HMRC Check which employees you can put on furlough guidance describes two sets of circumstances where the new employer is eligible to claim under the revised CJRS involving the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules. More specifically, these circumstances are set out in paragraph 37.6 of the Schedule to Treasury Direction No 3 as follows:

  1. •

    where the Income Tax (Pay As You Earn) Regulations 2003, SI 2003/2682, reg 102 has effect so that the change of employer from the former employer to the new employer is not treated as a cessation of employment for the purposes of SI 2003/2682, reg 36, ie the employee remains in employment in the same business, and the new owner can take over the operation of the PAYE scheme without completion of a Form P45

  2. •

    where ‘the transfer of the business or undertaking (or part thereof)’ resulting in the change in the employee’s employer does not terminate the employee’s contract of employment by virtue of TUPE, or

  3. •

    where a transfer of the trade, business or undertaking resulting in the change in the employee’s employer does not break the employee’s continuity of employment by virtue of section 218 of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (ERA 1996) (see Practice Note: Continuity of employment—Change of employer)

It is unclear whether the second circumstance described above describes both types of relevant transfer under TUPE, SI 2006/246, reg 3(1), ie business transfers and service provision changes; the words the transfer of the business or undertaking (or part thereof) in Treasury Direction No 3 reflect the words: transfer of an undertaking, business or part of an undertaking or business in TUPE, SI 2006/246, reg 3(1)(a), which would suggest that service provision changes (described in TUPE, SI 2006/246, reg 3(1)) are not covered. However, there would appear to be no rationale for employers not to be able to furlough employees who transfer by reason of a service provision change to which TUPE applies in the same way as they may furlough employees who transfer by reason of a business transfer. The position remains unclear, and it is to be hoped that HMRC guidance will provide clarification on this point in due course.

Employee transferred and furloughed by new employer on or before 10 June

An employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(a) of Treasury Direction No 3 if:

  1. •

    on 28 February, the employee was employed by the former employer

  2. •

    after 28 February, there has been an employee transfer to which the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules apply (see above), the effect of which is that there is a change of employer from the former employer to the new employer while the employee remains in employment in the same business

  3. •

    immediately before the change, the former employer's PAYE scheme having effect in relation to the employee was a qualifying PAYE scheme

  4. •

    the employee's new employer made a CJRS claim in respect of the employee:

    1. ◦

      on or before 31 July

    2. ◦

      in accordance with the original CJRS

    3. ◦

      for a period ending on or before 30 June

    4. ◦

      who was furloughed for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June

The transfer must have taken place on or before 10 June, otherwise the employee’s new employer would not have been able to make a CJRS claim in respect of a three-week furlough period beginning on or before that date.

If an employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(a) of Treasury Direction No 3, the new employer can make a CJRS claim in respect of that employee as if it had:

  1. •

    a qualifying PAYE scheme, and

  2. •

    made a payment of earnings in respect of that employee in the tax year 2019–20 which is shown in a PAYE return (ie notified on an RTI submission) made on or before 19 March

Employee transferred after 10 June, furloughed by former employer on or before 10 June

An employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(c) of Treasury Direction No 3 if:

  1. •

    on or before 31 July, the employee’s former employer ‘falls as a qualifying employer’ in relation to the employee (ie the former employer had a qualifying PAYE scheme and made a qualifying CJRS claim), or would do if the relevant transfer had not occurred, and

  2. •

    on 10 June the employee was employed by the former employer

  3. •

    after 10 June, there has been an employee transfer to which the TUPE or PAYE business succession rules apply (see above), the effect of which is that there is a change of employer from the former employer to the new employer while the employee remains in employment in the same business

  4. •

    immediately before the change, the former employer's PAYE scheme having effect in relation to the employee was a qualifying PAYE scheme

  5. •

    the employee ‘falls as a qualifying employee’ in relation to the former employer (ie one in respect of whom a claim was made under the original CJRS and who ceased all work (ie was furloughed) for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June), or would do if the relevant transfer had not occurred

If an employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(c) of Treasury Direction No 3, the new employer can make a CJRS claim in respect of that employee as if:

  1. •

    the new employer had:

    1. ◦

      a qualifying PAYE scheme

    2. ◦

      made a payment of earnings in respect of that employee in the tax year 2019–20 which is shown in a PAYE return (ie notified on an RTI submission) made on or before 19 March, and

    3. ◦

      made a qualifying CJRS claim under the original CJRS in respect of the employee, and

  2. •

    paragraph 10.3 (the criteria for an employee being a qualifying employee) applied in relation to the employee, ie as if:

    1. ◦

      on or before 31 July the employer had made a CJRS claim in accordance with the original CJRS in respect of the employee for a period ending on or before 30 June, and

    2. ◦

      the employee had ceased all work (ie was furloughed) for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June

Employee furloughed by new employer on or before 10 June, transfer from former employer (in liquidation) between 1 March and 30 June

An employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(b) of Treasury Direction No 3 if:

  1. •

    on or before 31 July, the employee's new employer has made a CJRS claim in accordance with the original CJRS in respect of the employee for a period ending on or before 30 June, ie the employee ceased all work (ie was furloughed) for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June

  2. •

    on 28 February, the employee was employed by the former employer

  3. •

    between 1 March and 30 June, the employee's employment with the former employer terminated before the time of the relevant transfer, ie a transfer of a business, or part of a business, that amounts to a relevant transfer under TUPE 2006, SI 2006/246

  4. •

    the employee’s employment by the new employer began on the day their employment with the former employer terminated

  5. •

    the relevant transfer is the sole or principal reason for the termination of the employee's employment by the former employer, and for their employment by the new employer

  6. •

    immediately before the termination of the employee's employment, the former employer's PAYE scheme having effect in relation to the employee was a qualifying PAYE scheme, and

  7. •

    at the time of the TUPE transfer, a winding-up order has been made in respect of the former employer (ie it is in compulsory liquidation)

  8. •

    the employee did not transfer to the new employer by virtue of TUPE 2006, because TUPE 2006, SI 2006/246, reg 4 (transfer of employment contract and rights and liabilities) and TUPE 2006, SI 2006/246, reg 7 (automatic unfair dismissal) were disapplied by reason of TUPE 2006, SI 2006/246, reg 8(7) (see Practice Note: TUPE—effect of insolvency)

  9. •

    the employee's new employer made a CJRS claim in respect of the employee:

    1. ◦

      on or before 31 July

    2. ◦

      in accordance with the original CJRS

    3. ◦

      for a period ending on or before 30 June

    4. ◦

      who was furloughed for a minimum three-week period beginning on or before 10 June

If an employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(b) of the Treasury Direction No 3, the new employer can make a CJRS claim in respect of that employee as if it had:

  1. •

    a qualifying PAYE scheme, and

  2. •

    made a payment of earnings in respect of that employee in the tax year 2019–20 which is shown in a PAYE return (ie notified on an RTI submission) made on or before 19 March

Employee furloughed by former employer on or before 10 June, transfer from former employer (in liquidation) between 11 June and 31 October

An employee is a ‘relevant transferred employee’ under paragraph 37.4(d) of Treasury Direction No 3 if:

  1. •

    the employee’s former employer ‘falls as a qualifying employer’ in relation to the employee (ie one with a qualifying PAYE scheme who made a qualifying CJRS claim on or before 31 July), or would do if the relevant transfer had not occurred, and
