Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—holiday and holiday pay
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note considers issues relating to the right to holiday and holiday pay during the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. It:

  1. •

    summarises the position under WTR 1998 in relation to the right to annual leave (or holiday) and pay under the Working Time Regulations 1998 (WTR 1998), SI 1998/1833, as a reminder of the general context in which these issues need to be considered

  2. •

    describes the relevant guidance issued by the Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy (BEIS), HMRC and Acas, and

  3. •

    considers, specifically in the context of holiday and holiday pay during the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic:

    1. ◦

      how holiday pay is calculated

    2. ◦

      whether an employer can tell an employee when to take their holiday, including managing holiday requests and requests to cancel booked holiday, and whether an employer can cancel a worker’s booked holiday or require a worker to take holiday at specific times

    3. ◦

      amendments to the WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833 relating to carrying forward holiday entitlement under the Working Time (Coronavirus) (Amendment) Regulations 2020 (Amendment Regs 2020), SI 2020/365

    4. ◦

      holiday and holiday pay for workers who are furloughed under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS) (see: Furloughed workers below), and

    5. ◦

      practical issues that may arise

The position under WTR 1998

For general information on the right to take holiday, also referred to as annual leave, and to be paid for it, see Practice Notes: Holiday and Holiday pay.

In summary, the position is as follows:

  1. •

    workers (and agency workers) have the right to paid annual leave, or holiday, under WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833 (see Practice Note: Holiday—Eligibility for statutory holiday)

  2. •

    the right under WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833 is to a total of 5.6 weeks' annual leave each leave year (see Practice Note: Holiday—Statutory holiday entitlement), made up of:

    1. ◦

      a basic entitlement to a minimum of four weeks' annual leave (20 days for a regular full-time worker), implementing the right to annual leave under Directive 2003/88/EC, the Working Time Directive (WTD)

    2. ◦

      an additional entitlement to 1.6 weeks' annual leave each leave year (eight days for a regular full-time worker), which is a right under domestic legislation only

  3. •

    under WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833, reg 15, and (see Practice Note: Holiday—When statutory holiday may be taken and the notice requirements):

    1. ◦

      the worker may give notice of when they wish to take leave

    2. ◦

      the employer may give a counter-notice refusing a worker’s request for leave, and/or

    3. ◦

      the employer may give notice requiring the worker to take leave at certain times

  4. •

    under WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833, reg 13(9), the basic four weeks' annual leave must be taken in the leave year in respect of which it is due and may not be carried over from one leave year to the next, ie the worker must ‘use it or lose it’, subject to certain exceptions established from case law, in relation to those who have been absent due to long-term sickness, are prevented from taking holiday for other reasons beyond their control or are, or have been, on maternity leave (see Practice Note: Holiday—Statutory holiday accrual, under the heading ‘Carry forward of leave’)

  5. •

    statutory holiday entitlement cannot be replaced by a payment in lieu except where the employment ends (see Practice Note: Holiday—Payment in lieu of statutory holiday entitlement)

  6. •

    there is no statutory right to take bank or public holidays as paid annual leave; the right to take leave on such days is governed by the express or implied terms of the worker's contract (see Practice Note: Holiday—Bank holidays and public holidays)

In addition, the contract of employment or other contract between the employer and the worker may provide the right to enhanced paid holiday, known as contractual holiday entitlement (see Practice Note: Holiday—Contractual holiday entitlement).

For information on the various practical issues that arise in relation to the entitlement to annual leave and holiday pay of workers who are, or have been, absent on sick leave, see Practice Note: Holiday and sickness absence.

The purpose of holiday

According to the ECJ in Stringer, the purpose of the entitlement to paid annual leave under Directive 2003/88/EC, the WTD is to enable the worker to rest and to enjoy a period of relaxation and leisure. In Schulte, the ECJ stated:

‘The right to paid annual leave, as laid down in Article 31(2) of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and in Article 7 of Directive 2003/88, has the dual purpose of enabling the worker both to rest from carrying out the work he is required to do under his contract of employment and to enjoy a period of relaxation and leisure (see Schultz-Hoff and others, paragraph 25).’

For further information on these issues generally, see Practice Notes:

  1. •

    Holiday—Holidays and other employment rights, and

  2. •

    Charter of Fundamental Rights of the EU and European Convention on Human Rights

Relevant guidance

This Practice Note takes into account:

  1. •

    the BEIS guidance: Holiday entitlement and pay during coronavirus (COVID-19)

  2. •

    the Acas advice on coronavirus for employers and employees, in particular the section on using holiday, first published on 31 March 2020 and updated several times subsequently (for details, see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme—guidance tracker—Acas: Coronavirus (COVID-19): advice for employers and employees)

  3. •

    the HMRC guidance for employers on working out 80% of employees' wages to claim through the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, first published on 17 April 2020 and updated several times subsequently, and subsequently superseded by two separate guidance documents: Steps to take before calculating your claim using the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme and Calculate how much you can claim using the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (for details, see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme—guidance tracker)

  4. •

    the HMRC guidance for employees on the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme, first published on 26 March 2020 and also updated several times subsequently (for details, see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme—guidance tracker—Guidance for employees: Check if your employer can use the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme)

BEIS guidance

The BEIS: guidance was first published on 13 May 2020 (see News Analysis: BEIS issues guidance on holiday entitlement and pay during coronavirus (COVID-19)). It provides:

  1. •

    a recap of the normal legal framework in relation to holiday and holiday pay

  2. •

    guidance on how that framework applies in relation to furloughed workers (including furloughed agency workers), and

  3. •

    guidance on the coronavirus-related provisions for carrying holiday entitlement into future years

The BEIS: guidance does not have statutory force. The BEIS: guidance states that it ‘should not be treated as legal advice. Employers and workers should always check individual contracts and if necessary seek independent legal advice’.

The guidance should be approached with some degree of caution, for the reasons explained in Additional considerations for employers in relation to notice of holiday below.

Acas guidance

Prior to 13 May, the Acas: Coronavirus: advice for employers and employees, first published on 31 March 2020, was the only general advice available. This included a section on using holiday which was subsequently updated on 2 April, 7 April and again on 9 April. As with the BEIS guidance, the Acas holiday advice does not have statutory force.

In relation to furloughed workers, before the BEIS guidance was published on 13 May:

  1. •

    prior to 17 April, those raising queries relating to holiday entitlement for furloughed workers were typically being referred to the Acas Coronavirus (COVID-19): advice for employers and employees—Using holiday

  2. •

    from 17 April, the employer guidance on working out 80% of employees' wages and the employee guidance included a section on holiday pay

The Acas holiday advice has been less than completely clear. The issues that were raised as a result were discussed by David Reade QC and Daniel Northall of Littleton Chambers in their articles:

  1. •

    The coronavirus job retention scheme: more holiday cancellations?, which considered the first version of the Acas advice, published on 31 March 2020

  2. •

    The Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme: an addendum on annual leave, which considered the version of the advice published on 2 April, and

  3. •

    Portal’s eve, which considered the employer guidance on working out 80% of employees' wages, published on 17 April, and the employee guidance, amended on the same date

See also the article by David Reade QC and others: Collaborative view on the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme from four silks.

For further information on the development of the relevant guidance, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—guidance tracker for employment.

Whether an employer can tell an employee when to take their holiday

In relation to statutory basic and additional holiday entitlement, the timing of leave is regulated by WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833, reg 15 (see: ‘Statutory holiday entitlement’ below. However, these rather prescriptive provisions are subject to variation or exclusion by the employment contract or another relevant agreement. For information on what is a ‘relevant ‘agreement’, see Practice Note: Holiday—Statutory holiday entitlement.

The contract may provide, for example, that:

  1. •

    the taking of holiday is subject to manager approval

  2. •

    a holiday request can be refused in certain circumstances, eg having regard to the reasonable requirements of the business

  3. •

    subject to reasonable notice being given, the employer can stipulate that holiday is required to be taken at a particular time

  4. •

    the employer can require holiday to be taken during a notice period

  5. •

    the employer can direct that holiday be taken by giving shorter notice than that provided for under the WTR 1998

  6. •

    unused holiday cannot be carried forward other than in specific circumstances

  7. •

    an employee is deemed to take their statutory basic annual leave entitlement first, then their statutory additional annual leave entitlement, and finally any additional contractual annual leave entitlement

  8. •

    on termination of employment the employee will be paid in lieu of accrued but untaken statutory holiday only, and that there will be no payment in lieu of accrued but untaken contractual holiday

For further information, see Practice Note: Holiday—When statutory holiday may be taken and the notice requirements. See also clause 7 of Precedent: Employment contract basic version.

For further information on working time generally, see Practice Note: Working time rights and obligations.

In relation to contractual holiday entitlement:

  1. •

    in the absence of an agreement to the contrary, holiday should be taken at a time ultimately determined by the employer, as the employee is obliged to obey reasonable and lawful orders from their employer

  2. •

    however, the employer will also be subject to an implied term not to act in a manner which is calculated to destroy or seriously damage the relationship of trust and confidence between employer and employee. This may mean, eg that the employer must not unreasonably refuse an employee's request to take holiday, or unreasonably direct an employee to take holiday when they do not want to do so

Statutory holiday entitlement

If the contract does not set out how and when notice of statutory holiday entitlement must be given, in summary:

  1. •

    the employee may elect to take holiday, by giving at least twice as many days’ notice in advance of the intended holiday period as the length of the intended holiday, eg a worker who wishes to take one week’s holiday must give at least two weeks’ notice of their intention to take that holiday

  2. •

    the employer may require the employee to take holiday on particular days, again by giving at least twice as many days’ notice in advance of the intended holiday period as the length of the intended holiday

  3. •

    the employer may require the employee not to take holiday on particular days by giving at least as many days’ notice in advance of the intended holiday period as the length of the intended holiday

Although the notice does not need to be in writing, this would be advisable for practical and evidential reasons. The employer must specify the days on which leave is or is not to be taken and, where the leave on a particular day is to be in respect of only a part of a day, its duration.

On the face of it, therefore, the employer may effectively use the mechanism for giving notices and counter-notices under WTR 1998 to:

  1. •

    refuse a worker's request to take holiday at a particular time, or

  2. •

    direct an employee to take holiday at a particular time

The BEIS guidance: Holiday entitlement and pay during coronavirus (COVID-19)—Taking holiday reflects the above provisions of the WTR 1998 without further comment. This would suggest that, in BEIS’s view, an employer is free, during the coronavirus pandemic, to cancel a worker’s holiday or to require workers to take holiday, provided the notice requirements are met. However, there are a number of additional considerations that should be taken into account before the employer simply adopts this approach, as set out below.

Bank holidays

As mentioned above (see: The position under WTR 1998), there is no statutory right to take bank or public holidays as paid annual leave.

The BEIS guidance makes this point, and also sets out that, where necessary, employers can require workers who would usually take bank holidays as holiday to work instead, using the standard notice periods; if employers do this, they must still ensure that workers receive their statutory holiday entitlement for the year.

For information on how to deal with a bank holiday that falls during a worker’s period of furlough, see: Furloughed workers below, under the heading ‘Bank holidays’.

Additional considerations for employers in relation to notice of holiday

An employer may have the right to direct when a worker or employee can take holiday under a relevant agreement or the WTR 1998 and, as mentioned above, the BEIS guidance suggests that an employer is free, during the coronavirus pandemic, to cancel a worker’s holiday or to require workers to take holiday, provided the notice requirements are met.

However, as mentioned above, the BEIS guidance does not have statutory effect and it not clear how, if at all, an employment tribunal would be prepared to take it into account in any employment tribunal claim.

Potential claims against the employer by an affected worker may include:

  1. •

    that the employer has failed to permit the worker to exercise their right to holiday (see Practice Note: Remedies for breach of working time rights—Breach of individuals' WTR rights)

  2. •

    for detriment and/or unfair dismissal (see the sections of Practice Note: Remedies for breach of working time rights: Suffering detriment and Dismissal for exercising WTR rights)

  3. •

    unlawful deductions from wages, if the employer fails to pay the worker the correct holiday pay (see: How holiday pay is calculated below)

  4. •

    constructive dismissal, eg where the employee’s contractual holiday entitlement is not satisfied or where the employer breaches the implied term of trust and confidence (see Practice Notes: Constructive dismissal and The term of trust and confidence)

  5. •

    for discrimination or other prohibited conduct (see: Prohibited conduct—overview)

It may therefore be important to consider:

  1. •

    whether the ‘fundamental purpose’ of annual leave can be met at the time when the employer intends to direct the worker to take holiday (see below)

  2. •

    in relation to an employee, the employer’s duty not to treat an employee in a wholly unreasonable manner under the imposed term of trust and confidence (see Practice Note: The term of trust and confidence). This means, as mentioned above, that the employer must not unreasonably refuse an employee's request to take holiday, or unreasonably impose a period of holiday on the employee

  3. •

    the employer’s legal duties in relation to the health, safety and welfare at work of their workers. The right to take time off from work for holidays benefits both employers and workers by allowing workers a period of relaxation and recuperation. The health benefits of using holiday are acknowledged in Acas advice, which points out that it is important for employees and workers to use their statutory holiday entitlement in their current leave year because it helps people keep physically and mentally healthy. This may be an important consideration for employers seeking to direct a worker to take their accrued holiday entitlement

  4. •

    the protection given to workers and employees against detriment, and to employees against dismissal, in relation to their rights under the WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833. Such protection may arise if the worker, or employee, as the case may be, suffers a detriment or was dismissed for refusing to comply with a requirement imposed by the employer in breach of the WTR 1998, or for refusing to forego a right under the WTR 1998 (see Practice Note: Working time rights and obligations)

  5. •

    implications for accrued holiday that cannot be taken in the current leave year, and whether such holiday can be carried forward into subsequent leave years

  6. •

    that an employer cannot use the powers of refusal of leave or of direction in such a way as to prevent workers from taking accrued leave either directly or, by seeking to postpone it outside the relevant leave year, by causing it to expire

See also: Carrying over holiday entitlement, below in relation to particular rules that apply to carrying forward holiday entitlement into the next two leave years where a worker has been prevented from taking it because of coronavirus.

The provisions in the WTR 1998 set out in Statutory holiday entitlement above are reflected, without further comment, in the section of the BEIS holiday guidance on taking holiday.

However, since 7 April, the Acas advice has encouraged employers, employees and workers to be ‘as flexible as they can’ about holiday during the coronavirus pandemic, and suggested that it is a good idea for the parties to:

  1. •

    talk about any plans to use or cancel holiday during coronavirus as soon as possible

  2. •

    discuss why holiday might need to be taken or cancelled

  3. •

    listen to any concerns, either from staff or the employer

  4. •

    welcome and suggest ideas for other options (the pre-9 April 2020 version of the guidance suggested the employer should ‘invite and suggest ideas for alternatives’)

  5. •

    consider everyone’s physical and mental wellbeing

  6. •

    be aware that it’s a difficult time for both employers and staff

The Acas advice states that, eg shutting for a week and telling staff to use their holiday entitlement, or cancelling pre-booked holiday could affect holiday staff have already booked or planned and cause upset. So employers should:

  1. •

    explain clearly why they need to do this

  2. •

    try and resolve anyone's worries about how it will affect their holiday entitlement or plans

As mentioned above, the Acas advice states that:

  1. •

    employers should still be encouraging workers and employees to take their paid holiday, and

  2. •

    employees and workers should make requests for paid holiday throughout their holiday year, if possible

The updated Acas advice acknowledges that an employee may no longer want to take time off they had previously booked, eg because their hotel cancelled the booking. Their employer can insist they still take the time off, but it is best practice to get the employee’s agreement. Equally, if the employee wants to change when they take this time off, they will need to get agreement from their employer.

The fundamental purpose of holiday

The purpose of holiday, as mentioned in The position under WTR 1998 above, under the heading ‘The purpose of holiday’ is to enable the worker to rest and to enjoy a period of relaxation and leisure.

While the BEIS guidance acknowledges this ‘fundamental purpose’, it appears to do so only to the extent that the employer should consider whether any restrictions the furloughed worker is under (eg the need to socially distance or self-isolate), would prevent the worker from resting, relaxing and enjoying leisure time before requiring a furloughed worker to take holiday (see below).

However, it is difficult to see why an employer should not also consider more generally whether those same restrictions would prevent any worker (not just a furloughed worker) from resting or enjoying a period of relaxation and leisure during the coronavirus pandemic. The social distancing restrictions have eased since they were first imposed on 26 March 2020, eg since 13 May people have been permitted to leave their homes for an extended list of reasons, including to visit a public open space for the purposes of open-air recreation to promote their physical or mental health or emotional wellbeing alone, with members of their household or with one member of another household. However, businesses providing holiday accommodation remain closed for leisure stays, and quarantine or ‘self-isolation’ restrictions are in place which will affect UK residents returning to the UK, which would affect anyone wanting to go on holiday other than (currently) within the UK, or to the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

Whether a period of holiday taken during the coronavirus pandemic would meet the fundamental purpose may depend, at least in part, on the worker’s personal circumstances; an individual who lives in a small flat or shared accommodation in the centre of a city without a garden, or access to the countryside or the beach may find it harder to find rest, relaxation and leisure while activities and travel are restricted than a colleague who has a garden and/or access to the countryside or the beach. A person who is shielding is unlikely to find relaxation or leisure while they are unable to leave their home or (from 1 June) advised to only spend time outdoors with members of their own household or, if they live alone, with one person from another household.

How holiday pay is calculated

Under WTR 1998, during any period of statutory holiday a worker is entitled to be paid at the rate of a 'week's pay' for each week of holiday, calculated in accordance with sections 221 to 224 of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (ERA 1996) (with certain modifications). For further information, see Practice Note: Holiday pay—Calculating statutory holiday pay: general.

Different methods of calculating a week’s pay apply, depending on whether the worker in question works 'normal working hours' or 'no normal working hours'. Briefly:

  1. •

    if a worker has normal working hours and their pay does not vary with the amount of work done, then they are entitled to the amount which is payable if they work throughout their normal working hours in a week (which, in general, has meant basic salary only) (see Practice Note: Holiday pay—Calculating statutory holiday pay: normal working hours), or

  2. •

    if the worker has no normal working hours, a week's pay is calculated (from 6 April 2020) as the average weekly remuneration (including commission and bonuses) over the previous 52 complete weeks in which remuneration is earned (see Practice Note: Holiday pay—Calculating statutory holiday pay: no normal working hours)

The BEIS guidance on holiday pay confirms that holiday pay should be calculated in line with the current legislation, based on a worker’s usual earnings, whether the worker is on furlough or not. The underlying principle is that a worker should not be financially worse off through taking holiday. Where they have regular hours and pay, their holiday would be calculated based on these hours; if they have variable hours or pay, their holiday pay is calculated as an average of the previous 52 weeks’ remuneration, excluding weeks in which there was no remuneration.

For information on holiday pay for furloughed workers, see: Furloughed workers below, under the heading ‘Holiday pay’.

Carrying forward holiday entitlement

Changes to the rules governing the carrying forward, or carrying over, of holiday entitlement have been introduced to give employers more flexibility to manage statutory holiday obligations and staffing requirements during the coronavirus pandemic, and allow workers to carry forward up to four weeks’ basic holiday entitlement into the next two leave years if they have been prevented from taking their holiday because of coronavirus.

These changes apply only to the four weeks of holiday provided for by the WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833, reg 13, and not the additional 1.6 weeks’ holiday provided for by WTR 1998, SI 1998/1833, reg 13A, which is subject to different carrying-over rules.

As mentioned above, the unamended WTR 1998 provides as follows:

  1. •

    the four weeks’ basic holiday entitlement must, subject to certain exceptions established from case law, be taken in the leave year in respect of which it is due and may not be carried over from one leave year to the next. This means that if a worker does not take their basic holiday entitlement in the year in which it falls due, it will generally be lost

  2. •

    the 1.6. weeks’ additional holiday entitlement may be carried forward into the leave year immediately following the leave year in respect of which it is due, if provided for in a relevant agreement (ie an employment contract or other legally enforceable agreement between the worker and the employer, a workforce agreement or collective agreement forming part of the agreement between the worker and employer)

  3. •

    a worker is not permitted to be paid in lieu of untaken basic holiday entitlement other than on termination of employment

For further information, see Practice Notes:

  1. •

    Holiday—Statutory holiday accrual, and

  2. •

    Holiday pay—Entitlement to statutory holiday pay on termination of employment

The Amendment Regs 2020, SI 2020/365 came into effect at 9pm on 26 March 2020. Amendment Regs 2020, SI 2020/365, reg 3 introduces a statutory exception to the rule against carrying forward basic holiday entitlement, and provides that those workers for whom it has not been reasonably practicable to take some or all of their four weeks’ basic holiday entitlement as a result of the effects of coronavirus (on the worker or their employer specifically, or on the economy or society more broadly), may carry forward such untaken holiday. This carried-forward holiday may be taken in the two leave years immediately following the leave year in respect of which it was due.

However, it is clear that the provisions allowing a worker to carry forward holiday do not apply to:

  1. •

    the 1.6 weeks of additional annual leave, and

  2. •

    any part of the basic four-week entitlement in respect of which it can be said that it was, despite ‘the effects of coronavirus’, nonetheless ‘reasonably practicable’ for the worker to take that leave during the original leave year to which it relates

For information on how the carry-forward provisions apply in respect of furloughed workers, see: Furloughed workers below, under the heading ‘Carrying forward holiday’.

The BEIS guidance includes guidance on the changes introduced by the Amendment Regs 2020, SI 2020/365. For further information, see News Analysis: BEIS issues guidance on holiday entitlement and pay during coronavirus (COVID-19).

As regards such parts of annual leave that cannot be carried forward, the guidance states that employers must give workers the opportunity to take that leave before the end of the leave year (to prevent them from losing the leave when the leave year ends).

Carrying forward additional and contractual holiday

As mentioned above, the provisions in the Amendment Regs 2020, SI 2020/365, allowing a worker to carry forward holiday do not apply to:

  1. •

    the 1.6 weeks of additional annual leave, and

  2. •

    any part of the basic four-week entitlement in respect of which it can be said that it was, despite ‘the effects of coronavirus’, nonetheless ‘reasonably practicable’ for the worker to take that leave during the original leave year to which it relates

Whether or not any such additional statutory holiday, or enhanced contractual holiday entitlement, can be carried forward will depend on the terms of the contract. See eg clause 7.6 of Precedent: Employment contract basic version.

Employers who wish to restrict the taking of holiday during the coronavirus pandemic (eg those in essential services) may therefore want to ensure that contractual terms are amended to permit employees to carry forward additional statutory holiday, and any further contractual entitlement where appropriate, if this is not already provided for, in order to avoid their employees losing this entitlement.

Employers may also want to include or review provisions specifying the order in which the different categories of leave entitlement are used. Contractual terms may provide, for example, that an employee is deemed to take their statutory basic annual leave entitlement first, then their statutory additional annual leave entitlement, and finally any additional contractual annual leave entitlement. See eg clause 7.1 of Precedent: Employment contract basic version.

The Acas advice states that, if employers do not already have an agreement in place, they can decide whether they will allow more than the four weeks’ basic statutory holiday entitlement) to be carried over (ie the remaining 1.6 weeks of statutory annual leave and/or the holiday that is more than the legal minimum). It also suggests that employees and workers should check their employment contract or talk to their employer to find out what they are entitled to.

Whether it was reasonably practicable for the worker to take leave

Clearly, application of the special coronavirus statutory mechanism for carry-over will depend on the interpretation of the phrase ‘not been reasonably practicable’. The BEIS guidance says that, in applying that test, an employer should consider various factors, such as:

  1. •

    whether the business has faced a significant increase in demand due to coronavirus that would reasonably require the worker to continue to be at work and that cannot be met through alternative practical measures

  2. •

    the extent to which the business’ workforce is disrupted by the coronavirus and the practical options available to the business to provide temporary cover of essential activities

  3. •

    the health of the worker and how soon they need to take a period of rest and relaxation

  4. •

    the length of time remaining in the worker’s leave year, to enable the worker to take holiday at a later date within the leave year

  5. •

    the extent to which the worker taking leave would impact on wider society’s response to, and recovery from, the coronavirus situation, and

  6. •

    the ability of the remainder of the available workforce to provide cover for the worker going on leave

Separately, in relation to furloughed workers, the BEIS guidance states that if the employer is unable to fund the difference between the CJRS grant and the worker’s ‘correct’ holiday pay, it is likely that this would make ...

It: • summarises the position under WTR 1998 in relation to the right to annual leave (or holiday) and pay under the Working Time Regulations 1998 (WTR 1998), SI 1998/1833

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—guidance tracker for employment
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note provides details of the various versions of guidance and advice that have been published by the Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy (BEIS), Acas, the Cabinet Office, HMRC and Public Health England (PHE), and provides tracked change versions, showing the updates between one version and the next, to enable practitioners easily to ascertain which version of the relevant guidance was live at any given date.

Separate sections of the Practice Note cover:

  1. •

    Acas: Coronavirus (COVID-19): advice for employers and employees

  2. •

    Cabinet guidance: Closing certain businesses and venues in England

  3. •

Bank holidays are usually part of the legal minimum 5.6 weeks’ paid holiday. Employees and workers must get their usual pay for bank holidays.

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme (CSSPRS)
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note considers the Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme (CSSPRS), under The Statutory Sick Pay (Coronavirus) (Funding of Employers’ Liabilities) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/512, in force 26 May 2020.

Key points to note

The government’s initiative to refund coronavirus-related statutory sick pay (SSP) was first announced in the Spring Budget 2020 (see News: Special temporary measures for Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) refunds announced in Budget).

The Coronavirus Act 2020, s 39(1) inserted a new provision for the funding of employers’ SSP liabilities in relation to coronavirus into the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992 (SSCBA 1992). SSCBA 1992, s 159B(1), enables regulations to make provision ‘for the payment by employers of statutory sick pay in respect of incapacity for work related to coronavirus to be funded by Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs to such extent and in such manner as may be prescribed’.

The Statutory Sick Pay (Coronavirus) (Funding of Employers’ Liabilities) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/512, in force 26 May 2020, provide the legal basis for the Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme (CSSPRS), the online service through which employers can reclaim coronavirus-related SSP, and set out requirements in relation to:

  1. •

    eligibility for funding (see Eligibility for funding, below)

  2. •

    making a claim (see Making a claim, below)

  3. •

    payments (see Payments and information requests, below)

  4. •

    record-keeping (see Record-keeping requirements, below), and

  5. •

    information requests (see Payments and information requests, below)

HMRC guidance

On 3 April 2020, HMRC published general guidance on the CSSPRS, and for employers to check whether they are eligible to claim back coronavirus-related SSP. This guidance has subsequently been updated a number of times.

On 26 May 2020, HMRC published guidance on how to claim under the CSSPRS to coincide with the launch of the online claims portal.

Separate service availability and issues guidance was also published on 26 May 2020, specifically for employers to check the availability status of the online portal and whether there are any reported issues in relation to accessing or using the service.

The general guidance includes information about which employers are eligible for the scheme, and what can be claimed.

The claims process guidance includes information about what information will be needed to submit a claim, how to claim, record-keeping obligations, and what happens after a claim has been submitted.

The CSSPRS online application service has been available since 26 May 2020.

Eligibility for funding

An eligible employer who has made a payment of SSP to an employee, may recover the amount paid (the reimbursement amount) from HMRC, provided:

  1. •

    that employee’s period of incapacity for work is related to coronavirus, and

  2. •

    the first day of incapacity for work in that period falls on or after 13 March 2020

An application for judicial review (heard on 11 June 2020) of the government’s decisions to amend the scheme for statutory sick pay (SSP) as a response to the pandemic without including those who are ‘workers’ within the meaning of ‘limb b’ of section 230(3) of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (‘limb b workers’), raising the level of SSP or removing the lower earnings limit (and to exclude limb (b) workers from the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)), alleging breaches of Article 14 of, and Article 1 of the First Protocol to, the European Convention on Human Rights, indirect discrimination on grounds of sex and race under EU law, and breach of the public sector equality duty, was dismissed by the High Court.

Former employees

An eligible employer is also permitted to recover the reimbursement amount in respect of a former employee who meets these conditions.

Employee must be eligible for SSP

An employer will not be able to claim back a payment made in relation to an employee who does not qualify for SSP (see Practice Note: Sick pay—SSP—eligibility).

Employees who have transferred under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (TUPE)

An employer can make a claim for SSP paid due to coronavirus to employees who have been transferred to it under TUPE if the employer had:

  1. •

    a PAYE scheme that was created and started on or before 28 February 2020, and

  2. •

    fewer than 250 employees (including TUPE transferred employees) across all PAYE payroll schemes on 28 February 2020

If the employer did not have a PAYE scheme that was created on or before 28 February 2020, but the previous employer did, the transferee employer can make a claim if the previous employer had fewer than 250 employees across all their PAYE schemes on that date.

As the new employer, an employer can only make claims for SSP that they have paid; a claim cannot include SSP paid by the previous employer.

For further information on TUPE generally, see: TUPE—overview.

State aid limits apply

A SSP rebate under the CSSPRS qualifies as state aid under the EU Commission temporary framework. In terms of the cap on support under the framework, an employer cannot submit a claim amount above the maximum €800,000 of state aid when combined with other aid received under the framework. There is a lower maximum for agriculture at €100,000 and aquaculture and fisheries at €120,000. This means that an employer is not permitted to claim the reimbursement amount if receipt of it would exceed the maximum permitted temporary aid amount.

For further information on state aid, see: State aid—overview, and News Analysis: Coronavirus (COVID-19) and State aid rules–the Commission’s approach.

No concurrent claim under Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme

An employer is also not entitled to a reimbursement amount in respect of an employee for a period for which the employer is entitled to a grant in respect of that employee under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme—ie an employer can claim back from both the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme and the CSSPRS for the same employee but not in respect of the same period of time (see Practice Note: Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (original version to 30 June 2020)).

Maximum amount that can be claimed

The amount that an eligible employer can recover from HMRC under the regulations is limited to:

  1. •

    in relation to a single employee, £191.70. This amount equates to two weeks’ SSP calculated at the weekly rate of £95.85 (which is the current weekly SSP rate as of 6 April 2020; before 6 April 2020 the weekly SSP rate was £94.25—see Practice Note: Sick pay—SSP—rate and recovery), and

  2. •

    in total, £191.70 multiplied by the number of employees enrolled in PAYE schemes of the eligible employer on 28 February 2020

Even if an employer pays the employee more than the weekly rate of SSP (eg as occupational sick pay), the employer can only claim up to the statutory weekly rate paid.

Employer eligibility requirements

An eligible employer is an employer that:

  1. •

    on 28 February 2020, had fewer than 250 employees enrolled in all PAYE schemes operated by the employer, and

  2. •

    on 31 December 2019, was not already ‘in difficulty’ for state aid purposes

Connected companies and charities can also use the scheme if their total combined number of PAYE employees was fewer than 250 on 28 February 2020.

When incapacity for work is related to coronavirus

An employee’s incapacity for work is related to coronavirus if the employee is:

  1. •

    incapable by reason of infection or contamination with coronavirus, or

  2. •

    deemed, in accordance with the Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, reg 2(1)(c) to be incapable by reason of coronavirus

of doing work which the employee can reasonably be expected to do under their contract of employment.

An employee will be to be incapable by reason of coronavirus if they are self-isolating or shielding. For further information, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—sickness absence and pay—Changes to Statutory Sick Pay (SSP), under the heading SSP entitlement extended to those who self-isolate.

HMRC’s guidance explains that the repayment will cover up to two weeks’ SSP starting from the first qualifying day of sickness, if an employee is unable to work because they either:

  1. •

    have coronavirus symptoms

  2. •

    cannot work because they are self-isolating because someone they live with has symptoms

  3. •

    are self-isolating because they’ve been notified by the NHS test and trace service that they’ve come into contact with someone with coronavirus

  4. •

    are shielding and have a letter from the NHS or a GP telling them to stay at home for at least 12 weeks

The guidance also states that individuals who are required to self-isolate for 14 days in accordance with quarantine measures introduced by the government on 8 June 2020 will not qualify for SSP unless they also meet one of these criteria (see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—sickness absence and pay—Quarantine measures for those travelling to England on or after 8 June 2020).
