STOP PRESS (13/7/20): The Health Protection (Coronavirus, International Travel and Public Health Information) (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/691 were laid before Parliament on 6 July 2020. They amend the Health Protection (Coronavirus, International Travel) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/568 to provide that with effect from 10 July 2020, individuals arriving in England from an exempt country or territory are not required to self-isolate for 14 days. Prior to 10 July 2020, and with effect from 8 June 2020, only those travelling to England from within the common travel area were not required to self-isolate on arrival. The Department of Transport has issued guidance on the countries and territories from where individuals can travel to England without needing to self-isolate on arrival. This Practice Note is currently being updated to incorporate these changes.
STOP PRESS (6/7/20): The Statutory Sick Pay (Coronavirus) (Suspension of Waiting Days and General Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/681 come into force 6 July 2020. They amend the Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894 to confirm that individuals who are shielding in accordance with the newly inserted Schedule 2 will continue to be deemed incapable of work for the purposes of SSP entitlement, and, by amendment to the newly-titled Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, Schedule 1 (Isolation Due to Coronavirus) to deem those who self-isolate pursuant to someone with whom they are in a ‘bubble’/linked household having symptoms of coronavirus, likewise incapable of work for SSP purposes. This Practice Note is currently being reviewed to reflect these developments.
UPDATE (3/7/20): On 22 June 2020, the government announced that advisory guidance for those who are shielding will be eased from 6 July 2020, to allow for gatherings of up to six people outdoors, and the formation of a ‘support bubble’ with another household. Shielding guidance in relation to individuals being advised not to attend their place of work remains unchanged until 31 July 2020. From 1 August 2020 individuals will no longer be advised to shield, and those who cannot work from home will be able to return to work provided their workplace is ‘COVID safe’. Shielding individuals will no longer be deemed incapable of work for SSP purposes after 31 July 2020, which means their entitlement to SSP will cease unless they are ill or self-isolating. See: Shielding guidance and Employees who are self-isolating or shielding in accordance with public health guidance, below. This Practice Note will be updated as further guidance becomes available.

This Practice Note considers the issues that arise in relation to employee sickness absence and pay in the context of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.

Employee sickness absence related to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic can result from:

  1. •

    an employee being unable to work because they are ill (see: Employees who are unable to work because of sickness caused by coronavirus)

  2. •

    an employee self-isolating or shielding in accordance with public health guidance (see: Employees who are self-isolating or shielding in accordance with public health guidance)

  3. •

    an employee self-isolating in accordance with a legal requirement, such as quarantine measures imposed on individuals who travel to England from outside the common travel area (see: Employees who are self-isolating in accordance with a legal requirement)

  4. •

    employees staying away from work on their own initiative as a precautionary measure, eg if they are clinically vulnerable and decide stay at home as a protective measure (see: Employees who are self-isolating on their own initiative as a precautionary measure)

In some, but not all, cases an individual may be entitled to Statutory Sick Pay (SSP) while they are off work. Temporary changes to the rules governing entitlement to SSP mean that eligible employees who are unable to work because they are self-isolating due to coronavirus, and who are not able to work from home, may be deemed incapable of work and entitled to SSP. Given the increase in the categories of those who are potentially required to self-isolate over the course of the pandemic so far, issues of pay and absence management, in particular, have become steadily more acute for both employers and employees.

This Practice Note covers:

  1. •

    public health guidance and legislation in relation to those who are required to self-isolate or shield themselves, including information about the NHS test and trace service and quarantine restrictions on those travelling to England from outside the common travel area with effect from 8 June 2020 (see: Self-isolation)

  2. •

    changes to SSP rules—extending entitlement to SSP to those deemed incapable of working due to coronavirus, allowing SSP to be claimed from the first day of an isolation period, permitting small and medium employers to claim back SSP paid under the Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme (CSSPRS), and providing for isolation notes to replace fit notes as evidence of incapacity (see: Changes to Statutory Sick Pay (SSP))

  3. •

    issues arising from employee absence from work, including payment for employees who self-isolate, in accordance with public health guidance, those who self-isolate in accordance with a legal requirement, and those who self-isolate on their own initiative as a precautionary measure (see: Employees who are self-isolating or shielding in accordance with public health guidance, Employees who are self-isolating in accordance with a legal requirement, and Employees who are self-isolating on their own initiative as a precautionary measure)

  4. •

    the position in relation to sickness absence and SSP entitlement of employees who have been furloughed under the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (see: Furloughed employees)

This Practice Note reflects the guidance and law as it applies in England. For information about the legal position, and guidance, on these issues as applied in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, see:

  1. •

    for Scotland: Coronavirus in Scotland

  2. •

    for Wales: Coronavirus (COVID-19)

  3. •

    for Northern Ireland: Nidirect: Coronavirus (COVID-19)

The situation in relation to coronavirus changes very rapidly. We monitor the position closely and endeavour to update this Practice Note as soon as possible. However, we recommend that subscribers check the following websites regularly for the very latest position and guidance in relation to England:

  1. •

    in relation to self-isolation and clinically vulnerable individuals:

    1. ◦

      PHE: collection of guidance: Coronavirus (COVID-19)

    2. ◦

      PHE: COVID-19: guidance for households with possible coronavirus infection

    3. ◦

      PHE: COVID-19: guidance on shielding and protecting people defined on medical grounds as extremely vulnerable

    4. ◦

      PHE: Guidance for households with grandparents, parents and children living together where someone is at increased risk or has possible or confirmed coronavirus (COVID-19) infection

    5. ◦

      PHE: guidance for contacts of people with confirmed coronavirus (COVID-19) infection who do not live with the person

    6. ◦

      DHSC: Coronavirus (COVID-19): how to self-isolate when you travel to the UK

  2. •

    in relation to social distancing and working safely:

    1. ◦

      Cabinet Office guidance: Staying alert and safe (social distancing)

    2. ◦

      BEIS guidance: Working safely during coronavirus (COVID-19)

For further information:

  1. •

    generally on workplace issues arising during the coronavirus pandemic, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—dealing with issues in the workplace

  2. •

    tracking changes to the various versions of general guidance on coronavirus that has been published, including guidance from Acas, the Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy (BEIS), PHE, the Cabinet Office and HMRC, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—guidance tracker for employment

  3. •

    tracking legislation introduced as part of the government’s response to the pandemic, including a coronavirus SI database collating details of relevant draft and enacted secondary legislation laid in Parliament, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—legislation tracker

An application for judicial review (heard on 11 June 2020) of the government’s decisions to amend the scheme for statutory sick pay (SSP) as a response to the pandemic without including those who are ‘workers’ within the meaning of ‘limb (b)’ of section 230(3) of the Employment Rights Act 1996 (‘limb (b) workers’), raising the level of SSP or removing the lower earnings limit (and to exclude limb (b) workers from the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)), alleging breaches of Article 14 of, and Article 1 of the First Protocol to, the European Convention on Human Rights, indirect discrimination on grounds of sex and race under EU law, and breach of the public sector equality duty, was dismissed by the High Court.

Self-isolation

In order for employers to manage staff absence and other issues relating to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, they need to be fully aware of the relevant legislation and guidance that is in place. This is complex and changes frequently. As noted above, those advising employers should ensure that they are referring to the most up-to-date versions of the legislation and guidance. See Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—guidance tracker for employment.

This section of the Practice Note sets out the guidance in relation to self-isolation, including the requirements in relation to quarantine.

If someone is required to self-isolate, it means that they must stay at home and not go outside their home at any time.

Currently, PHE requires an individual to self-isolate at home if:

  1. •

    they have symptoms of coronavirus (see: Individuals who have symptoms of coronavirus, below)

  2. •

    they live in the same household as someone who has symptoms of coronavirus (see: Those with symptoms living in a household with others, below)

  3. •

    they have been contacted by the NHS test and trace service and informed that they have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus (see: Contacts of someone who has tested positive for coronavirus, below)

  4. •

    they have travelled to England from outside the common travel area (see: Quarantine measures for those travelling to England on or after 8 June 2020, below)

Those who have been identified as clinically extremely vulnerable to serious illness from coronavirus have been advised to take extra precautions to shield themselves from possible contact with the virus (see: Shielding guidance, below).

Symptoms of coronavirus

From 18 May 2020, the most important symptoms of coronavirus are recent onset of any of the following:

  1. •

    a high temperature

  2. •

    a new continuous cough

  3. •

    loss of, or change in, an individual’s normal sense of taste or smell (anosmia)

Prior to 18 May 2020, the symptoms requiring an individual to self-isolate were:

  1. •

    a high temperature

  2. •

    a new and continuous cough

NHS test and trace service

The government has published the following guidance in relation to the NHS test and trace service in England:

  1. •

    DHSC: NHS test and trace: how it works

  2. •

    PHE: guidance for contacts of people with confirmed coronavirus (COVID-19) infection who do not live with the person

  3. •

    DHSC: NHS test and trace: workplace guidance

Similar measures have been implemented in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. For information about contact testing and tracing in:

  1. •

    Scotland, see: Coronavirus (COVID-19): Test and Protect

  2. •

    Wales, see: Test Trace Protect

  3. •

    Northern Ireland, see: Testing and tracing for COVID-19

Unless otherwise stated, discussion of the test and trace service in this Practice Note reflects the position in England only.

The NHS test and trace service was launched on 28 May 2020. The aim of the service is to identify, contain and control localised outbreaks of infection and in so doing, reduce the spread of coronavirus. It aims to do this by:

  1. •

    testing anyone who has symptoms of coronavirus

  2. •

    tracing their close contacts if they test positive for the virus, and

  3. •

    requesting those who have been in close contact to self-isolate for 14 days

For those who need to order a test, this can be done online via NHS.UK, or by calling NHS 119.

A ‘contact’ for these purposes is an individual, including household members, who has been:

  1. •

    close to someone who has tested positive for coronavirus anytime from two days before the person was symptomatic up to seven days from onset of symptoms, and

  2. •

    notified by NHS test and trace that they are a contact of that person

'Close' contact includes:

  1. •

    having face-to-face contact with that person (less than one metre away)

  2. •

    having contact with someone (less than one metre away) for one minute or longer without being face-to-face

  3. •

    spending more than 15 minutes within two metres of someone

  4. •

    travelling in a car or other small vehicle with someone (even on a short journey), or being near to them on a plane

Interaction that has only taken place through a Perspex screen (or equivalent) is excluded from what would be considered as ‘close’ contact.

Individuals who have symptoms of coronavirus

If an individual has one or more symptoms of coronavirus, however mild (see: Symptoms of coronavirus, above), or they have received a positive coronavirus test result, they should start to self-isolate immediately and stay at home for at least seven days starting from when their symptoms started (or until their temperature returns to normal, if that takes longer than seven days).

Affected individuals should not go to a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital. It is not necessary for the individual to contact NHS 111 to go into self-isolation.

The NHS 111 online coronavirus service should be used if:

  1. •

    they feel they cannot cope with their symptoms at home

  2. •

    their condition gets worse, or

  3. •

    their symptoms do not get better after seven days

Individuals should only call NHS 111 if they cannot get help online.

As from 28 May 2020, in accordance with guidance from the NHS test and trace service, any individual who has symptoms should:

  1. •

    immediately arrange to be tested by ordering a test from NHS.UK, or by calling NHS 119 if they don’t have internet access, to find out if they have the virus

  2. •

    while waiting for their test result, consider alerting those with whom they have been in close contact in the 48-hour period before developing symptoms to them to the possibility that they are at risk of having been exposed to the virus. Until the test result is known those individuals are not required to self-isolate, but they should take extra care in following personal hygiene and social distancing guidance

If the test result is positive:

  1. •

    the individual should complete the remainder of their seven-day isolation period (or until their temperature returns to normal, if that takes longer than seven days)

  2. •

    they will be contacted by the NHS test and trace service and asked to share information (such as names and contact details) about those with whom they have been in close recent contact (ie in the previous 48 hours before developing symptoms, and since they developed symptoms), their work environment, and places they have visited where they may have encountered others. This information should be provided online, or, in the absence of internet access, given to a NHS contact tracker, as soon as possible

If the test is negative, the individual no longer needs to self-isolate.

If an individual has previously tested positive for coronavirus, but later develops symptoms again, they must self-isolate for at least seven days from onset of symptoms and be tested. If they live in a household, all other household members must stay at home for 14 days.

Those with symptoms living in a household with others

Current advice for those living in households is:

  1. •

    if they are the first person in the household to have symptoms of coronavirus, then they must stay at home for at least seven days (or until their temperature returns to normal, if that takes longer than seven days). See Individuals who have symptoms of coronavirus, above

  2. •

    all other members of the household who remain well must stay at home and not leave the house for 14 days, starting from the day when the first person in the house became ill

  3. •

    for anyone else in the household who starts displaying symptoms, they need to stay at home for seven days from when their symptoms started, regardless of what day they are on in their original 14-day isolation period

As from 28 May 2020, in accordance with guidance from the NHS test and trace service, the first person in the household to have symptoms of coronavirus should, in addition to self-isolating, immediately order a test from NHS.UK, or by calling NHS 119 if they don’t have internet access, to find out if they have the virus.

If the test result is positive:

  1. •

    they should complete the remainder of their seven-day isolation period (or until their temperature returns to normal, if that takes longer than seven days), and

  2. •

    anyone in their household should continue to self-isolate for a period of 14 days from when the first person’s symptoms started

If the test is negative they, and members of their household, no longer need to self-isolate.

If anyone in the household starts displaying symptoms during their 14-day isolation period, they should arrange to have a test to find out whether they have coronavirus. If their test result is positive, they should self-isolate for at least seven days from their symptoms starting (or until their temperature returns to normal, if that takes longer than seven days) regardless of what day they are on in the original 14-day isolation period.

If their test result is negative, they must continue with isolation as part of the household for the full 14 days.

Contacts of someone who has tested positive for coronavirus

As from 28 May 2020, anyone identified and contacted by the NHS test and trace service as having been in close contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus must stay at home and not leave their house for 14 days, starting from the date they were last in contact with that person (see: NHS test and trace service, above).

If someone has had contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus, but has not been contacted by the NHS test and trace service, they are not a ‘contact’ for these purposes, and do not need to self-isolate, but should follow social distancing guidance.

If the contact lives in a household with other people, those household members do not have to self-isolate if the contact does not have symptoms, but they are advised to take extra care to follow personal hygiene and social distancing guidance.

A contact who does not have symptoms should not seek a test.

Only if the contact develops symptoms of coronavirus while they are self-isolating:

  1. •

    should they should book a test and follow the guidance set out for individuals who have symptoms of coronavirus. See: Individuals who have symptoms of coronavirus, above

  2. •

    are members of their household required to start self-isolating immediately for 14 days in accordance with PHE stay at home guidance

If the contact’s test result is positive, they must continue to stay at home for seven days, or until their temperature returns to normal if that takes longer than seven days.

If their test result is negative, they must nevertheless complete the full 14-day isolation period as the virus may not yet be detectable.

If a contact has previously tested positive for coronavirus and they are notified that they are a contact of someone who has had a positive test result, they must nevertheless self-isolate for 14 days as they may still be capable of transferring infection to others.

Quarantine measures for those travelling to England on or after 8 June 2020

The quarantine, or self-isolation, requirements with which an individual who is travelling to England must comply are set out in the Health Protection (Coronavirus, International Travel) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/568, which came into force on 8 June 2020 and apply in England only. The Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC) has also published guidance for those travelling to the UK on how to self-isolate.

Separate measures apply in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. For information about quarantine requirements in:

  1. •

    Scotland, see: Coronavirus (COVID-19): public health measures at borders

  2. •

    Wales, see: How to self-isolate when you travel to Wales: coronavirus (COVID-19)

  3. •

    Northern Ireland, see: Coronavirus (COVID-19): travel advice

The statutory requirements for a person travelling to England are to:

  1. •

    provide certain personal, journey and contact information on the Passenger Locator Form, and

  2. •

    self-isolate (see details of the requirements, below)

For the purposes of this Practice Note, the requirements relating to self-isolation are set out below. For further information about the requirement to provide information, see: News Analysis: New contact form and self-isolation measures for overseas arrivals from 8 June 2020 (05/06/2020).

From 8 June 2020, any individual:

  1. •

    arriving in England from outside of the common travel area, or

  2. •

    arriving in England from within the common travel area who has been outside of the common travel area at any time in the 14 days before the date of their arrival in England

is required to self-isolate for 14 days, starting from when they arrived in the common travel area. Where an individual is travelling to England for less than 14 days, they will be expected to self-isolate for the length of their stay.

These measures are part of the government’s strategy to prevent a second wave of coronavirus infections, and they apply both to visitors, and to those who are resident in England.

The common travel area consists of:

  1. •

    the UK

  2. •

    the Republic of Ireland

  3. •

    the Channel Islands

  4. •

    the Isle of Man

Anyone arriving in England who is subject to the duty to self-isolate must travel directly to the place at which they are to self-isolate, and must then self-isolate until whichever is the earlier of:

  1. •

    the end of the 14th day after the day on which they arrive in the common travel area, or

  2. •

    their departure from England

They should self-isolate at the address they provided on the public health passenger locator form for the full isolation period (other than in very limited circumstances, where a change of address is permitted). The intended place of self-isolation must be:

  1. •

    the person’s home

  2. •

    the home of a friend or family member, or

  3. •

    a hotel, hostel, bed and breakfast accommodation, or other suitable place

Individuals must not leave, or be outside of, the place where they are self-isolating during the 14-day period, unless it is:

  1. •

    to travel in order to leave England, provided that they do so directly

  2. •

    to seek urgent medical assistance

  3. •

    to fulfil a legal obligation (such as attending court or to participate in legal proceedings)

  4. •

    to avoid injury or illness or to escape a risk of harm

  5. •

    on compassionate grounds (such as to attend a funeral of a household member or close relative)

  6. •

    to move to a different place for self-isolation

  7. •

    in exceptional circumstances, such as:

    1. ◦

      to obtain basic necessities such as food and medical supplies (where these cannot be delivered)

    2. ◦

      to access critical public services (such social services)

    3. ◦

      an emergency

Anyone staying in a household with someone who has recently arrived in England from outside the common travel area does not need to self-isolate, unless they have travelled with that person, or that person develops symptoms of coronavirus, in which case all household members will need to start self-isolating (see: Those with symptoms living in a household with others, above).

Anyone arriving in England who is under the duty to self-isolate, and who develops symptoms of coronavirus during their 14-day isolation period:

  1. •

    should apply for a test to find out if they are infected with coronavirus

  2. •

    if their test result is positive, should share their contacts with the NHS test and trace service so that their fellow passengers can be alerted

  3. •

    should continue to self-isolate at home for not less than the required 14 days in total, even if they have been tested for coronavirus and received a negative result

  4. •

    should self-isolate for at least seven days from their symptoms starting (or until their temperature returns to normal, if that takes longer than seven days) regardless of what day they are on in the original 14-day isolation period.

  5. •

    will need to self-isolate for the required 14 days even if they have had, and recovered from, coronavirus symptoms in this time

  6. •

    can discontinue self-isolation if they arrived in the common travel area more than 14 days ago and have self-isolated for at least seven days from their symptoms starting and their temperature has returned to normal

Individuals arriving in England from within the common travel area, and who have been in the common travel area for the last 14 days before arrival, do not need to self-isolate for 14 days. Others who are exempt from the duty to self-isolate in England are listed in the legislation and Home Office guidance on exempt travellers. They include:

  1. •

    members of diplomatic missions and consular posts, officers, servants or representatives of international organisations, representatives at an international or UK conference granted privileges and immunities, and their families or dependents

  2. •

    Crown servants or government contractors travelling to the UK for essential government work

  3. •

    drivers of goods vehicles

  4. •

    various transport workers

  5. •

    specified seasonal agricultural workers working in edible horticulture

  6. •

    workers with specialist technical skills required for various essential or emergency works or services

  7. •

    various healthcare workers

  8. •

    people who live in the UK, but work in another country and travel between the UK and their country of work at least once a week

  9. •

    people who live outside the UK, but work in the UK and travel between their country of residence and the UK at least once a week

Anyone failing to comply with statutory duty to self-isolate under the quarantine rules may face enforcement action. Contravention is punishable with a £1,000 fixed penalty notice in England or potential prosecution and an unlimited fine.

Shielding guidance

Certain people have been identified as extremely vulnerable on medical grounds to serious illness from coronavirus (Covid-19), and individuals in this group have been advised to take extra precautions to shield themselves from possible contact with the virus. They include:

  1. •

    solid organ transplant recipients

  2. •

    people with specific cancers

  3. •

    those with severe respiratory conditions

  4. •

    those with rare diseases that significantly increase the risk of infections

  5. •

    those on immunosuppression therapies sufficient to significantly increase risk of infection

  6. •

    pregnant women with significant heart disease

  7. •

    others who have been classed as clinically extremely vulnerable, based on clinical judgement and an assessment of their needs

An individual will only fall within this group if they have received a letter from their relevant public health agency (in England, NHS England) advising them that they have been identified as being extremely vulnerable on medical grounds, or they have been told by their GP or hospital clinician/specialist that they are in this group.

Initially, the guidance was that individuals in this group should ‘shield’ themselves by staying at home at all times and avoid any face-to-face contact. In particular, they were advised:

  1. •

    not to leave their house

  2. •

    not to attend any gatherings (including gatherings of friends and family in private spaces), and

  3. •

    strictly to avoid contact with anyone who is displaying symptoms of coronavirus

On 31 May 2020, the advisory guidance started easing in relation to what those who are shielding are advised to do in order to minimise their risk of infection. The advice in the period 31 May 2020-5 July 2020 was:

  1. •

    to stay at home as much as possible

  2. •

    to spend time outdoors for recreational purposes if they so choose, but to keep outdoor activity to a minimum (ie only once a day), accompanied only by household members or one person from another household (ideally the same person each time)

  3. •

    not to enter other buildings, households or enclosed spaces

  4. •

    to take extra care to minimise contact with others when outside, eg by keeping two metres apart

  5. •

    not to attend any gatherings (including gatherings of friends and family in private spaces), and

  6. •

    strictly to avoid contact with anyone who is displaying symptoms of coronavirus (see: ‘Symptoms of coronavirus’, above)

When the shielding guidance was first published, it advised that the shielding period was to be for a period of at least 12 weeks from the date of receipt of the letter from NHS England notifying the individual that they had been identified as being extremely vulnerable on medical grounds. In subsequent updates the guidance confirmed that the shielding measures were to be followed until 30 June 2020.

On 22 June 2020, however, it was announced that the shielding period would be extended until 31 July 2020, albeit with protection advice gradually being eased after the end of June 2020.

Subject to general public health measures being implemented to address a localised outbreak of the virus in a specific location, further steps to relax shielding guidance introduced 6 July 2020 allow those who are shielding:

  1. •

    to meet in a group of up to six people outdoors, including people from different households, while maintaining strict social distancing

  2. •

    no longer to observe social distancing with other members of their household

  3. •

    in line with the wider guidance for single adult households (either an adult living alone or with dependent children under 18) in the general population, to form a ‘support bubble’ with one other household. All those in a support bubble will be able to spend time together inside each other’s homes, including overnight, without needing to socially distance

Leicester is an example of where a localised outbreak of coronavirus has led to a decision not to relax shielding measures in that area on 6 July 2020, as planned (see: DHSC: Leicestershire coronavirus lockdown: areas and changes).

From 1 August 2020, shielding will be ‘paused’ and those who had been shielding are advised, instead, to adopt strict social distancing measures when they go out. This means that, from this date:

  1. •

    they should take particular care to minimise contact with others outside their household or support bubble

  2. •

    if they cannot work from home, they are permitted to go to work—as long as their workplaces are ‘COVID-safe’

  3. •

    they can go out, eg to buy food, to places of worship and for exercise, but they should maintain strict social distancing

  4. •

    they should remain cautious and stay at home where possible, as they remain vulnerable to risk of severe illness from coronavirus

The guidance is to be updated when the changes come into effect on 1 August 2020.

Individuals who live in a household with someone who is shielding do not need to start shielding themselves, but they are advised carefully to follow guidance on Staying alert and safe (social distancing).

Changes to Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)

A number of temporary changes have been introduced by government in relation to accessing SSP, and SSP rules, in response to the coronavirus pandemic:

  1. •

    those who self-isolate or are shielding because of coronavirus are potentially deemed incapable of working, and, therefore, entitled to SSP (see: SSP entitlement extended to those who self-isolate, below)

  2. •

    the rule stipulating that SSP is not payable in respect of the first three ‘waiting’ days of any sickness period has been temporarily suspended with effect from 13 March 2020 for employees whose incapacity for work is related to coronavirus, enabling those who are eligible to claim SSP from day one of a period of entitlement (see: Suspension of waiting days, below)

  3. •

    the Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme, the online service open since 26 May 2020, through which eligible employers are able to reclaim certain coronavirus-related SSP (for further information, see: Practice Note: Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme (CSSPRS))

  4. •

    on 20 March 2020, the DHSC announced the launch of an online service to provide isolation notes for people unable to work for more than seven days because of coronavirus. For the first seven days of illness employees can self-certify, but after that employers may request evidence of illness. The isolation note can be used to provide evidence following the appearance of coronavirus symptoms or if the person in question is living with someone who has coronavirus symptoms. For those who are self-isolating because they have come into contact with someone with coronavirus and they have been contacted by the NHS test and trace service, the notification from the NHS will suffice as evidence, and for those who are shielding, the letter from the NHS or their GP advising them to shield can be used (see: Isolation notes and other evidence, below)

For further guidance on SSP generally, see Practice Note: Sick pay.

SSP entitlement extended to those who self-isolate

In the normal course, one of the essential qualification requirements for SSP is that the employee must be too ill to undertake any work under their contract of employment on any day for which they claim SSP.

However, not all infection or symptoms of illness necessarily render an employee incapable of working under their contract of employment. An employee may, for example, be obliged to stay at home for a period of time if they are self-isolating (see: Self-isolation above) , or if they are shielding. For the purposes of entitlement to SSP, therefore, it may be necessary to consider what a ‘day of incapacity for work’ means.

A ‘day of incapacity for work’ means a day on which the employee concerned is, or is deemed in accordance with regulations to be, incapable by reason of some specific disease or bodily or mental disablement of doing work which they can reasonably be expected to do under their contract of employment.

A person who is not incapable of work may be deemed incapable of work in certain circumstances.

The Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894 have been amended to make provision for eligible employees who are self-isolating or shielding as a result of coronavirus to be deemed incapable of work for the purposes of entitlement to SSP. The amending regulations are:

  1. •

    Statutory Sick Pay (General) (Coronavirus Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/287, which came into force on 13 March 2020 and amended Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, reg 2(1)(c) to extend the deeming provisions to those who self-isolate in accordance with relevant public health guidance

  2. •

    Statutory Sick Pay (General) (Coronavirus Amendment) (No 2) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/304, which came into force on 17 March 2020 and further amended Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, reg 2(1)(c) in relation to the applicable public health guidance under the deeming provisions

  3. •

    Statutory Sick Pay (Coronavirus) (Suspension of Waiting Days and General Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/374, which came into force on 28 March 2020 and, in addition to other provisions, amended Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, reg 2(1)(c) to remove all reference to public health guidance, and instead provide that the deeming provisions would only be extended to those who self-isolate in accordance with the newly inserted Schedule on ‘Isolation due to coronavirus’ (Schedule)

  4. •

    Statutory Sick Pay (General) (Coronavirus Amendment) (No 3) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/427, which came into force on 16 April 2020, and amended Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, Schedule to include those who are shielding

  5. •

    Statutory Sick Pay (General) (Coronavirus Amendment) (No 4) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/539, which came into force on 28 May 2020, and amended Statutory Sick Pay (General) Regulations 1982, SI 1982/894, Schedule to include those who have been contacted and told to self-isolate because they have had contact with someone who has tested positive for coronavirus

In summary: with effect from 13 March 2020, a person who isolates themselves from other people in such a manner as to prevent infection or contamination with coronavirus, and by reason of that isolation is unable to work, will be deemed to be incapable of work for the purposes of claiming SSP (for further information, see Practice Note: Sick pay—SSP—incapable of working), provided that they have isolated themselves in accordance with:

  1. •

    in respect of the period 13–16 March 2020, guidance published by PHE, NHS National Services Scotland or Public Health Wales and effective on 12 March 2020

  2. •

    in respect of the period 17–27 March 2020, guidance published by PHE, NHS National Services Scotland or Public Health Wales and effective on 16 March 2020

  3. •

    from 28 March 2020, the Schedule

The early guidance from PHE was that individuals were advised to isolate only if they had been in contact with someone who had coronavirus, or they had returned from an affected area identified by the Chief Medical Officer as high risk, and they were feeling unwell with a cough, difficulty breathing or fever. Thereafter, the guidance in relation to who is required to self-isolate has changed and evolved over the course of the pandemic. For further information, see Self-isolation, above.

The Schedule echoes current relevant PHE guidance. It confirms that a person is isolating themselves in accordance with the Schedule (and accordingly deemed to be incapable of work for the purposes of claiming SSP) if:

  1. •

    they have symptoms of coronavirus, however mild, and are staying at home for seven days, beginning with the day (‘day 1’) the symptoms started, or

  2. •

    they live with someone who is isolating themselves for seven days on account of having symptoms of coronavirus, and they, accordingly, are staying at home for 14 days, beginning with day 1, above, or

  3. •

    while isolating themselves during the above 14-day period, they themselves develop symptoms of coronavirus, however mild, and they are staying at home for seven days, beginning with the day on which the symptoms started (in which case that seven day period replaces their initial 14-day period), or

  4. •

    (with effect from 16 April 2020) they are defined in public health guidance as extremely vulnerable and at very high risk of severe illness from coronavirus because of an underlying health condition, and they have been advised, by notification sent to, or in respect of, them in accordance with that guidance, to follow rigorous shielding measures for the period specified in the notification

  5. •

    (with effect from 28 May 2020) they have been advised by a relevant notification that they have had contact with a person who at the time of the contact was infected with coronavirus, and they are staying at home for 14 days, starting from the latest date on which that contact occurred, or (if sooner) until the date specified in the latest relevant notification

In relation to those who are shielding, the initial shielding period specified in the notification would have been for a period of 12 weeks, or until the end of June 2020. That period has been extended until 31 July 2020, and those who are on the Shielded Patient List would have received a letter confirming the extension by way of notification for SSP purposes, as well as evidence to their employer that they cannot work outside their home until 31 July 2020 (see: Shielding guidance and Employees who are self-isolating or shielding in accordance with public health guidance, under the heading ‘Employees who are shielding’).

‘Symptoms of coronavirus’, as defined in the Schedule, means the recent onset of:

  1. •

    a continuous cough

  2. •

    a high temperature

  3. •

    both a continuous cough and a high temperature, or

  4. •

    any other symptoms of coronavirus as may be specified by the Chief Medical Officer or one of the Deputy Chief Medical Officers in guidance as amended from time to time

With effect from 18 May 2020, PHE guidance has been amended to include a further symptom of coronavirus, namely: loss of, or change in, an individual’s normal sense of taste or smell (anosmia). See: Symptoms of coronavirus, above.

‘Public health guidance’, as defined in the Schedule, means guidance, as amended from time to time, issued by:

  1. •

    Public Health England

  2. •

    the Scottish Ministers, or

  3. •

    Public Health Wales National Health Service Trust

‘Relevant notification’ means a notification in writing sent to, or in respect of, a person by:

  1. •

    the Department of Health and Social Care

  2. •

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—revisiting financial orders
Nodes.BodyContent:
The coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic is an unforeseen global event that has had significant ramifications for society and the economy. Family practitioners are once again debating, as they did in the wake of the 2007-2008 global financial crisis, whether an event of such magnitude is likely to constitute a ‘Barder event’ in financial remedy proceedings before the courts of England and Wales. This Practice Note re-examines that question at this turbulent and unprecedented juncture. It also considers alternative mechanisms for revisiting financial orders, the Re Barrell and Thwaite jurisdictions, as well as the civil law concept of frustration.

Barder applications

If after a full hearing an aggrieved party complains that the judge fell into error, the appropriate avenue for challenging the order is by way of appeal. If, however, the complaint is not that the judge fell into error but rather relates to an unforeseen event or events that have occurred since the order was made, which fundamentally changes a central aspect of that order, then a so-called Barder application may be possible (per Barder v Barder (Caluori Intervening)).

Such an application asserts that new events have invalidated the basis or fundamental assumption on which the financial order was made, making it appropriate to revisit that order. An application can be made in respect of consent orders as well as orders made after a contested hearing. See also Practice Note: Setting aside financial orders including Barder events where no error of the court alleged.

A Barder application should be made in accordance with Family Procedure Rules 2010 (FPR 2010), SI 2010/2955, 9.9A, which was inserted by the Family Procedure (Amendment No.2) Rules 2016, SI 2016/901 with effect from 3 October 2016. This provides that the FPR 2010, SI 2010/2955, Pt 18 procedure applies to applications to set aside a financial remedy. This includes a Barder application. Pursuant to FPR 2010, PD 9A, para 13.3, where the financial remedy order was made on or after 22 April 2014, an application to set it aside under FPR 2010, SI 2010/2955, 9.9A is to be made to the court that made that order. This reflects the departure from the previous conception of the application as being a species of appeal out of time. It is now clear that applications to set aside all or part of a financial remedy order, including a consent order, should be made to the first instance judge who made the order (if possible), or to a judge of the same level, rather than an appellate tribunal.

Barder provides that a court may revisit a financial remedy order on the ground of new events if the conditions outlined by Lord Brandon (at p495) are satisfied, ie that the court may properly exercise its discretion on the basis of new events provided that:

  1. •

    a new event has occurred since the making of the order which invalidates the basis, or fundamental assumption on which the order was made

  2. •

    the new event occurred within a relatively short time of the order having been made

  3. •

    the application for leave to appeal out of time was made reasonably promptly in the circumstances of the case, and

  4. •

    the grant of leave to appeal out of time (as was the appropriate remedy at that time) does not prejudice third parties who acquired, in good faith and for valuable consideration, interests in property which is the subject matter of the relevant order

This four-limbed test in Barder was considered by Hale J (as she then was) in Cornick v Cornick (No 1), in the context of a change in value of an asset since the date of the underlying order. Of the following three scenarios, only the third was found to potentially give rise to a Barder event:

  1. •

    an asset which was taken into account and correctly valued at the date of the hearing changes value within a relatively short time owing to price fluctuation

  2. •

    a wrong value was put upon the asset at the hearing

  3. •

    something unforeseen and unforeseeable has happened since the hearing which has altered the value of the assets so dramatically as to bring about a substantial change in the balance of the assets brought about by the order

Thorpe LJ observed in Myerson v Myerson (No 2) that ‘very few successful applications have been reported’. This accords with the common view that the gateway for a successful Barder application is narrow. This is unsurprising and perhaps appropriate given the public interest in maintaining the finality of litigation. Myerson was one of a number of cases in or around 2008-2009 where parties advanced the argument that the depreciation of their assets caused by the credit crunch and global financial crisis amounted to a Barder event, and therefore justified setting aside a financial order. In Myerson, the Court of Appeal rejected a Barder appeal brought by the husband where his shares in an alternative investment market (AIM) company fell dramatically from £2.99 per share when the order was made to £0.275 per share at the date of the Court of Appeal hearing. Dismissing the husband’s appeal, Thorpe LJ held that the test established in Cornick clearly pointed to the dismissal of the husband’s appeal, with words (at para [39]) that may seem as much of a warning now as they did in 2008-2009:

‘There may be many who are contemplating an attempt to reopen an existing ancillary relief order on the grounds of subsequently encountered financial eclipse. All in that situation should ponder Hale J’s analytical characterisation and ask themselves whether the events upon which they intend to rely can be brought within either the second or the third category. Even then they would be well advised to heed the warning that very few successful applications have been reported. I echo the words of Hale J that the natural processes of price fluctuation, whether in houses, shares, or any other property, and however dramatic, do not satisfy the Barder test.’

Thorpe LJ also considered that other factors prevented the appeal from succeeding, notably that the husband had elected to carry risk in the hope of reward and that the remaining instalments of the lump sum were variable (at paras [33]-[36]).

Similarly, an application in Horne v Horne was refused by the Court of Appeal, which found that the sharp fall in property valuations and the continued trading losses for the business in question had been foreseeable. Thorpe LJ stated (at para [14]):

‘Looking at the authorities as a whole, given that Hale J’s judgment in Cornick has been consistently approved in later decisions, I can only conclude that the true path to be followed by trial judges is the path set by Barder followed by Cornick.’

The inescapable conclusion is that the threshold is extremely high where the factual matrix concerns value fluctuations caused by market forces.

Is COVID-19 likely to be a Barder event?

There are likely to be many clients who now find themselves struggling to comply with one or more aspects of an order or are reflecting on what now feels like an unfair outcome.

The most likely impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19) seems set to be a significant shift in the value of assets or income. Minor or temporary fluctuations will clearly not be sufficient, nor will those that have occurred as a consequence of ‘normal’ price fluctuations. If there is a significant change, the issue will be whether the coronavirus (COVID-19) will be considered a sufficiently ‘abnormal’ or unforeseeable occurrence so as to lead to orders being set aside. Just as Thorpe LJ’s approach in Myerson, the starting point must be Hale J’s observation in Cornick (at p537) that ‘…once the couple are divorced and their capital divided, they cannot normally expect to profit from, any more than they should expect to lose by, later changes in the other’s fortune’.

Given the courts’ response to Barder applications in the aftermath of the financial crisis of 2007-2008, the question is whether there is likely to be any different response to similar changes brought about by the coronavirus (COVID-19).

While the consequences may be similar, it could be argued that the coronavirus (COVID-19) is in a different category and should be treated as a Barder event on the basis that this is not a foreseeable market disturbance. On the contrary, that these are wholly unforeseeable circumstances which have resulted in unprecedented UK government intervention in individual businesses and the economy more broadly, highlighting the uncomfortable friction between a government which recognises the exceptional nature of the pandemic by intervening directly in public finances at a universal grass-roots level and a hitherto hesitant judiciary which may refuse to accommodate requests to revisit orders made in circumstances which are now unrecognisable. On the other hand, the coronavirus (COVID-19) crisis could be said to be just another event that has triggered a radical shift in the market, valuation, income, etc. It is currently unknown whether the courts will focus on cause or effect. Time will tell whether there will be a policy-level determination by an appeal court in the inevitable test case or if cases will be left to be determined on their individual facts and circumstances.

Consider a long-established business that a trader has successfully run for many years, with no foreseeable threat to continued success. Potential issues to consider include whether the parties should have factored into their negotiations the emergence of a virus that would lead governments to rewrite the rulebook on state control, whether the outcome would be different if a party chose to take on the risk, no doubt in the hope of reward, and whether it would make a difference if dealing with a ‘sharing’ or a ‘needs’ case.

An interesting granular level argument may be the date at which the current lockdown became foreseeable—arguably it took the government a long time to stop public events such as the Cheltenham Festival and the Stereophonics concert in Cardiff on the 15 March 2020. Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—targeted EU banking package
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note summarises the new targeted banking package of measures proposed by the European Commission in April 2020 to address the impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19). The package comprises an Interpretative Communication on the flexibility within EU accounting and prudential rules, and Regulation (EU) 2020/873 which makes targeted amendments to the Capital Requirements Regulation (EU) 575/2013 (CRR) to encourage banks to lend to mitigate the coronavirus’s economic impact.

Background to the targeted banking package

On 28 April 2020, the European Commission adopted a banking package aimed at facilitating bank lending to households and businesses throughout the EU. The package is intended to encourage banks to make full use of the flexibility embedded in the EU’s prudential and accounting framework so that banks can fully support citizens and companies during the pandemic by providing funding. Consisting of targeted ‘quick fix’ amendments to EU banking rules set out in the CRR, as well as an Interpretative Communication on the EU’s accounting and prudential frameworks, the package clarifies how the current rules can be applied more flexibly and in a coherent manner across the EU while ‘maintaining a prudent approach so as to preserve financial stability’.

Commenting on the announcement of the proposed package, the European Commission’s executive vice-president for an economy that works for people, Valdis Dombrovskis, said ‘we are supporting households and businesses as much as we can to deal with the economic fallout of the coronavirus. The banking sector can do a lot to help here. We are using the full flexibility of the EU’s banking rules and proposing targeted legislative changes to enable banks to keep the liquidity taps turned on, so that households and companies can get the financing they need. I will soon also be launching roundtable discussions bringing together consumer and business groups with the financial sector so that we can address the most urgent needs of our citizens and companies.’

The Amending Regulation

The European Commission set out its proposals in April 2020 in a proposed Regulation amending the CRR and Regulation (EU) 2019/876 (CRR II) as regards adjustments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In the explanatory memorandum to the Amending Regulation, the Commission explained that the severe economic shock caused by the coronavirus pandemic and the containment measures were having a far-reaching impact on the economy. While credit institutions are well capitalised and ‘much more resilient than they were in 2008’, enabling them to play a key role in managing the economic shock stemming from the pandemic, the Commission said that uncertainty related to the pace of economic activity would inevitably have an impact on the banking sector.

In order to address the economic impact, in addition to highlighting the flexibility embedded in the existing prudential framework (please see The Interpretative Communication below), the Commission proposed making limited changes to specific aspects of the CRR to maximise credit institutions’ capacity to lend and to absorb losses related to the pandemic, while still ensuring their continued resilience. It also proposed changes to the existing rules in order to reflect changes agreed at an international level by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS) to delay by a year the implementation of the final elements of the Basel III framework and to allow greater flexibility to the phase-in of the impact of the International Financial Reporting Standard 9 (IFRS 9) on capital.

Regulation (EU) 2020/873 (the Amending Regulation) was published in the Official Journal of the EU on 26 June 2020. It entered into force on 27 June 2020, and its provisions apply from that date (except for the amendments relating to the calculation of the leverage ratio, which apply from 28 June 2021).

The main changes introduced by the Amending Regulation relate to:

  1. •

    transitional arrangements for mitigating the impact of IFRS 9 provisions on regulatory capital

  2. •

    the treatment of publicly guaranteed loans under the non-performing loans (NPL) prudential backstop

  3. •

    the date of application of the leverage ratio buffer

  4. •

    offsetting the impact of excluding certain exposures from the calculation of the leverage ratio

  5. •

    the date of application of the exemption of certain software assets from capital deductions

  6. •

    the date of application of the specific treatment envisaged for certain loans backed by pensions or salaries

  7. •

    the date of application of the revised small and medium-sized enterprises (SME) supporting factor and the infrastructure supporting factor

Transitional arrangements to mitigate IFRS 9 impact

IFRS 9 is an international accounting standard which sets out, among other things, how companies should value financial assets such as loans to households or companies, and how they should measure the risk associated with lending. It is particularly relevant to banks.

Transitional arrangements under Article 473a of the CRR allow institutions to add back to their Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) capital a portion of any increase in provisions due to the introduction of expected credit-loss (ECL) accounting under IFRS 9. The transitional arrangements consist of:

  1. •

    a static component, which allows credit institutions to partially neutralise the ‘day-one impact’ on CET1 capital of the increase in accounting provisions introduced by IFRS 9, and

  2. •

    a dynamic component, which allows banks to partially neutralise the impact of the additional (post-day-one) increase in provisions for financial assets that are not credit-impaired

The European Commission was concerned that the application of IFRS 9 during the coronavirus pandemic might lead to a sudden increase in the ECL provision of banks, which would result in an erosion of their capital and therefore their ability to continue lending at a time when businesses and households need it most. To mitigate the potential negative impact of this, the Amending Regulation extends the current transitional arrangements in the CRR.

The existing transitional arrangements cover the period 2018–2022. The Amending Regulation extends that timeline by two years, effectively resetting the transition period so that financial institutions can add back to their CET1 capital during the period 2020–2024 any increase in new ECL provisions that they recognise in 2020 and 2021 for their financial assets which have not defaulted. Only provisions incurred as of 1 January 2020 are eligible, to ensure that the additional relief is related to the exceptional circumstances of the coronavirus pandemic.

The transitional arrangements are extended for the dynamic component only, in accordance with the targeted revisions of the internationally agreed BCBS prudential standards. The BCBS transitional arrangements for ECL accounting are set out at CAP90.7 onwards in the Basel Framework.

Publicly guaranteed loans and the NPL prudential backstop

Although non-performing loan (NPL) stocks remain high in some EU Member States, significant progress has been made in recent years to address this, with banks strengthening confidence in their balance sheets, reducing the level of NPLs and improving operational efficiency. The NPL prudential backstop is a requirement for minimum loss coverage for NPLs, introduced into the CRR by Regulation (EU) 2019/630 to ensure that banks set aside sufficient funds to cover the risks associated with loans that have become non-performing. Under the backstop, NPLs guaranteed by official export credit agencies, which typically issue guarantees on behalf of national governments to provide credit protection for loans used for financing exports, are treated preferentially in respect of the provisioning requirements under Article 47c of the CRR.

The Amending Regulation temporarily extends this preferential treatment to cover NPLs guaranteed by the public sector in the context of measures aimed at mitigating the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic, in accordance with EU state aid rules. This temporary extension recognises the similar characteristics shared by export credit agencies guarantees and coronavirus-related guarantees.

Leverage ratio buffer—date of application

A new Article 92(1a) of the CRR, introduced by CRR II, imposes a leverage ratio buffer requirement on global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs). The date of application of the buffer was originally set to 1 January 2022 (see Article 3(5) of CRR II), but Article 2(2) of the Amending Regulation defers this date by one year, to 1 January 2023, to address the impact of the pandemic and to reflect the revised implementation timeline agreed by the BCBS.

In its questions and answers on the Amending Regulation, the European Commission said it remained committed to implementing the final Basel III standards in the EU, and that it would use the additional time to take the impact of the pandemic on banks’ financial situation into account in preparing the impact assessment to accompany its forthcoming proposal on Basel III.

Calculating the leverage ratio

Banks built up excessive leverage during the years leading up to the 2008/2009 financial crisis, and were forced to reduce that leverage over a short period of time during the financial crisis due to losses and a shortage of funding. This amplified downward pressures on asset prices, causing further losses for banks and, in turn, further declines in their capital. Ultimately, this resulted in less availability of credit to the real economy and a deeper and longer crisis.

To address this, the CRR introduced a new regulatory tool, the leverage ratio, which is a ratio between a bank’s capital and its exposures. Initially, banks were only required to calculate it, report it to their supervisors and disclose it publicly.

CRR II modified the calculation of the leverage ratio, based on the revised Basel standard. The changes CRR II made included implementing a discretion (available under Article 429a(1)(n) and (5) to (7) of the amended CRR) to temporarily exclude central bank reserves from a bank’s leverage ratio calculation in exceptional circumstances. The exemption may be granted by competent authorities for a limited period of up to one year, and any impact of the exemption is fully offset via a mechanism (set out in Article 429a(7) of the CRR) that increases a bank’s individual leverage ratio requirement in a proportionate manner.

The CRR, as amended by CRR II, provides that the discretion and the leverage ratio requirement will become applicable on 28 June 2021. However, the European Commission said the crisis caused by the coronavirus pandemic had shown that the offsetting mechanism (when applicable) would be too restrictive and its application would not actually facilitate an effective transmission of monetary policy (which the discretion is intended to do). Ultimately, the Commission felt the mechanism could force banks to deleverage by selling assets or reducing the level of lending to the economy.

To address those concerns, the Amending Regulation modifies the offsetting mechanism to enhance the flexibility to act appropriately during possible future crises. A bank exercising the discretion would still need to calculate the so-called ‘adjusted leverage ratio’ but (unlike under the existing rule) that calculation would only need to take place once, at the moment it exercises the discretion. The adjusted leverage ratio would not change throughout the full period during which the discretion is exercised.

The Amending Regulation also brings forward the application of several agreed measures that incentivise banks to finance employees, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and infrastructure projects, and to invest in software.

The amendments to Article 429a of the CRR apply from 28 June 2021.

Exemption of certain software assets from capital deductions—date of application

Intangible assets, including software, are generally required to be deducted from banks’ regulatory capital. CRR II changed the regulatory treatment of ‘prudently valued software assets’, which are not materially affected in a gone concern situation (ie the resolution, insolvency or liquidation of an institution), with the aim of supporting the transition towards a more digitalised banking sector. Under the amended rules, banks are no longer required to deduct these particular software assets from their CET1 capital (under Article 36(1)(b) of the CRR). The European Banking Authority (EBA) was mandated (under Article 36(4) of the CRR) to develop a draft RTS to specify how this exemption from deductions should be applied, by defining the scope of software assets to be exempted and how they will be risk-weighted. Under Article 3(7) of CRR II, the revised rules on the treatment of software assets are due to apply from 12 months after the RTS enters into force.

However, in the context of the accelerated uptake of digital services as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, the Amending Regulation brings forward the date of application of the exemption and allows banks to use it as soon as the RTS enters into force.

Specific treatment for certain loans backed by pensions or salaries—date of application

CRR II introduced a more favourable treatment of certain loans granted by banks to pensioners or employees with a permanent contract. This favourable treatment was introduced due to the additional guarantees attached to such loans stemming from the unconditional transfer of part of the borrower’s pension or salary to that credit institution. The revision was due to become applicable on 28 June 2021.

In the context of the coronavirus pandemic, the Commission said the application of this revised treatment would incentivise banks to extend lending to employees and pensioners. On that basis, the Amending Regulation brings forward the date of application of the revised treatment, so that it applies from 27 June 2020.

SME and infrastructure supporting factors—date of application

The ‘SME supporting factor’ is a capital reduction factor in the amount of capital that banks need to hold for prudential reasons in respect of loans they grant to SMEs. It was introduced by the CRR to allow banks to ensure an adequate flow of credit to SMEs. CRR II increased the capital discount for exposures to SMEs (the ‘revised SME supporting factor’), and introduced a new discount on the capital requirements for exposures to entities that operate or finance physical structures or facilities, systems and networks that provide or support essential public services (the ‘infrastructure supporting factor’). These revisions were due to apply from 28 June 2021.

In the context of the coronavirus pandemic, there is an increased need for banks to continue lending to SMEs and supporting infrastructure investments. The supporting factors allow for a more favourable prudential treatment of certain exposures to SMEs and infrastructure with a view to incentivising banks to prudently increase lending to those entities. The Amending Regulation therefore advances the date of application of the two supporting factors, so that they apply from 27 June 2020.

How did the legislative proposal develop?
