Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—business interruption insurance
Nodes.BodyContent:
Business interruption insurance has typically been sold as an extension to commercial property policies. Most business interruption cover requires that any such losses result from damage to insured property. There is, however, no standard form of business interruption insurance and some insurers offered policies with additional triggers for business interruption cover, such as denial of access or closure by a public authority.

Many businesses have sought to claim under their business interruption insurance for coronavirus (COVID-19) losses but few have been indemnified. Aggrieved policyholders have been vocal and the mainstream press critical of the insurance industry’s response. Both have, however, brushed over the complex legal issues that have arisen in the context of coronavirus business interruption, which, unlike conventional perils such as fire or flood, cannot so easily be located at a particular place and time.

Whether a policyholder is entitled to be indemnified for coronavirus business interruption is a matter of fact and policy construction, which are matters for the courts to determine, should the parties be unable to agree. In light of the need to urgently indemnify policyholders with valid claims and the need to protect the reputation of the insurance industry, the FCA, in consultation with policyholders and insurers, has commenced a test case under the Financial markets test case scheme. The test case is being expedited, with the purpose of providing clarity for policyholders and insurers, so that valid coronavirus business interruption claims can be settled as soon as possible. A hearing date has been set for 20 July 2020.

This Practice Note provides information and guidance on coronavirus business interruption claims and the FCA test case in respect of ‘non-damage’ business interruption insurance cover. For information on coronavirus and insurance generally, see: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—insurance considerations.

Property and business interruption insurance

Property insurance for businesses often also provides business interruption insurance to cover insureds who have suffered property damage in respect of loss of profits or higher costs of working resulting from the damage to insured property and consequent repairs. This requires business interruption losses to flow from damage to insured property. It is, however, unlikely to respond to claims from businesses that have closed their doors due to the outbreak or staff shortages.

This will be the standard position, whether the insured business was obliged to close down or whether it did so voluntarily. Accordingly, acutely affected businesses such as in the hospitality and leisure industry may be wholly uninsured in respect of the sudden and catastrophic downturn in business that followed the government’s social distancing advice, which explicitly included avoiding pubs and entertainment venues. Government measures to assist affected businesses are likely only to partially mitigate the impact.

There may be exceptional cases where, for example, contamination of premises with coronavirus might arguably constitute property damage. It is suggested, however, that such cases will be exceptional because the overwhelming majority of policyholders will lack any means to prove that their premises were in fact contaminated by coronavirus and that their losses were caused by such contamination, as opposed to government measures and advice to stay at home.

That the UK government did not immediately impose widespread compulsory closures of business premises is unlikely to be relevant in the context of traditional damage based business interruption cover. While an official instruction to close could be considered a fortuity, businesses would still not be covered under standard property and business interruption insurance because of the absence of property damage.

On 17 March 2020, the Prime Minister and Chancellor said that insurers will make payments to companies that are forced to close as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, if they have policies to that effect. They said an agreement has been reached with insurance companies to ensure businesses receive payouts where appropriate. While it may be expected that the government will encourage insurers to pay valid claims promptly and not to quibble in borderline cases, it is difficult to understand how insurers might be expected to pay claims that they did not insure—which is likely the position as regards holders of standard property damage and business interruption insurance.

For a detailed chronology of the coronavirus pandemic, its impact on the UK, and steps taken by the government in response, see sections D and F of the FCA’s amended particulars of claim in the FCA business interruption insurance test case.

Some policyholders may have paid additional premium for optional policy extensions to standard property and business interruption cover, which may include cover for losses arising out of a notifiable disease (declared by the UK government on 4 March 2020, see: LNB News 04/03/2020 30). Such extensions may cover some policyholders’ loss of profit arising from the coronavirus outbreak but this will depend on the wording of the policy and the factual circumstances. Ultimately, coverage will depend on whether the outbreak and its consequences, in the absence of any property damage, is sufficient to trigger business interruption cover and whether any other policy terms apply. The extent to which ‘non-damage’ extensions will respond to coronavirus business interruption claims is expected to be clarified by the FCA test case.

Physical damage trigger

For policies that require physical damage to insured property in order to trigger business interruption cover, a key question is what constitutes ‘physical damage’ for the purposes of the relevant policy. In many cases ‘damage’ will be defined in the policy. In other cases, where damage is not defined, the question falls to be determined by reference to previous cases.

Blue Circle v Ministry of Defence concerned a pond that had been contaminated by water containing radioactive material. The Court of Appeal held that this did constitute damage to the insured property (the land) on the basis that there was an alteration in its physical characteristics that rendered it less useful or valuable. This was because the radioactive material had intermingled with the land and could not be removed, short of excavating the contaminated soil.

The Court of Appeal in Hunter v Canary Wharf considered dust ingrained in carpet to be physical damage for similar reasons, ie that the insured property had been physically changed, rendering it less useful or valuable.

In both Blue Circle and Hunter the relevant contaminant was intermingled with insured property, which was considered to be physical damage, but these cases may be distinguished from authorities dealing with surface contamination. In Merlin v BNFL radioactive dust that had contaminated only the surface of the insured property was held not to be physical damage. On the other hand, in Losinjska Plovidba v Transco Overseas Ltd, The Orjula [1995] 2 Lloyd's Rep 395 (not reported by LexisNexis®), the Commercial Court held that acid that had contaminated the deck of a vessel did constitute physical damage because the acid had to be removed by specialists.

Coronavirus presents novel scenarios in this context in that it is understood to remain on surfaces for several days, following which the surface will no longer be contaminated. How the authorities fall to be applied may depend on the facts of each case but there are clearly tensions between them. These tensions will need to be resolved by the courts before policyholders and insurers have clarity as to whether and in what circumstances coronavirus contamination may constitute physical damage for the purposes of triggering business interruption insurance.

Contingent business interruption insurance

Businesses that are highly reliant on their suppliers may have insured against business interruption losses arising from damage or incapacity of its suppliers’ premises, ie contingent business interruption insurance. While these policies do not require any damage to the insured’s property the trigger for business interruption cover will usually require some tangible damage to the suppliers’ property. This is not always the case, however, and policyholders should look carefully at the triggers for business interruption cover. In some policies cover may be triggered by suppliers being denied access to premises, which may apply in places where governments have mandated premises to be closed. Accordingly, contingent business interruption policies may not provide cover for loss of profits unless the policy has been extended to cover losses from infectious diseases or is triggered by denial of access to premises (and not otherwise excluded).

Those businesses which do have business interruption cover that responds to losses arising out of the coronavirus outbreak will also have to quantify their loss. This can be complex in ordinary circumstances but may be particularly so in the context of the coronavirus outbreak. This is because the insured business must show that its losses would not have occurred ‘but for’, or, arguably, largely because of, the insured against peril (such as denial of access) in circumstances where its takings would have been substantially reduced anyway for other reasons, such as its customers practicing social distancing. This type of argument was considered in Orient-Express Hotels Ltd v Assicurazioni General SpA (UK) (t/a Generali Global Risk). See also News Analysis: and Coronavirus (COVID-19) and insurance law implications.

Of the policies that are triggered by denial of access or infectious disease outbreak, many will impose a relatively low sub-limit for consequential business interruption losses, however policyholders would still need to establish causation. Coronavirus business interruption insurance causation issues are considered in News Analysis: Proving causation—business interruption insurance coverage amid coronavirus (COVID-19).

The Association of British Insurers believes only a small minority of businesses might have purchased an extension to their cover for closure due to infectious diseases (see: LNB News 17/03/2020 45).

Insurance products providing cover in the event of a pandemic (including parametric insurance) have been available for some years but the take up by businesses was scant.

Coronavirus business interruption litigation

On 22 May 2020, a House of Commons Briefing Paper was published, 'Coronavirus: Business interruption insurance'. This set out demands for government action, the importance of policy wording and continuing disputes, potential legal action and the future.

Policyholders in the UK have commenced legal action against certain insurers in order to pursue business interruption claims. Insurers that have sold policies with denial of access and infectious disease extensions are the primary targets. Hiscox in particular is the defendant in high profile group litigation that is being brought by several hundred policyholders, known as the Hiscox Action Group.

Group actions are also being co-ordinated by industry sector. For example, the hospitality industry is coordinating a group action on behalf of its members (the Hospitality Insurance Group Action). Aviva Insurance and QBE UK have been identified as being the Hospitality Insurance Group Action’s focus. The Hiscox Action Group and the Hospitality Insurance Group are both represented by Mishcon de Reya LLP. Another group, led by the British Dental Association, has instructed Brown Rudnick LLP (see Coronavirus (COVID-19)—dentists raise doubts over scope of FCA test case).

Mishcon de Reya announced on 15 June 2020 that it has also commenced arbitration against Hiscox in respect of its clients’ business interruption losses under policies that are subject to an arbitration clause (see: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—Mishcon launches arbitration claim against Hiscox). The Hiscox Action Group and the Hospitality Insurance Group Action were both granted permission at the 26 June 2020 CMC to intervene and to make submissions in the FCA business interruption test case.

Proceedings by policyholders and industry groups are also underway in other jurisdictions. In the US, various groups of claimants are seeking to consolidate proceedings against insurers in states that may favour policyholders’ interpretation of cover. These actions are taking place against a political and legislative backdrop which is hostile to insurers, with proposals including the imposition of retroactive business interruption cover for pandemics, even where the policy as issued does not provide such cover.

Many US property insurers that are required to cover business interruption losses will have reinsured their property portfolio into the international reinsurance market. As with the direct policies, the affected reinsurance programmes impacted will not have been intended to cover loss of market resulting from the measures imposed to curb the spread of coronavirus. It is nevertheless likely that there will be circumstances in which the property reinsurance market will be required to pay coronavirus business interruption losses. Reinsurance with broadly drafted reinsuring clauses and those with loss settlement clauses that preclude any reopening of the underlying facts will be impacted most.

In other countries, including France and South Africa, some policyholders have succeeded in obtaining favourable court judgments in respect of their coronavirus business interruption insurance claims. These results arose, of course, in the context of different legal systems and on the basis of particular policy wordings and factual circumstances. It is nevertheless interesting to see how foreign courts, particularly common law influenced jurisdictions like South Africa, are dealing with some of the issues that are before High Court in the FCA test case. In Cafe Chameleon CC v Guardrisk Insurance Company Ltd, the High Court of South Africa (Western Cape Division, Cape Town), the judge accepted that there was a clear nexus between the coronavirus outbreak and the government’s response to it, which caused the claimant’s loss. An argument that lockdown measures were only introduced to ‘flatten the curve’ was rejected.

The FCA test case on the validity of business interruption claims

Alongside the policyholder litigation, the FCA announced on 1 May 2020 that it intends to seek legal clarity on business interruption cover to resolve uncertainty as to whether or not policyholders are covered by their business interruption policies. The FCA is seeking to accomplish this by obtaining clarity from the courts in relation to particular key issues that are causing uncertainty.

The FCA’s 1 May 2020 announcement expressly stated that the FCA’s intended action does not preclude individuals and qualifying companies from making a complaint to the Financial Ombudsman Service (FOS). Indeed, a large volume of complaints to the FOS is anticipated. Whatever decision the court reaches in the FCA test case, it will be only be binding on the insurers that are party to it. The result should, however, provide persuasive guidance as to how the courts in other actions, and the FOS, should interpret particular policies, clauses and exclusions. It is unclear how the FOS will respond to business interruption insurance complaints in the meantime (see: LNB News 01/05/2020 35).

On 1 June 2020 the FCA published an update on progress in the test case. In its update, the FCA reported that it has reviewed over 500 policies from 40 insurers to identify a sample of policy wordings that is intended to be broadly representative of the different types of policies in the market that provide some form of business interruption cover. As of 1 June 2020, there were 17 policy wordings in the sample.

The FCA also published an initial list of insurers and the policy wordings they use, together with specimen clauses from the representative sample of policy wordings (see: LNB News 01/06/2020 64).

The FCA has also published finalised guidance for insurers and intermediaries dealing with coronavirus business interruption claims and complaints while the FCA test case is ongoing (see: FCA finalised guidance on the COVID-19 business interruption insurance test case).

The first CMC in the FCA test case was heard before Justice Christopher Butcher on 16 June 2020, pursuant to which the judge ordered that:

  1. •

    the case be allocated to the pilot Financial Markets Test Case Scheme (see The Financial List—starting and transferring claims for more information about the scheme)

  2. •

    the parties must apply for permission to rely on any factual or expert evidence by 24 June 2020

  3. •

    a second CMC to be held on 26 June 2020

Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—intellectual property implications for life sciences companies
Nodes.BodyContent:
Introduction

We are facing a new life-threatening virus, rapidly spreading on a global scale, for which there is currently no effective treatment or vaccine. Thankfully, this crisis has been met by an explosion of innovation and new product development, supported by incredible generosity from pharmaceutical and medical device companies that are pooling their resources, making accessible their relevant intellectual property (IP) and supplying products for free or at cost. While the unprecedented sharing of IP is highly commendable to combat the pandemic, companies should be mindful of the manner in which their IP is protected and shared to avoid potentially adverse consequences to their IP rights and sustainable product development in the longer term.

Companies will also need to be aware that some governments are considering extreme measures such as the use of compulsory licensing to allow third parties to use new technologies while avoiding patent infringement. This is concerning because the erosion of IP protection risks undermining future research and development (R&D) since effective IP protection is essential to secure high-risk life sciences investment. Governments must therefore ensure that any extraordinary measures implemented in response to the pandemic do not compromise the development of future medical technologies.

Legal framework

Companies typically rely on patents for their core IP protection for medicines and medical devices. However, legislators have found patent protection to be insufficient to incentivise the development of medicines for unmet patient needs, necessitating the creation of additional regulatory IP rights. In the EU, these rights include supplementary protection certificates (to partially compensate patentees for the erosion of their patent protection due to the lengthy regulatory approval process), regulatory data protection and marketing protection (to protect the scientific data submitted with marketing authorisations for medicines and to support investments in medicines), orphan market exclusivity (to incentivise the development of drugs for rare diseases) and paediatric rewards (to stimulate and reward for conducting testing in the paediatric population). Medical devices cannot benefit from these regulatory IP rights, but they may additionally benefit from other forms of IP such as patent, copyright and design rights.

Exceptions to patent protection have been built into legislative frameworks for use in cases of national emergency, such as the compulsory licensing of patents in certain circumstances or the ‘Crown use’ exception in the UK. Some countries, such as the UK, have introduced further protective measures for third parties that are looking to rely on coronavirus (COVID-19)-related IP, for example by indemnifying them against third-party claims for patent infringement should equipment made in response to the Ventilator Challenge infringe third-party IP rights.

Faced with a significant global shortage of essential medicines, medical devices (in particular ventilators and incubators) and personal protective equipment, and the necessity to increase the production of those products exponentially, many life sciences companies are taking proactive measures to make their COVID-19-related IP available on a voluntary basis, mitigating against the need for governments to resort to exceptional measures to circumvent IP rights.

Voluntary licences

A number of pharmaceutical companies and medical device companies have already ‘donated’ IP by making the relevant information publicly available, or have offered voluntary licences, on a large scale. For example, Medtronic has publicly posted design specifications for its Puritan BennettTM560 (PB560) ventilator and Smiths Group has provided IP and advice in relation to its paraPAC Plus ventilator to the Ventilator Challenge UK.

We have seen a number of different approaches taken by these companies, ranging from individual company initiatives, to the co-ordinated ‘pledging’ of IP and the creation of broad IP pools. In practice, measures have also included announcements that patentees will not enforce related patent rights and will make available clinical trial data through non-exclusive voluntary licences, appropriate waivers or similar mechanisms. For example, Novartis will make IP from its COVID-19 clinical trials available through non-exclusive voluntary licences/waivers etc and has published a set of compounds from its libraries that it considers suitable for in vitro antiviral testing. AbbVie has announced that it will not defend its patent rights to its drug Kaletra and Gilead Sciences has asked the Food and Drug Administration in the US to rescind the orphan drug designation awarded for its drug remdesivir for the COVID-19 indication.

In some instances, time-limited licences have been granted which will be valid for a set period of years or until a specific event occurs such as the lifting of the World Health Organisation (WHO)’s public health emergency of international concern designation. Some licences have included terms requiring any subsequent modifications to the IP to also be made available under a licence on the same terms, so that new innovation continues to be passed forward.

Companies have also been careful to ensure that trade marks are not infringed and that adequate warnings restricting the use of the product to the COVID-19 pandemic have been included.

Innovators are also being encouraged to share their IP under the Open Covid Pledge, a scheme established by an international group of scientists and lawyers which provides a framework by which companies can freely licence their IP in order to support action against the pandemic. The pledgor will not assert any regulatory exclusivity against any entity for use of the licensed IP in accordance with the licence and will not seek injunctive or regulatory relief to prevent any entity from doing so.

Licensing pools such as the Medicines Patents Pool (MPP) have existed for some time to support low- and middle-income countries. MPP has now expanded its mandate, in collaboration with Unitaid, to include medicines and diagnostics for COVID-19 in their licensing pools. In addition, the President of Costa Rica called on WHO to create a pool of rights to tests, medicines and vaccines for COVID-19, with free access or licensing on reasonable and affordable terms for all countries. WHO endorsed this proposal and, together with Costa Rica, has launched the COVID-19 Technology Access Pool (C-TAP).

The MPP is already gathering patent knowledge for products being used in clinical trials and making it available on its patents and licences database, MedsPaL. Products already included in the database include: remdesivir, lopinavir/ritonavir, favipiravir, and two biologics: tocilizumab and sarilumab. In the UK, the Ventilator Challenge UK Consortium has been established to pool IP, technology, knowhow and resources to respond to shortages of ventilators.

Further, many companies participating in the COVID-19 Therapeutics Accelerator, backed by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, have agreed to share their proprietary libraries of molecular compounds that already have some degree of safety and activity data to quickly screen them for potential use against COVID-19.

Nodes.Title: Impact of coronavirus (COVID-19) on Licensing [Archived]
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note considers the application, scope and limitations of the changes to legislation and practice applied to businesses subject to licensing regimes introduced as part of the Government’s response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic through the Coronavirus Act 2020 (CA 2020) and the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350 and subsequent amending legislation between 26 March 2020 and 3 July 2020. The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (No 2) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/684 came into force on 4 July 2020 and revoked Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350 and subsequent amendments save to the extent provided for in regulation 2(2) in relation to any offence committed under those regulations before 4 July 2020. This content remains relevant as reference point for those offences.

These temporary provisions are designed to ensure the protection of public health by enforcing business closures and other restrictions to ensure social distancing to minimise the spread of the coronavirus.

What legislative changes to the licensing regime were introduced, and when?

The chronology of the government response to the pandemic is set out in full in theCoronavirus (COVID-19)—governance tracker and the Coronavirus (COVID-19)—licensing tracker.

What legal issues arise from the Government’s legislative response?

There are possible evidential issues with the definition of the disease:

  1. •

    what level of ‘infection’ will qualify as ‘infected’?

  2. •

    could there be degrees of infection that would have to be considered de minimis?

  3. •

    when might a person be considered ‘clear’ of coronavirus? and

  4. •

    what would qualify as ‘re-infected’?

The powers relating to events, gatherings and premises are in the following:

  1. •

    powers to issue directions relating to events, gatherings and premises

  2. •

    confers powers to issue directions in relation to events, gatherings and premises

In addition, CA 2020, s 78 contains powers to issue directions regarding local authority meetings. See Practice Note: Local authority meetings during the Coronavirus pandemic.

If, as seems likely, restrictions arising from the current pandemic continue until well into the Autumn (and conceivably, even into next year), then the government will (on medical & scientific advice) continue to experiment with the gradual lifting of restrictions according to:

  1. •

    the number and possibly, age of individuals in premises at different times

  2. •

    the size of the premises and space between individual fixtures

  3. •

    the purpose for which a person is in the premises

  4. •

    the facilities provided by the premises and/or

  5. •

    the period of time individuals might remain within those premises

The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020

Similar regulations have been imposed under powers delegated by sections 45C, 45F and 45P of the Public Health (Control of Disease) Act 1984 (PH(CD)A 1984), and for each of the devolved administrations. For the purposes of this Practice Note, focus is on the English provisions.

The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350 (as amended by The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/447) expire at the end of six months after they come into force (26 September 2020), while restrictions and requirements in the regulations apply from when the regulations came into force, until they are terminated by a direction given under the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350, reg 3 (‘the emergency period’).

There is a requirement on the SoS to review the need for restrictions or requirements every 21 days. The SoS may terminate one or multiple restrictions or requirements in one direction and/or terminate only in respect of specified businesses or descriptions of businesses as and when the SoS considers they ‘are no longer necessary to prevent, protect against, control or provide a public health response to the incidence or spread of infection in England with the coronavirus’.

The first such review removing restrictions was introduced by the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No 2) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/500. Further relaxations came into force on 13 May 2020, 1 and 15 June. Still further relaxations will come into force on 4 July 2020. See movement restrictions section below and LNB News 13/05/2020 4, LNB News 01/06/2020 10, LNB News 15/06/2020 9 and LNB News 24/06/2020 68.

Guidance on the closure of businesses and premises is set out at: Closing certain businesses and venues.

Application of the regulations

The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350 apply during the ‘emergency period’ defined in reg 3 as set out above, in the following circumstances:

  1. •

    premises selling food/drink

  2. •

    businesses in the leisure sector

  3. •

    shops and libraries

  4. •

    holiday accommodation

  5. •

    places of worship and community centres

  6. •

    movement restrictions

  7. •

    gathering restrictions

Food and drink businesses: Scope of the regulations

The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350, Sch 2, Part 1, para 2 sets out the businesses subject to restrictions or closure:

  1. •

    restaurants, including restaurants and dining rooms in hotels or members clubs

  2. •

     cafes, including workplace canteens, but not including—

    1. ◦

      cafes or canteens at a hospital, care home or school

    2. ◦

      canteens at a prison or an establishment intended for use for naval, military or air force purposes or for the purposes of the Department of the Secretary of State responsible for defence

    3. ◦

      services providing food or drink to the homeless

  3. •

    bars, including bars in hotels or members’ clubs

  4. •

    public houses

Similar regulations have been issued (and amended on six occasions) in relation to Wales.

Food and drink businesses: duty of closure

A person who is responsible for carrying on a business listed above must:

  1. •

    during the emergency period—

    1. ◦

      close any premises, or part of the premises, in which food or drink are sold for consumption on those premises and

    2. ◦

      cease selling food or drink for consumption on its premises

  2. •

     if the business sells food or drink for consumption off the premises, cease selling food or drink for consumption on its premises during the relevant period

The intention is to allow such premises to remain open in so far as food or drink is sold only for consumption off the premises.

The person who is responsible ‘includes the owner, proprietor and manager of the business’.

Food and drink businesses: take-away/delivery

Broadly a business selling food/drink for consumption off premises, can allow public access but not to consume food/drink there. However, government guidance requires Public Health Guidelines to be observed, for example on maintaining 2m minimum distances although this will change from 4 July 2020), and cautions against allowing customers to congregate in premises while waiting for food/drink.

A new General Permitted Development regulation (GPDR) enables restaurants, cafés and pubs which do not currently offer delivery and hot food takeaway to do so. However, premises remain subject to the Licensing Act 2003 (LA 2003) and any licence conditions in force when carrying out licensable activities, ie they will still require a licence to sell alcohol and generally need one to sell hot food/drink between the hours of 23:00 to 05:00. See Practice Note: Licensing of alcohol and entertainment and News Analysis: The Pendulum pub licence revoked at summary review hearing for breaking lockdown regulations.

Once food and drink are no longer sold for consumption on premises, the requirement is satisfied. Refurbishments/administrative work in the interim is probably permitted.

Businesses in the leisure industry and other premises

There are 23 categories of business generally covered within the leisure sector, including:

  1. •

    cinemas although this will change from 4 July 2020

  2. •

    theatres

  3. •

    nightclubs

  4. •

    bars although this will change from 4 July 2020 and be permitted limited to table services

  5. •

    pubs although this will change from 4 July 2020 and be permitted limited to table services

  6. •

    bingo halls

  7. •

    concert halls etc

Separate guidance for accommodation providers was published on 24 March, see: COVID-19 advice for accommodation providers.

Businesses in the leisure industry: closure duty

A person responsible for carrying on a business or providing a service which is listed in the Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/350, Sch 2, Pt 2 must cease to carry on that business or to provide that service during the ‘emergency period’ save for the following narrow exceptions:

  1. •

    for specified businesses, such as theatres which can broadcast performances on the internet/radio/TV, and

  2. •

    all these businesses may host blood donation sessions

The requirement is to cease to carry on the business, not necessarily to close premises/refuse entry. For example, if no longer functioning as a theatre, asking employees to do administrative work or refurbishment work is potentially outside of the requirement.

Holiday accommodation and places of worship etc.

Subject to exceptions, ‘a person responsible for carrying on a business consisting of the provision of holiday accommodation whether in a:

  1. •

    hotel

  2. •

    hostel

  3. •

    bed and breakfast accommodation

  4. •

    holiday apartment

  5. •

    home

  6. •

    cottage or bungalow

  7. •

    campsite

  8. •

    caravan park or boarding house

must cease to carry on that business during the ‘emergency period’.

The exceptions include, for example, accommodation for vulnerable persons or for critical workers who are part of the effort to deal with coronavirus whose need for accommodation is connected to their work. This category was extended by The Health Protection (Coronavirus, Restrictions) (England) (Amendment) (No. 3) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/558 from 1 June 2020, to permit those isolating from others as required by law and elite athletes, their coaches and parents if the athlete is under 18 who needs accommodation for the purposes of training or competition. All accommodation restrictions will be removed from 4 July 2020. See: LNB News 24/06/2020 68.

Closures are also forced on Places of Worship, Crematoria (although there are exceptions for funerals, and in the case of Places of Worship, broadcasting of services) and Community Centres. Both Places of Worship and Community Centres may be used to provide essential voluntary activities, urgent public support services (including the provision of food banks or other support for the homeless or vulnerable people, blood donation sessions or support in an emergency and since 1 Jun...

Nodes.Title: Changes to certain requirements for early years providers during coronavirus (COVID-19) response
Nodes.BodyContent:
This Practice Note explains the modifications and disapplications introduced by the Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development and Welfare Requirements) (Coronavirus) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/444 to the Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development Requirements) Order 2007, SI 2007/1772 and the Early Years Foundation Stage (Welfare Requirements) Regulations 2012, SI 2012/938.

The Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) statutory framework sets the standards that all early years providers must meet to ensure that children aged 0 to 5 learn and develop well and are kept healthy and safe. As part of the national response to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, local authorities are undertaking a wide range of essential and additional functions, while also contributing to local resilience planning and continued delivery of local services. This legislation has been introduced to support early years providers to remain open for vulnerable children and the children of critical workers during the present outbreak of coronavirus in England, by ensuring sufficient flexibility in supporting the ability to easily respond to changes in workforce availability and potential fluctuations in demand while still providing high quality and safe care, including through the temporary disapplication and modification of certain requirements in the EYFS statutory framework.

What amendments to requirements for early years providers are introduced by Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development and Welfare Requirements) (Coronavirus) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/444?

The Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development and Welfare Requirements) (Coronavirus) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/444 makes a number of changes to the Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development Requirements) Order 2007, SI 2007/1772 and the Early Years Foundation Stage (Welfare Requirements) Regulations 2012, SI 2012/938 to support early years providers to remain open to vulnerable children and children of critical workers during the coronavirus pandemic, and to ensure sufficient flexibility while still providing high quality and safe care. The changes apply to maintained schools, non-maintained schools, independent schools (including free schools and academies), all providers on Ofsted’s Early Years Register and all providers registered with an early years childminder agency (CMA).

Changes to learning and development requirements

The Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development Requirements) Order 2007, SI 2007/1772, art 3 indicates that reg 2 of the guidance Statutory Framework for the Early Years Foundation Stage specifies the learning and development requirements for early years providers to which they must have regard.

The Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development Requirements) Order 2007, SI 2007/1772, article 3 is amended by the Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development and Welfare Requirements) (Coronavirus) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/444, art 5, which inserts after article 3, a new article 3A being the temporary modification of the learning and development requirements set out in the guidance. According to article 3A, during the ‘relevant period’, the learning and development requirements (prescribed in the Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development Requirements) Order 2007, SI 2007/1772, art 1) are to be treated as discharged as long as a provider uses its ‘reasonable endeavours’ to discharge them. Further, the requirement to carry out a progress check at age two or assessment for the academic year 2019/2020 has been removed.

The relevant period is defined as being between 24 April and 25 September 2020. The Secretary of State is required to review the effectiveness of the regulations before the 25 September leaving the option available for the legislation to be extended if required.

Matters for consideration by early years childminder agencies

The Early Years Foundation Stage (Learning and Development Requirements) Order 2007, SI 2007/1772, art 6A sets out the matters to be considered by the Chief Inspector, which includes any allegation that an early years provider has:

  1. •

    failed to meet the learning and development requirements prescribed in reg 2 of the guidance, or

  2. •

    failed ...

Nodes.Title: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—the pensions implications
Nodes.BodyContent:
Key provisions of the Act

On 25 June 2020, after less than 40 days in Parliament, the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020) received Royal Assent. This Act, which contains far-reaching reforms to UK insolvency law, mostly came into force on 26 June 2020 (subject to paragraph 51 of Schedule 3 coming into force on a day to be appointed).

CIGA 2020 is designed to help companies and other entities stay afloat where they find themselves in financial difficulties as a result of the coronavirus crisis. Among other things, CIGA 2020 includes the following provisions:

  1. •

    introduction of a company moratorium—directors of insolvent companies or companies that are likely to become insolvent can obtain a 20 business day moratorium period to allow viable businesses time to restructure or seek new investment free from creditor action (ie to give the company some breathing space). The moratorium period may also be extended. The moratorium is overseen by an insolvency practitioner acting as a ‘monitor’ although the directors remain in charge of running the business on a day-to-day basis (known as a ‘debtor-in-possession’ process with the company being the ‘debtor’). The moratorium is free-standing; it is not a gateway to a particular insolvency (or any process at all, if the company can be rescued during the moratorium without needing entry into an insolvency procedure)

  2. •

    introduction of a restructuring plan—the restructuring plan closely resembles the existing English ‘scheme of arrangement’ allowing a company to bind all creditors—including junior classes of creditors even if they vote against the plan—through the use of a ‘cross-class cram down’ provision. Such cram down could be imposed provided dissenting classes of creditors are no worse off than they would be in the relevant alternative. The classes of creditors would be proposed by the distressed company on a case-by-case basis. For a class to vote in favour, 75% of a class by value has to agree to the plan. No financial conditions are set in order to qualify for a restructuring plan. This means both solvent and insolvent companies will be able to propose restructuring plans to their creditors

  3. •

    temporary restrictions on winding-up petitions—the government has legislated to temporarily prevent winding up proceedings being taken on the basis of unsatisfied statutory demands and to temporarily stop winding up proceedings where coronavirus has had a financial effect on the company which has caused the grounds for the proceedings. The CIGA 2020 provides that a winding-up petition based on section 123(1)(a) of the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986) (ie an unsatisfied statutory demand in respect of a debt exceeding £750) that relates to a statutory demand served on or after 1 March 2020 cannot be presented by a creditor during the period beginning on 27 April 2020 (it has retrospective effect) until 30 September 2020. More widely, a petition may not be presented unless the creditor has reasonable grounds for believing that: (a) coronavirus has not had a financial effect on the debtor, or (b) the debtor would have been unable to pay its debts even if coronavirus had not had a financial effect on the debtor. The CIGA 2020 makes provision where a winding-up order has been made during the relevant period

For more information, see: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—overview (subscription dependent).

Defined benefit (DB) schemes are unsecured creditors which means that they usually rank at the bottom of the priority order on an employer insolvency, unless they benefit from a contingent asset with a higher priority. In turn, this means they rarely get their deficit paid in full, so that they often end up entering the Pension Protection Fund (PPF).

While the measures of CIGA 2020 are welcome for struggling employers, they potentially limit the options trustees of DB schemes can pursue in the short term to secure the monies owed to them. At the same time, enabling the sponsoring employer to stay afloat will usually be beneficial to the scheme in the long term.

If they haven’t already done so, trustees of DB schemes should review the impact of CIGA 2020 on the employer covenant, the amount they might be able to recover from the employer in the event of an employer insolvency, as well as any contingent asset the scheme might be entitled to.

The changes made by CIGA 2020 are also relevant to any trustee decision concerning a request by an employer to suspend or reduce deficit repair contributions (DRCs)—for more information on such requests, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—the pensions implications for employers—Suspending or reducing deficit repair contributions (DRCs) and future service costs.

The moratorium—pensions issues

While a moratorium is in place, a struggling employer will effectively benefit from a payment holiday in respect of certain ‘pre-moratorium’ pension debts (ie pension debts which fell/fall due before or during the moratorium).

Key points and concerns relating to the moratorium provisions of CIGA 2020 are as follows:

  1. •

    the moratorium will not provide a payment holiday for debts in respect of ‘wages or salary arising under a contract of employment’. ‘Wages or salary’ is defined as including ‘a contribution to an occupational pension scheme’. This means that the moratorium provisions CIGA 2000 will not affect debts in respect of contributions arising under a contract of employment. It seems that contractually agreed DC contributions and DB contributions for future service can be said to be contributions arising under a contract of employment, so that such contributions should continue to remain due during a moratorium provided the scheme is an occupational pension scheme. The Pensions Regulator has certainly taken the view that ‘all contributions due in respect of the company’s employees who are members of any occupational pension scheme must still be made during a moratorium’, but it has not made it clear whether it believes that such contributions include DCRs—see third bullet point below for more information on DRCs

  2. •

    DC contributions to a personal pension scheme could also be said to be contributions under a contract of employment, but contributions to a personal pension scheme do not fall within the definition of ‘wages or salary arising under a contract of employment’. While this may simply be an omission, it leaves us in a position where contributions to a personal pension scheme will be treated as a ‘pre-moratorium debt’ for which the employer will have a payment holiday during a moratorium

  3. •

    in the context of a DB scheme, it is unlikely that DRCs can be said to be contributions which arise ‘under a contract of employment’. It seems more accurate to say that DRCs arise under a DB scheme’s schedule of contributions or recovery plan. It therefore seems that, while a moratorium is in place, a payment holiday will be granted to the employer in respect of the following pre-moratorium pension debts:

    1. ◦

      outstanding DRCs (although the trustees may have agreed, in any event, to suspend such DRCs temporarily as a result of the coronavirus pandemic—see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—the pensions implications for employers—Suspending or reducing deficit repair contributions (DRCs) and future service costs)

    2. ◦

      section 75 debts triggered before or during the moratorium

    3. ◦

      potentially, pension scheme expenses payable by the employer (since contributions covering scheme expenses cannot be said to arise under a contract of employment)

    4. ◦

      contribution notices and financial support directions due to the Pensions Regulator. Indeed, CIGA’s definition of ‘pre-moratorium debt’ reflects the case Re Nortel GmbH (in administration) by making a distinction between provable debts and expenses in administration. Following the Supreme Court’s reasoning, liabilities such as contribution notices and financial support directions under the Pensions Act 2004 should be considered pre-moratorium debts (and, therefore, not payable during the moratorium) even if the request to pay them arises after the start of the moratorium. For more information on Re Nortel GmbH (in administration), see News Analysis: FSD not above claims of other creditors for administration (Re Nortel GMBH)

  4. •

    as the moratorium prevents legal action against the employer, including by commencing a claim or crystallising a floating charge, DB trustees may find it difficult to enforce a contingent asset while a moratorium is in place

  5. •

    a moratorium could be extended by up to 12 months, which means that DB schemes could be left:

    1. ◦

      without DRC payments or scheme expenses for up to a year. This may force DB trustees to divest some of the scheme’s less liquid assets to ensure they can meet cash flow requirements. If a moratorium is extended, a review of the scheme’s investment strategy and statement of investment principles may be in order, and

    2. ◦

      unable to recover existing pension debts or enforce any contingent asset for up to a year. Again, this may put the scheme in a precarious position if the moratorium leads to an employer insolvency, as the moratorium will have left the trustees unable to reduce the size of the pension debt before the employer enters insolvency

  6. •

    CIGA 2020 contains a power to make regulations amending the types of debts for which there will be no payment holiday during a moratorium. It is to be ...
