Nodes.Title: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—Planning
Nodes.BodyContent:
The impact of Coronavirus (COVID-19) measures on national and local planning services could cause delay in respect of planning applications, publicity of planning and compulsory purchase documentation, appeals and court proceedings. This Practice Note looks at the impact of coronavirus for the Planning Inspectorate (PINS), local planning authorities (LPAs), developers, the house-building sector, acquiring authorities, the courts and Parliament.

Planning decision-making

The Local Authorities and Police and Crime Panels (Coronavirus) (Flexibility of Local Authority and Police and Crime Panel Meetings) (England and Wales) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/392, made under section 78 of the Coronavirus Act 2020, enable English local authority meetings to be held virtually for a temporary period to 7 May 2021. This allows planning committee and other important council meetings to continue remotely and be remotely attended by members of local authorities, the public and the press. The regulations also enable English local authorities to hold and alter the frequency and occurrence of meetings without requirement for further notice. Existing legislative requirements for English local authority meetings are also disapplied.

Guidance published by the Ministry of Housing, Communities & Local Government (MHCLG) on 13 May 2020 (the 13 May MHCLG Guidance) urges English LPAs to take advantage of these powers to hold virtual planning committees—rather than deferring committee dates—and also consider using ‘urgency powers’ within their constitutions to give senior officers delegated authority to make decisions. MHCLG is working with the Planning Advisory Service to provide practical advice to LPAs through on-line guidance and web-based training on how to manage planning committees and continue decision-making.

In Wales, the Local Authorities (Coronavirus) (Meetings) (Wales) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/442 enable Welsh LPAs’ meetings to be held remotely up to 1 May 2021 and for their frequency and occurrence to be altered.

On 24 March 2020, the Chief Planner, Steve Quartermain, wrote to chief planning officers of LPAs in England, providing information on the coronavirus position (the Chief Planner’s letter). 

In respect of decision-making, the Chief Planner’s letter stresses the need for LPAs to continue to process planning application and provide the best service possible, especially where the decisions will support the local economy. It encourages LPAs to:

  1. •

    be pragmatic and continue, as much as possible, to work proactively with applicants and others, where necessary agreeing extended periods for making decisions

  2. •

    take an innovative approach, recognising that, while face-to-face events and meetings may have to be cancelled, technology should be used where possible to ensure that discussions and consultations can go ahead

  3. •

    consider delegating committee decisions where appropriate

  4. •

    prioritise permitted development prior approval applications where possible and if necessary, seek to agree an extended approval date with the applicant. Where agreement cannot be reached, the LPA may need to consider whether prior approval should be refused if the application cannot be considered with the requisite attention

Much of this has been overtaken by the 13 May MHCLG Guidance.

Validation of applications

The 13 May MHCLG Guidance advises English LPAs to encourage all planning applications to be made online to avoid the need for staff to work in the office. This should continue to enable the remote processing of planning applications to continue as far as possible to support the latest social distancing guidelines. LPAs should make this clear on their websites and contact local agents to inform them that applications should be submitted online. However, the guidance emphasises that arrangements are in place to ensure paper applications can still be validated. Priority should continue to be given to the validation of any urgent coronavirus-related applications for planning permission and associated consents, including hazardous substance consents, where statutory consultees if necessary, should be contacted immediately.

Publicity and consultation for planning applications

On 14 May 2020, the Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure, Listed Buildings and Environmental Impact Assessment) (England) (Coronavirus) (Amendment) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/505 (the 2020 Regulations) came into force. The 2020 Regulations, expiring on 31 December 2020, supplement the existing statutory publicity arrangements in England for planning applications, listed building consent applications and environmental statements for environment impact assessment (EIA) development in response to coronavirus. They amend, on a temporary basis, certain requirements placed on LPAs and applicants for development requiring an environmental impact assessment (EIA) for publicity and inspection of documents where the authority or applicant is not able to comply with a particular requirement because it is not reasonably practicable to do so for reasons connected to the effects of coronavirus, including restrictions on movement.

Under the 2020 Regulations, LPAs (and applicants of EIA development under the TCPA) in England have the flexibility to take other reasonable steps to publicise applications if they cannot discharge the specific requirements for site notices, neighbour notifications or newspaper publicity because of the impacts of coronavirus. The LPA, or in the case of EIA development, the applicant, must take reasonable steps to communicate the notice to people who are likely to have an interest in a planning application/listed building application/EIA development, including people who live or work in, or otherwise have a direct connection with, the area in which the proposed development is located. The reasonable steps that an LPA/applicant must take may include use of social media and communication by other electronic means, and must be proportionate to the scale and impact of the development. The requirement for physical inspection of documents is disapplied where LPAs can no longer do so safely, and instead, documents need to be made available online. In respect of EIA development, the requirement to ensure copies of an environmental statements at a named address is removed, and instead, an applicant must by electronic notice publicise where the environmental statement is available online. The minimum consultation period, during which members of the public can submit representations in respect of a planning applications, is also extended from 14 to 21 days.

Planning Practice Guidance (PPG) has been updated to provide a summary of the changes introduced by the 2020 Regulations. It provides guidance on how LPAs and applicants can comply with the 2020 Regulations and best publicise planning applications where it is not possible to comply with requirements for site notices, neighbour notifications, newspaper publicity or physical inspection of documents. Specifically, it provides guidance on: what forms of electronic communication might be appropriate, what LPAs can do to make their online planning register more accessible (in the absence of putting planning documentation out for physical inspection), how an LPA should determine which people have to be notified electronically and what issues an LPA should consider in ensuring the reasonable steps they take are proportionate to the scale and impact of the development.

For more detail, see News Analysis: Planning publicity and consultation in the wake of the coronavirus (COVID-19) restrictions.

Determination timescales

The 13 May MHCLG Guidance also clarified that the government in England does not intend to change the determination timescales for planning applications set out in the Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (England) Order 2015, SI 2015/595, but acknowledged that timescales may not be met in all cases. Developers are encouraged to agree extensions of time where necessary, but retaining the timescales means there is still the option to appeal to the Secretary of State on the grounds of non-determination.

Wales—planning policy priorities post-coronavirus

In July 2020, the Welsh Government published ‘Building Better Places: The Planning System Delivering Resilient and Brighter Futures’, which sets out the Welsh Government’s planning policy priorities to assist in taking action in the recovery period after the coronavirus pandemic crisis. It highlights the key existing planning policies and tools which should be used by all sectors in the environmental, social, cultural and economic recovery of Wales, recognising the continuing need for planners to operate within a wider context of priorities and action at all scales. Key proposals addressed in the document include:

  1. •

    boosting digital services in areas where current provision is poor to ensure everybody in Wales can stay connected; and making sure well-designed communities can reap the benefits of home working, which include reduced traffic and cleaner air

  2. •

    creating mixed use, sustainable communities with a mixture of housing (include social housing) and services

  3. •

    capturing active travel opportunities

  4. •

    revitalising town centres by creating flexible town centre buildings and making the most of outdoor space opportunities

  5. •

    reopening the tourism and sector and providing guidance on readjusting to social distancing

  6. •

    ensuring access to green spaces and opportunities to connect with the natural and historic environment, and

  7. •

    improving air quality and soundscapes for better health and well-being

See: LNB News 16/07/2020 68.

Developments of national significance/major development in Wales

The Planning Applications (Temporary Modifications and Disapplication) (Wales) (Coronavirus) Order 2020, SI 2020/514 (the TMD Wales Amendment Order), which came into force on 19 May 2020, made changes to the Town and Country Planning (Development Management Procedure) (Wales) Order 2012, SI 2012/801 (DMPWO) and the Developments of National Significance (Procedure) (Wales) Order 2016, SI 2016/55 (DNSPWO) in response to the challenges presented by coronavirus. The changes aim to enable the pre-application consultation process and the subsequent submission of planning applications for major development to continue.

Planning applications for major development

‘Major development’ is defined in article 2 of the DMPWO. The TMD Wales Amendment Order provides that:

  1. •

    the requirement in article 2C(1) of the DMPWO to make information available for inspection at a location in the vicinity of the proposed development is removed for applications made during the period beginning with 19 May 2020 and ending with 18 September 2020. Instead, developers must make all the information available on a website and send hard copies of the documents to any person who requests it. If hard copies are requested, an application must not be submitted before the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the last document is sent. The requisite notice in Schedule 1D of the DMPWO that contains the information that must contain in any notice placed on or near the land to which the proposed application relates and sent to owners and occupiers of adjoining land has also been amended to reflect these changes

  2. •

    where community consultation has been completed prior to local premises having closed, and all other consultation requirements have been complied with, the subsequent planning application can be submitted to the LPA. Where the community consultation was incomplete when premises were required to close, that consultation should restart from the beginning. All requisite notices must be re-served and contain the updated information in Schedule 1D of the DMPWO

  3. •

    Article 2F of the DMPWO sets out what must be included in a pre-application consultation report, to be submitted with a planning application. This includes a declaration of the notice given about the consultation undertaken. The TMD Wales Amendment Order requires developers to declare that the prescribed information was made available on a website in accordance with the requirements, whether hard copies were requested and that such copies were supplied. The revised consultation arrangements will continue to apply to pre-application community consultations where at least one of the notice requirements in articles 2C(1)(a) and 2D(2) is given before 18 September 2020

  4. •

    developers and agents are expected to expand use of social media and other online services during this time to widen public engagement with the consultation process

See News Analysis: Planning publicity and consultation in the wake of the coronavirus (COVID-19) restrictions.

Site Notices

A letter from the Welsh Government notifying developers of the changes under the TMD Wales Amendment Order confirms that the requirement for the display of site notices under the DMPWO and DNSPWO remains in place. The display of a site notice is an activity that cannot be undertaken from home so is a reasonable excuse for the purpose of the Health Protection (Coronavirus Restrictions) (Wales) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/353.

Developments of National Significance

The TMD Wales Amendment Order temporarily removes article 12(5)of the DNSPWO for applications made during the period beginning with 19 May 2020 and ending with 18 September 2020, meaning that where an application for a development of national significance has been submitted electronically, there is no longer a requirement for a hard copy to be deposited with the Welsh Ministers and the LPA. See News Analysis: Planning publicity and consultation in the wake of the coronavirus (COVID-19) restrictions.

Temporary automatic extensions of planning consents in England

The Business and Planning Bill, introduced to Parliament on 25 June 2020, provides for the commencement period of certain unimplemented planning permissions and listed building consents in England to be extended, automatically in most cases, but on a temporary basis.

The Bill proposes to ensure that planning permission granted or deemed to be granted in relation to development of land in England, which is subject to a condition that the development to which the permission relates must be begun not later than a time falling within the period of the day on which clause 17 of the Bill comes into force, and ending with 31 December 2020, is instead deemed to be subject to a condition that the development to which the permission relates must be begun not later than 1 April 2021. The Bill will have the same effect in respect of a planning permission where the time limit for commencement expired between 23 March 2020 and the date on which clause 17 of the Bill comes into force, if an ‘additional environmental approval’ is granted or deemed to be granted in relation to that permission. An environmental approval can be granted on an application if either the development does not contain any development for which an environmental impact assessment (EIA) is required, or the development remains the subject of an up-to-date EIA, and if either the development would not require a habitats regulation assessment (HRA) or the development was previously subject to a HRA which ascertained that the development would not adversely affect the integrity of a European site or European offshore marine site, and which remains up-to-date.

Similar provisions are to be applied in respect of:

  1. •

    outline planning permissions granted or deemed to be granted in relation to development of land in England, which are subject to a condition that an application for approval of a reserved matter must be made not later than a time falling within the period beginning with 23 March 2020, and ending with 31 December 2020, so that such consents are instead deemed to be subject to a condition that the application for approval of that reserved matter must be made not later than 1 April 2021. Where they are also subject to a condition that they must be implemented between the day on which clause 18 of the Bill comes into force and 31 December 2020, they are instead deemed to be subject to a condition that the development to which the permission relates must be begun not later than 1 April 2021. If instead they are subject to a condition that they must be implemented between 23 March 2020 and the date on which clause 18 of the Bill comes into force, they are instead deemed to be subject to a condition that the development to which the permission relates must be begun not later than 1 April 2021 if an ‘additional environmental approval’ is granted or deemed to be granted in relation to that permission

  2. •

    listed building consents granted or deemed to be granted in relation to a building in England which are subject to a condition that the works must be begun not later than a time falling within the period beginning with 23 March 2020 and ending with 31 December 2020, so that such consents are instead deemed to be subject to a condition that the works to which the consent relates must be begun not later than 1 April 2021

For more detail, see News Analysis: Planning reforms for England in the Business and Planning Bill 2019–21.

Planning appeals

PINS has published guidance in response to the spread of coronavirus, which is updated regularly. It contains the latest information on changes to normal appeal procedure in light of changing government advice on coronavirus. Parties to an appeal should check this guidance regularly and can contact their case officer for urgent enquiries.

On 24 March 2020, PINS announced that it had cancelled all previously arrange site visits with immediate effect. Additionally, there were no PINS staff working in the Bristol or Cardiff offices until further notice. In light of this, PINS requested that copies of appeal forms or supportive evidence are not sent via post and are instead submitted via the appeals casework portal.

On 13 May 2020, PINS outlined plans to restart site visits and an update on the work to implement digital events:

  1. •

    site visits—as confirmed in the written ministerial statement published on 13 May 2020, PINS intends to begin to visit sites, subject to certain conditions, including that the inspector can visit the site safely under current physical distancing guidance and the case requires the inspector to visit the site in person in order to progress the case. It notes that, in some instances, cases can be progressed without a site visit

  2. •

    digital events—PINS is trialling the holding of local plan hearing sessions as digital events (by video/telephone conference) and, if the pilot is successful, aims to be able to offer this, where possible, for all current examinations

The Business and Planning Bill also proposes to amend the power for the Secretary of State in England to determine which appeal procedure (written representations, a hearing or a local inquiry) should be adopted to enable a more flexible deployment of one or more of the three types of procedure. Once enacted, the Secretary of State will be able to chose that a particular appeal or application should follow one or more of the procedures rather than just one. For example, an appeal or application can proceed in part by hearing and in part by written representations. This is intended to be a permanent change to provide operational efficiencies to the work of PINS. For more detail, see News Analysis: Planning reforms for England in the Business and Planning Bill 2019–21.

Permitted development

England

On 17 March 2020, the Communities Secretary announced that, in light of the coronavirus outbreak, the government would set out measures so that pubs and restaurants can operate as hot food takeaways to serve people having to stay at home. On 24 March 2020, a new Class DA was inserted into the The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 2015 (the English GPDO), SI 2015/596, Sch 2 Pt 4, to allow the temporary change of use the English GPDO, SI 2015/596, Sch 2 Pt 4, Class DA of a pub (A4—drinking establishment) and a restaurant/café (A3—restaurants and cafes) to provide a takeaway or delivery service for hot or cold food which has been prepared for consumers, for collection or delivery, to consumed, reheated or cooked by consumers off the premises. This right is subject to certain conditions, including:

  1. •

    the right will cease to have effect from 23 March 2021; premises may operate as a use under the English GPDO, SI 2015/596, Sch 2 Pt 4, Class DA only up to that date

  2. •

    the developer must notify the LPA if the building and any land within its curtilage is being/will be used, for the provision of takeaway food at any time during the relevant period

  3. •

    change of use to the provision of takeaway food under Class DA does not affect the Use Class which the building and any land within its curtilage had before the change of use, and

  4. •

    if the developer changes use to the provision of takeaway food under Class DA during the period ending on 23 March 2021, the use of the building and any land within its curtilage reverts to its previous lawful use at the end of this period or, if earlier, when the developer ceases to provide takeaway food under Class DA

Article 4 of the English GPDO does not apply, so an LPA cannot disapply the new class of permitted development rights.

Additionally, the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Coronavirus) (England) (Amendment) Order 2020, SI 2020/412, in force from 9 April 2020, inserted a new Part 12A in Schedule 2 to the English GPDO. The new Part 12A is to enable English LPAs and certain health service bodies to carry out development on land owned, leased, occupied or maintained by them for the specific purposes of:

  1. •

    (a) preventing an emergency

  2. •

    (b) reducing, controlling or mitigating the effects of an emergency, or

  3. •

    (c) taking other action in connection with an emergency

This is subject to conditions, including:

  1. •

    if the developer is not also the LPA, the developer must notify the LPA of that development, and

  2. •

    any use of the land must cease on or before 31 December 2020, and

  3. •

    on or before the expiry of the period of 12 months beginning with the date which the use of the land ceases for the purpose of this new right:

    1. ◦

      any building, works, plant, machinery, structure and erection permitted must be removed, and

    2. ◦

      the land must be restored to its condition before the development took place, or, if the developer is not also the LPA, to such other state as may be agreed in writing between the LPA and the developer

The explanatory memorandum notes that this new temporary permitted development right will help LPAs and health service bodies bring forward a range of new use and additional facilities, including hospitals, health facilities, testing centres, coroner facilities, mortuaries, accommodation, and for storage and distribution including for community food hubs.

Further, the Town and Country Planning (Permitted Development and Miscellaneous Amendments) (England) (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020, SI 2020/632 introduce two new temporary permitted development rights which apply on a temporary basis:

  1. •

    a new Class BA to Part 4 of Schedule 2 to the English GPDO, which permits the use of any land for any purposes for up to 28 days in total during the period from 1 July 2020 to 31 December 2020, of which up to 14 days in total may be for the purposes of the holding of a market or motor car and motorcycle racing. The provision on the land of any moveable structures required for the use of the land is also allowed, although there are certain exceptions, for example, land which falls within the curtilage of a listed building cannot be used for these purposes

  2. •

    a new Class BA to Part 12 of Schedule 2 to the English GPDO, which allows, at any time from 25 June 2020 to 23 March 2021, any land to be used for the holding of a market by or on behalf of a local authority, and the provision on the land of any moveable structure for that use

For more detail, see News Analysis: English permitted development rights changed to permit upwards extensions and require adequate light in house conversions.

Wales

The Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Amendment) (Wales) Order 2020, SI 2020/367, in force from 30 March 2020, inserted a new Part 12A in Schedule 2 to the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order 1995, SI 1995/418 (the Welsh GPDO). The aim of Welsh GPDO, SI 1995/418, Sch 2 Pt 12A, Class A is to enable Welsh LPAs to carry out development for specified purposes on their land in an emergency. For these purposes an emergency is an event or situation which threatens serious damage to human welfare in a place in the UK. The development permitted is for the purposes of:

  1. •

    (a) preventing an emergency

  2. •

    (b) reducing, controlling or mitigating the effects of an emergency, or

  3. •

    (c) taking other action in connection with an emergency

This is subject to conditions, including:

  1. •

    if the developer is not also the LPA, the developer must notify the LPA of that development, and

  2. •

    on or before the expiry of the period of 12 months beginning with the date on which the development began:

    1. ◦

      any use of that land for a purpose of Class A must cease and any buildings, plant, machinery, structures and erections permitted by Class A must be removed, and

    2. ◦

      the land must be restored to its condition before the development took place, or to such other state as may be agreed in writing between the LPA and the developer

The aim of Welsh GPDO, SI 1995/418, Sch 2 Pt 12A is to enable, for instance, buildings such as leisure centres to be used for the purpose of hospital care, without requiring the LPA to apply for planning permission to carry out such development. A letter from the Minister for Finance and Trefnydd explains that, in view of the circumstances surrounding coronavirus, which falls in the category of an ‘emergency’ for the purposes of the Order and its fast-moving nature, not adhering to the 21-day rule is thought necessary and justifiable in this case.

Additionally, the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (Amendment) (No 2) (Wales) Order 2020, SI 2020/420, in force from 10 April 2020, inserted a new Class A, Part 3A in Schedule 2 to the Welsh GPDO. Welsh GPDO, SI 1995/418, Sch 2 Pt 3A, Class A permits development undertaken by or on behalf of an NHS body, comprising:

  1. •

    the change of use of a building or land to Class C2 (residential institutions) or Class D1 (non-residential institutions), and

  2. •

    the provision of buildings or other structure

  3. •

    for the purposes of preventing, controlling or mitigating the effects of, or taking other action in connection with a public health emergency in the UK (defined as an event or situation which threatens serious damage to human welfare in a place in the UK, where an event or situation is taken to threaten damage to human welfare only if it involves, or causes/may cause, loss of human life, human illness or injury or disruption of services relating to health)

Welsh GPDO, SI 1995/418, Sch 2 Pt 3A, Class A is subject to conditions, including:

  1. •

    if the developer is not also the LPA, the developer must notify the LPA of that development, and

  2. •

    on or before the expiry of the period of 12 months beginning with the date on which the development began:

    1. ◦

      any use of that land for a purpose of Class A must cease and any buildings, moveable structures, works, plants and machinery permitted by Class A must be removed, and

    2. ◦

      the building or land must be restored to its condition before the development took place, or to such other state as may be agreed in writing between the LPA and the developer

Pavement licences in England

The Business and Planning Bill proposes to create a new streamlined procedure to allow businesses selling food and drink such as cafes, pubs and restaurants to apply to the local authority (LA) for a temporary pavement licence allowing them to put furniture such as tables and chairs outside on the highway for their customers to consume their food and drink. In addition to a pavement licence, some LPAs require the business to also apply for planning permission on the basis that putting tables and chairs on the highway is a change of use of the land. The Bill provides that where a temporary pavement licence is granted, any necessary planning permission is automatically deemed to have been granted. This is a bespoke procedure, outside of the existing procedures under the Highways Act 1980 and other local acts such as the London Local Authorities Act 1990.

For more detail, see News Analysis: Planning reforms for England in the Business and Planning Bill 2019–21.

Planning conditions and enforcement

Delivery hours of supermarkets in England

On 13 March 2020, the Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick published a Written Ministerial Statement on the ‘urgent matter’ of enabling retailers of food, sanitary and other essential items to increase the frequency of deliveries to their stores to support the response to the coronavirus outbreak in England.

Currently, many supermarkets, food retailers and distribution centres in England are subject to planning conditions, which restrict the time and number of deliveries from lorries and other delivery vehicles, particularly at night. Nodes.Title: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—progress tracker
Nodes.BodyContent:
The Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill represents the biggest change to the UK’s insolvency framework in 20 years.

The overarching objective of the Bill is to provide businesses with the flexibility and breathing space they need to continue trading during the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The measures are designed to help UK companies and other similar entities by easing the burden on businesses and helping them avoid insolvency during this period of economic uncertainty.

The Bill is a combination of reactionary, temporary measures designed to help businesses survive the coronavirus pandemic, and permanent measures which were formulated as a result of the Insolvency and Corporate Governance consultation that culminated with the government’s response in 2018 (see News Analysis: Exploring the government’s response to the insolvency and corporate governance consultation).

We set out below the progress of the Bill as it makes it through the parliamentary process.

Nodes.Title: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—temporary changes to the wrongful trading regime
Nodes.BodyContent:
What is the background to the changes to the wrongful trading regime?

The coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and the corresponding public health response has resulted in an economic crisis both globally and in the UK. On 20 March 2020, the government announced that businesses including restaurants, pubs and leisure centres must close, and on 23 March 2020 a full lockdown was introduced, sending huge parts of the private sector into hibernation. As lockdown is eased and replaced by social distancing measures, many businesses continue to face financial pressures and uncertainty.

In order to mitigate the economic consequences and keep the economy on life support, the government has already introduced a range of measures, from financial support initiatives to legislative reform. For further details of the financial support available, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19)—summary of government support.

Directors of companies in financial difficulties are presented with many practical and legal concerns, including the risk of personal liability. One of the key concerns for directors is usually the threat of liability for wrongful trading under section 246ZB of the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986) (in the context of insolvent administration) and IA 1986, s 214 (in the context of insolvent liquidation). While there is no offence of trading while insolvent under English law, directors and shadow directors of a company that goes into insolvent administration or insolvent liquidation can be liable to make a personal contribution to the company’s assets where wrongful trading has occurred.

The wrongful trading regime

Essentially a wrongful trading claim arises where:

  1. •

    at some time before the commencement of the company’s administration or liquidation, the director knew or ought to have concluded that there was no reasonable prospect of the company avoiding insolvent liquidation or administration, and

  2. •

    from that point, the director failed to take every step with a view to minimising the further potential loss to the company’s assets/creditors

If a director is found liable, they can be ordered to make a contribution which generally reflects the increase in the company’s net deficiencies (ie losses to creditors as a whole) that the company incurred during the period of wrongful trading (ie from the point at which the directors concluded or ought to have concluded there was no reasonable prospect of avoiding insolvent administration or liquidation to the point of the actual insolvency). This is subject to the statutory defence of taking every step with a view to minimising losses. For further reading on the wrongful trading regime, see Practice Note: Wrongful trading claims under sections 214 and 246ZB of the Insolvency Act 1986.

There is no requirement to show that the company actually traded during this period (provided that losses are increasing), nor is the word ‘trading’ referred to in the wording of IA 1986, ss 214 nor 246ZB. Therefore, one of the immediate consequences of coronavirus was that directors could be liable for wrongful trading even though they were not in fact able to trade.

The Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020

In a bid to prevent directors commencing insolvency proceedings prematurely in order to avoid personal liability, the government announced its intention to legislate to temporarily suspend the wrongful trading regime, with such suspension being back-dated to 1 March 2020.

On 20 May 2020, the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill was introduced, which makes a number of far-reaching changes to UK insolvency law, some permanent and some temporary (see News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill). Unlike the temporary changes to the wrongful trading regime, many of the changes are based on the 2016 Insolvency and Corporate Governance consultation, which the government responded to in August 2018 (see News Analysis: Exploring the government’s response to the insolvency and corporate governance consultation). However, in the end the proposed changes to the wrongful trading regime are more nuanced than the original announcement may have led many practitioners to anticipate.

The Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020) received Royal Assent on 25 June 2020. For further information on the Act, see: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—overview.

What are the proposed changes?

CIGA 2020, s 12 is headed ‘suspension of liability for wrongful trading’, but the section itself does not suspend the wrongful trading regime. Instead, it provides that in determining for the purposes of wrongful trading (whether under IA 1986, ss 214 or 246ZB) the contribution (if any) that a person should make to a company’s assets, the court is to assume that the person is not responsible for any worsening of the financial position of the company or its creditors that occurs during the ‘relevant period’. Nodes.Title: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—moratorium
Nodes.BodyContent:
The Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act (CIGA 2020) inserts a new Part A1 into the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986) which provides for a new insolvency process whereby directors of insolvent companies, or companies that are likely to become insolvent, can obtain a 20 business day moratorium period. This is designed to allow viable businesses time to restructure or seek new investment free from creditor action. The moratorium is overseen by an insolvency practitioner acting as a ‘monitor’, although the directors will remain in charge of running the business on a day-to-day basis (known as a ‘debtor-in-possession’ process with the company being the ‘debtor’) subject to certain constraints. The intention is to provide a streamlined procedure that keeps administrative burdens to a minimum, makes the process as quick as possible and does not add disproportionate costs on to struggling businesses.

The moratorium will be free-standing—it is not be a gateway to a particular insolvency (or any process at all, if the company can be rescued during the moratorium without needing entry into an insolvency procedure).

This Practice Note considers how the moratorium may be commenced, what action may be taken during the moratorium and potential areas of difficulties. For information on how to extend, terminate and challenge the moratorium, see Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill 2020—moratorium extension and termination.

For links to forms to be used in connection with the commencement, extension and termination of the moratorium, see Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—moratorium forms.

Who is eligible to apply?

The company needs to meet the following criteria::

  1. •

    it is, or is likely to become, unable to pay its debts, and

  2. •

    it is likely that the moratorium would result in the rescue of the company as a going concern

In addition, IA 1986, Sch ZA1 excludes certain companies from using the moratorium. These include:

  1. •

    companies that have in the last 12 months been subject to a moratorium (unless the court orders not to take that into account) or a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) or administration (as a temporary measure, this exclusion is omitted until 30 September 2020)

  2. •

    companies already subject to an insolvency procedure

  3. •

    certain types of companies, including: insurance companies, banks, securitisation companies and parties to capital market arrangements

How to apply

The directors of an eligible company may apply for the moratorium in two ways:

  1. •

    if there is no outstanding winding-up petition, by filing the relevant documents with the court

  2. •

    if there is an outstanding winding-up petition, by an application to court

As a temporary measure, until 30 September 2020, a company which is subject to an outstanding winding-up petition is entitled to file the relevant papers at court, rather than make an application to court.

An overseas company may also apply to court for a moratorium provided it is not subject to an outstanding winding-up petition.

Relevant documents

IA 1986, s A6 sets out the relevant documents that must be either filed at court or included with an application. These are:

  1. •

    a notice from the directors:

    1. ◦

      that they wish to obtain a moratorium

    2. ◦

      that in the directors’ view the company is, or is likely to become unable to pay its debts

  2. •

    a statement from the proposed monitor that:

    1. ◦

      they are (i) a qualified person and (ii) consents to act as the monitor in relation to the proposed moratorium

    2. ◦

      the company is an eligible company

    3. ◦

      in the proposed monitor’s view, it is likely that a moratorium for the company would result in the rescue of the company as a going concern

Further details of the information that must be provided in the notice/statement are found in paragraphs 14 to 18 of Schedule 4 to CIGA 2020. Each statement under IA 1986, s A6(1)(b) to (e) must be made within the period of 5 days ending with the day on which the documents under A6(1)(a) to (e) are filed/lodged with the court (or, if the documents are filed on different days, the last of those days). Where documents are filed on different days, the moratorium comes into force on the last of those days.

Where directors of a company file relevant documents with the court by means of electronic delivery (within the meaning of CPR PD 51O) for the purposes of obtaining a moratorium, the documents shall be treated as being filed with the court at the date and time recorded in the email referred to at CPR PD 51O, para 5.3(1), generated by automatic notification acknowledging that the documents have been submitted.

As a temporary measure, until 30 September 2020, the monitor is able to qualify their statement such that the moratorium would be likely to result in the company being rescued as a going concern or would do so if it were not for any worsening of the financial position due to coronavirus.

As drafted, it is not clear whether the monitor must believe that the company can be rescued as a going concern within the initial period, or can assume that it is reasonably likely to be possible to obtain a suitable extension if required. Turning a company around in 20 business days (or 40 business days if the monitor was to assume the first extension by the directors) will be a big ask in many restructurings.

Where the company is a regulated company within the meaning of IA 1986, s A48(13), written consent of the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) or the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) to the appointment of the proposed monitor must be included with the filing or application.

During the moratorium

During the moratorium the company must continue to pay on-going costs of running the business (defined as moratorium debts). In addition, the company must meet the following pre-moratorium debts which do not benefit from a payment holiday during the moratorium:

  1. •

    the monitor’s remuneration and expenses

  2. •

    goods/services supplied during the moratorium

  3. •

    rent in respect of a period during the moratorium

  4. •

    wages or salary arising under a contract of employment

  5. •

    redundancy payments, or

  6. •

    debts or other liabilities arising under a contract or other instrument involving financial services (as defined in new IA 1986, Sch ZA2)

The moratorium that arises is very similar to the moratorium that arises in an administration under IA 1986, Sch B1:

  1. •

    no insolvency proceedings may be commenced, other than on an application by the directors or on public interest grounds

  2. •

    no steps may be taken without the permission of the court in relation to forfeiture, enforcement of security (other than in relation to financial collateral), repossessing goods under a hire purchase agreement or instituting/continuing any legal process (other than employment-related claims)

Unlike an administration, where the administrator may consent to the lifting of the stay, the restriction on enforcement and legal proceedings in the moratorium may only be lifted by the court—neither the directors nor the monitor has that power. Additionally, a creditor with a pre-moratorium debt that is subject to a payment holiday during the moratorium may not apply to court for permission to enforce that debt. By contrast, a creditor with a pre-moratorium debt which is not subject to a payment holiday (for example, a lender) can apply to court for permission to enforce the debt by way of security enforcement or otherwise.

The moratorium does not, however, prevent a creditor from declaring a default or exercising its right to accelerate a debt or terminate the contract

Floating charges cannot be crystallised, nor can new restrictions be placed on disposal of the chargor’s property during the moratorium. Though it is not specifically stated, the types of new restrictions which are prohibited might include those contained in notices to contract counterparties (or banks where the company holds accounts) requiring the counterparty to deal only with the lender from the date of the notice. This means that the company is likely to be able to deal with floating charge assets in the ordinary course of its business during the moratorium without the lender being able to exert any additional control and without any requirement that the sale proceeds be applied in reduction of the related debt.

The directors of the company remain in control of the company during the moratorium but are subject to certain restrictions designed to protect creditors. These include:

  1. •

    no credit may be obtained in excess of £500 unless the lender has been informed that there is a moratorium is in force

  2. •

  4. •

    no payment of pre-moratorium debts in excess of the greater of £5000 or 1% of total indebtedness unless the monitor agrees. The monitor can only consent on the basis that they think it will support the rescue of the company as a going concern

Nodes.Title: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—restructuring plan provisions
Nodes.BodyContent:
Spurred on by the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, the government has pushed through the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020). The government previously consulted on proposed changes to the UK’s insolvency regime and published its response on 26 August 2018 (see News Analysis: Exploring the government’s response to the insolvency and corporate governance consultation). The CIGA 2020 largely follows the conclusions set out in the government’s response.Among the reforms, CIGA 2020, s 7 and Sch 9 introduce a new Part 26A of the Companies Act 2006 (CA 2006)—Arrangements and Reconstructions for Companies in Financial Difficulty (a ‘restructuring plan’) which is also supported by the Practice Statement (Companies: Schemes of Arrangement under Part 26 and Part 26A of the Companies Act 2006)(Practice Statement 2020).

What are the practical implications?

We have already seen several corporate failures around the world linked to coronavirus. Some of the reforms implemented by the CIGA 2020 have been in the pipeline for several years, including the new tool for struggling companies—a restructuring plan. The CIGA 2020 restructuring plan should give many struggling companies which have viable underlying businesses the tools needed and necessary breathing space to secure a rescue.

The CIGA 2020 introduces a new restructuring procedure that allows a company to bind all creditors, including junior (or senior) classes of creditors even if they vote against the plan, through the use of a cross-class cram down (CCCD) provision. Such cram down can be imposed provided dissenting classes of creditors are no worse off than they would be in the relevant alternative. The classes of creditors will be proposed by the distressed company on a case by case basis. For a class to vote in favour, 75% of a class by value must agree to the plan. The restructuring plan provisions are a permanent change to the UK’s insolvency laws and a welcome addition to its toolkit.

The CIGA 2020’s separate moratorium proposals also mean that a statutory moratorium is available, subject to eligibility, to protect a company while it prepares its proposal.

Eligibility criteria

The availability of a restructuring plan is not dependent on the company’s size or turnover; this is in line with the government’s response in August 2018 to the Insolvency and Corporate Governance consultation that the restructuring plan should be available to all companies as there may be circumstances where a smaller company may better effect a rescue via a restructuring plan than by using a company voluntary arrangement (CVA) (ie despite the fact that some respondents had argued that in practice only larger more complex companies would be viable given the costs associated with two court hearings). However:

  1. •

    the Secretary of State may introduce regulations to exclude certain companies which are authorised persons (‘authorised person’ has the same meaning as in the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000—ie those involved in specific financial market transactions; this is to avoid interfering with the proper functioning and integrity of those markets)

Note that the earlier wording excluding the binding effect on creditors with aircraft-related interests (see News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—Restructuring Plan provisions) was removed from the draft Bill before it was presented to the House of Lords. This is a welcome change as otherwise the restructuring plan could not have been used effectively for airline failures.

The Insolvency Service factsheet accompanying the CIGA 2020 states that regulations are expected to extend the provisions to:

  1. •

    charitable incorporated organisations (CIOs)

  2. •

    mutuals (including co-operatives and community benefit societies)

  3. •

    limited liability partnerships (LLPs)

Conditions A and B must be met (CA 2006, s 901A):

  1. •

    Condition A is that the company has encountered, or is likely to encounter, financial difficulties that are affecting, or will or may affect, its ability to carry on business as a going concern (no further guidance is provided on the meaning or scope of the term ‘financial difficulties’, which is potentially very broad).

  2. •

    Condition B is that:

    1. ◦

      (a) a compromise or arrangement (arrangement includes a re-organisation of the company’s share capital by the consolidation of shares of different classes or by the division of shares into shares of different classes, or by both of those methods) is proposed between the company and (i) its creditors, or any class of them, or (ii) its members, or any class of them, and

    2. ◦

      (b) the purpose of the compromise or arrangement is to eliminate, reduce or prevent, or mitigate the effect of, any of the financial difficulties mentioned

Solvent or insolvent—no hard financial conditions are set in order to qualify for a restructuring plan (beyond that the company has encountered, or is likely to encounter, financial difficulties that are affecting, or will or may affect, its ability to carry on business as a going concern mentioned in Condition A above). This means both solvent and insolvent companies may propose restructuring plans to their creditors/members.

Available to insolvency practitioners (IPs)—a company in an insolvency procedure, acting through the insolvency office-holder (eg an administrator or liquidator), may also propose a restructuring plan to creditors/members. While the government does not think this would happen often, maximum flexibility is desirable to ensure viable businesses do not fail unnecessarily.

Compromise or arrangement— query the extent to which there must be an exchange for value ie whether the plan proponent can completely disenfranchise a certain class of creditors/members even if they are out of the money without offering them something in return of at least a nominal value.

Application available to debtor or creditors or members—the debtor itself may apply (as will usually be the case) or the creditors (this is a change from the government’s response 2018 which envisaged that only the debtor could apply) or the members. In practice, query whether creditors or members will have the requisite information required to file an application for a restructuring plan.

Jurisdiction—applies to companies liable to be wound up under the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986) (new CA 2006, s 901 A(4)(b)); this is a similar definition to that used for schemes of arrangement, which use the broader test of whether or not a company has sufficient connection with the relevant court of the UK (for the approach used in schemes, see Practice Note: Establishing jurisdiction and sufficient connection for schemes of arrangement) rather than the higher centre of main interests (COMI) test (see Practice Note: Recast Regulation—establishing the centre of main interests (COMI) for corporates). Therefore, a company incorporated outside of the UK may be eligible if it has a sufficient connection with the UK (and fulfils the other tests listed above). This makes the restructuring plan a formidable tool for international restructuring.

Excluded creditors

An important limitation on the effect of the restructuring plan is that relevant creditors for moratorium debts and priority pre-moratorium debts have the ability to veto a subsequent restructuring plan that proposes to compromise them where commenced within 12 weeks of the end of a moratorium (see new CA 2006, ss 901H and 899A ). Note, that each of these creditors has a right of veto. The final wording here (made after receipt of proposals by the City of London Law Society (CLLS)) amends s 174A IA 1986 to clarify the order of priority of moratorium debts and excludes ‘relevant accelerated debt’, being any pre-moratorium debt that fell due during the relevant period by reason of the operation of, or the exercise of rights under, an acceleration or early termination clause in a contract or other instrument involving financial services.

In practice, this means that in order to implement a successful wholesale restructuring of all creditor types, the restructuring plan must be launched (i) whilst any moratorium is in force (ie before it ends) or (ii) without the use of any prior moratorium or (iii) with the consent of these excluded creditors.

For more detailed consideration of the impact on lenders, see Practice Note: The Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 and other developments in insolvency and restructuring—key issues and discussion points for lenders.

Process

Consultation responses and discussions with stakeholders persuaded the government of the benefits of modelling the restructuring plan procedure on that of schemes of arrangements. As well as familiarity, this has the advantage of providing a long-established and tested body of jurisprudence that courts will be able to draw upon when dealing with the new restructuring plan and considering matters such as class formation (ie relevant scheme case law should be applicable to relevant provisions of the new restructuring plan procedure, see: Schemes of arrangement—overview). In practice, lock up agreements are also likely to be used to bind creditors/members into voting in favour of the restructuring plan. Note that the new Practice Statement 2020 must also be complied with.

The new process therefore largely mirrors that used in schemes:

  1. •

    a restructuring plan proposal will be sent to creditors/members and filed at court

  2. •

    at a first hearing, the court will examine the classes of creditors/members as defined by the applicant (this is akin to a scheme convening hearing; see Practice Note Schemes of arrangement—convening hearing and sanction hearing). Creditors/members may challenge class formation if they think the company’s classes do not accurately reflect the rights and interests of different classes. Note that although there is no specific guidance in the CIGA 2020 on how classes are formed, the expectation is that courts will follow the existing scheme caselaw on this ie stakeholders should vote in the same class where their rights are ‘not so dissimilar as to make it impossible for them to consult together with a view to their common interest’ (see Practice Note: Schemes of arrangement—class issues and checklist: Checklist of factors which may (and may not) fracture the class in a scheme of arrangement). Practice Statement 2020, para 2 emphasises that it is the responsibility of the applicant to (i) determine whether more that one meeting of creditors and/or members is required and (ii) if so, to ensure those meetings are properly constituted

  3. •

    if satisfied, the court will confirm that a vote on the proposal may be conducted on a specified date ahead of a second hearing if required

  4. •

    necessary information would be anything that creditors/members need in order to make a decision whether or not to support the proposal (ie similar to the explanatory statement used in schemes; also see Practice Statement 2020), including certain mandatory matters that must be covered in all cases (see further below)

  5. •

    vote of creditors (or members)—if no challenges are brought or no counter-proposals permitted by the court then creditors/members will vote on the proposal

  6. •

    court sanction hearing—subject to the requisite voting thresholds being met and the rules for imposing a cross-class cram down being complied with (discussed below), the court will then schedule a second hearing at which it will consider if the necessary requirements have been met and will make a decision whether or not to confirm the restructuring plan and make it binding on affected creditors/members

Note that the appointment of a supervisor is not mandatory (although this was mooted in the earlier consultations), but parties are free to engage a supervisor if they wish.

Pension schemes

Following significant lobbying from various pensions groups, the Pensions Regulator/Pension Protection Fund (PPF) now have a seat at the negotiating table in certain cases and are entitled to the notices which creditors/members receive. The aim is to ensure that the interests of pension schemes are fully taken into account in any restructuring or rescue of a sponsoring company.

Where the company is or has been an employer (CA 2006, s 901I):

  1. •

    in respect of an occupational pension scheme that is not a money purchase scheme, any notice or other document must be also sent to the Pensions Regulator

  2. •

    in respect of an eligible scheme (as defined under section 126 of the Pensions Act 2004), any notice or other document must be also sent to the board of the PPF

The Secretary of State is also given powers to introduce regulations providing that the PPF can exercise any rights exercisable by the trustees or manages of an eligible pension scheme as a creditor of the company (see CA 2006, ss 901I(3)-(7)).

Contents of the Explanatory Statement

Certain mandatory matters must be covered in all cases under CA 2006, s 901D:

  1. •

    explain the effect of the compromise or arrangement (also see Practice Statement 2020)

  2. •

    state (i) any material interests of the directors of the company (whether as directors or as members or as creditors of the company or otherwise), and (ii) the effect on those interests of the compromise or arrangement, in so far as it is different from the effect on the like interests of other persons

  3. •

    where the compromise or arrangement affects the rights of debenture holders of the company, the statement must give the like explanation as respects the trustees of any deed for securing the issue of the debentures as it is required to give as respects the company’s directors

  4. •

    where a notice given by advertisement states that copies of an explanatory statement can be obtained by creditors or members entitled to attend the meeting, every such creditor or member is entitled to a copy

Note that it is the duty of (a) any director of the company, and (b) any trustee for its debenture holders, to give notice to the company of such matters relating to that director or trustee as may be necessary for the purposes of the above.

Practice Statement 2020, para 14 requires Explanatory Statements to be in a form and style appropriate to the circumstances of the case, including the nature of the member and/or creditor constituency, and should be as concise as the circumstances admit. In addition to complying with the provisions of section 901D of the CA 2006, the commercial impact of the scheme must be explained and members and/or creditors must be provided with such information as is reasonably necessary to enable them to make an informed decision as to whether or not the scheme is in their interests, and on how to vote on the scheme. Where a document is incorporated into the explanatory statement by reference, readers should be directed to the material part(s) of the document.

The court will consider the adequacy of the Explanatory Statement at the convening hearing. The court may refuse to make a meetings order if it considers that the Explanatory Statement is not in an appropriate form. However, the court will not approve the Explanatory Statement at the convening hearing, and it will remain open to any person affected by the [Part 26A] scheme to raise issues as to its adequacy at the sanction hearing (see Practice Statement 2020, para 15).

Contents of the supporting witness statement

The stated purpose of Practice Statement 2020, para 1 is to ensure that issues concerning (i) jurisdiction, (ii) composition of classes and (iii) the convening of meetings is identified and, if appropriate, resolved early in the proceedings. Practice Statement 2020, para 6 specifies that the applicant must ensure that the supporting witness statement covers:

  1. •

    any issues which may arise as to the constitution of meetings of members or creditors or which otherwise affect the conduct of those meetings

  2. •

    any issues as to the existence of the court's jurisdiction to sanction the [Part 26A] scheme;

  3. •

    (in relation to a Part 26A scheme) any issues relevant to the conditions to be satisfied pursuant to section 901A of CA 2006 (ie eligibility conditions A and B) and, if an application under section 901C(4) of the CA 2006 (ie exclusion of class with no genuine economic interest)is to be made, any issues relevant to that application; and

  4. •

    any other issue not going to the merits or fairness of the scheme, but which might lead the court to refuse to sanction the scheme

The witness statement should describe how it is proposed that members and/or creditors are to be given notice of any meetings convened to consider the scheme (Practice Statement 2020, para 13).

Where interests in the applicant’s debt are through intermediaries/ indirectly, if it is proposed that the votes to be cast at the meetings should by some method reflect the views of persons holding such indirect interests, the evidence should set out the applicant’s proposals in that respect and any facts justifying those proposals (Practice Statement 2020, para 13).

Convening hearing: Notice requirements

Practice Statement 2020, para 7 specifies the form and contents of the notice to persons affected by the restructuring plan. In summary, they must be told:

  1. •

    (a) that the [Part 26A] scheme is being promoted

  2. •

    (b) the purpose which the [Part 26A] scheme is designed to achieve and its effect

  3. •

    (c) the meetings of creditors and/or members which the applicant considers will be required and their composition

  4. •

    (d) the other matters that are to be addressed at the convening hearing, including the issues identified in para 6 of the Practice Statement 2020,

  5. •

    (e) the date and place fixed for the convening hearing

  6. •

    (f) that such persons are entitled to attend the convening and sanction hearings, and

  7. •

    (g) how such persons may make further enquiries about the [Part 26A] scheme

The applicant must ensure such notification is given in a concise form and is communicated to all persons affected by the [Part 26A] scheme in the manner which is most appropriate to the circumstances of the case (Practice Statement 2020, para 7). Generally it should be given to affected persons in sufficient time to enable them to consider what is proposed, to take appropriate advice and if so advised, it attend th...

Nodes.Title: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—restrictions on ipso facto clauses
Nodes.BodyContent:
Background to the Bill

Spurred on by the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic and a desire to mitigate the effect on businesses of the government-imposed lockdown, the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill received Royal Assent on 25 June 2020 resulting in the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020). This followed the government’s previous consultation on proposed changes to the UK’s insolvency regime in 2016, its response to which was published on 26 August 2018 (see News Analysis: Exploring the government’s response to the insolvency and corporate governance consultation).

Among the reforms, the CIGA 2020 introduces new provisions into the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986) to ensure the continuity of essential supplies and restrict contractual termination provisions on insolvency (so-called ‘ipso facto’ clauses).

For an overview of the CIGA 2020, see Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—overview and News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020.

For more in depth analysis of the specific proposals, see:

  1. •

    Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—restructuring plan provisions

  2. •

    Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—moratorium

  3. •

    News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—temporary changes to winding-up petitions

  4. •

    Practice Note: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020—temporary changes to the wrongful trading regime

  5. •

    News Analysis: Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill—company meetings and company filings

What are ipso facto clauses?

When a company is subject to an insolvency procedure, creditors often seek to improve their position by threatening to terminate their supply of goods or services to the company. Creditors can do this if the contract contains a provision entitling the creditor to terminate on the grounds of insolvency or the impaired financial position of the counterparty. These types of clauses are known as ipso facto clauses.

Typically, the creditor will refuse to continue supplying the insolvent company unless it agrees to settle any outstanding debts it owes to the creditor. This creates a problem for the company because it can divert limited funds away from keeping the business afloat. It also risks disturbing the statutory waterfall of payments on insolvency—see Practice Note: Waterfall of payments—a comparative guide.

What was the position prior to the CIGA 2020?

One of the long-standing principles of English law is the freedom of parties to contract as they choose. However, the law has long recognised the need to impose certain restrictions and safeguards on that freedom, for example to prevent duress. When a company enters an insolvency process, the IA 1986 already prevents suppliers of ‘essential supplies’ from demanding payment of pre-insolvency debts as a condition of continuing the supply (see IA 1986, s 233). Where the company enters into administration or a voluntary arrangement, IA 1986, s 233A also imposes certain restrictions on termination because the law recognises the importance to companies of ensuring the continuation of essential supplies to facilitate either a rescue of the company, or a better return to creditors. Therefore the supply of key utilities are protected and from 1 October 2015 the government extended the list of essential supplies to include private suppliers of utilities and IT supplies (see Practice Note: The Insolvency (Protection of Essential Supplies) Order 2015—what is its effect?).

However, the law prior to the CIGA 2020 had limitations and did not take account of the particular needs of individual businesses in determining what is an essential supply, which varies from business to business.

Moreover, under IA 1986, ss 233–233A the guarantee of essential supplies is conditional: the office-holder can request the continuation of the essential supply, but the supplier can insist on a personal guarantee from the office-holder in respect of those future supplies.

What are the changes to ipso facto clauses?

The CIGA 2020 seeks to provide companies in financial difficulties with a comprehensive toolkit to aid their survival. As such, it is more radical with regard to ipso facto clauses than its predecessor legislation and seeks to restrict the enforcement of termination clauses in a wider range of circumstances.

Under new IA 1986, s 233B, suppliers of goods or services are unable to rely on contractual clauses allowing for termination in the event of the counterparty’s insolvency or restructuring. This includes not only where the counterparty is subject to an existing insolvency procedure, but also where the counterparty is subject to the new restructuring plan or moratorium created by the CIGA 2020. However, where the counterparty enters into a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, ipso facto clauses will remain enforceable.

The creditor is unable to insist on payment of pre-insolvency debts in order to secure future supplies, nor are they able to do ‘any other thing’ as a result of the insolvency or restructuring. For example, the creditor is prevented from increasing its prices or insisting on less favourable payment terms.

The new provisions go further and prohibit the termination of a contract or supply where the creditor has a pre-existing right of termination which arose—but was not exercised by the creditor—before the relevant insolvency or restructuring commenced.

The restrictions will remain in place throughout the duration of the insolvency procedure. Significantly, they also have retrospective e...
