Nodes.Title: Taxation of coronavirus (COVID-19) government support payments
Nodes.BodyContent:
During the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, the UK government announced a series of measures to support individuals and businesses that are adversely affected by the pandemic. A number of these measures involve the receipt of funds directly from government or local government that are not expected to be paid back, ie grants rather than loans. For more detail on the schemes announced, see Practice Note: Coronavirus (COVID-19) implications for tax lawyers.

Guidance relating to these schemes has always indicated that the recipients should treat these grants as taxable income because the grant is, in effect, replacing the income of the recipient that would otherwise have arisen.

On 1 June 2020, the government published draft legislation, tax information and impact note and explanatory notes for consultation. The purpose of the legislation is to:

  1. •

    ensure that the grants are treated as income where the business is within the scope of income tax or corporation tax

  2. •

    enable HMRC to recover payments to which the recipient was not in fact entitled, and

  3. •

    enable HMRC to charge a penalty for deliberate non-compliance

On 25 June, the government published a government amendment to be added into the Finance Bill 2020 (FB 2020), with some minor changes to the legislation. For analysis of the changes between the original and the amended version of the provisions, see News Analysis: Finance Bill 2020—new clauses published on 25 June 2020—Taxation of coronavirus support payments.

Which business support grants are within the scope of these provisions?

The provision applies to ‘coronavirus support payments’ (CSPs). This is defined in draft clause 1(2). It currently includes payments made (at any time, including before FB 2020 receives Royal Assent) under:

  1. •

    the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme (CJRS)

  2. •

    the Self-Employment Income Support Scheme (SEISS)

  3. •

    the Coronavirus Statutory Sick Pay Rebate Scheme (CSSPRS)

  4. •

    a ‘coronavirus business support grant scheme’, which is defined as schemes under which a public authority makes grants with the object of supporting businesses affected by coronavirus. Specific examples are given in draft clause 1(6) being the small business grant fund (SBGF), the retail, hospitality and leisure grant fund (RHLGF), the local authority discretionary grants fund (DGF) and their equivalents in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland

The definition also allows for the expansion to cover other schemes that are:

  1. •

    the subject of a direction given under section 76 of the Coronavirus Act 2020 (currently only the CJRS and the SEISS have been the subject of such a direction)

  2. •

    ‘coronavirus business support grant schemes’, or

  3. •

    specified in regulations made by the Treasury

How are the grants to be brought within the charge to tax?

The operative provisions are contained in a new Schedule expected to be added to FB 2020. Paragraphs 1–7 relate to the way in which the receipt of a CSP is dealt with in the hands of the recipient depending on the context:

  1. •

    paragraphs 1–3 deal with CSPs that are ‘referable to a business’

  2. •

    paragraph 4 provides for exemptions and reliefs for amounts that are dealt with under paragraphs 1–3

  3. •

    paragraph 5 provides a specific charge to tax for CSPs under the CJRS where employment costs are deductible by another person

  4. •

    paragraph 6 provides a specific charge to tax for CSPs (other than those made under the CJRS or the SEISS) where no business is carried on

  5. •

    paragraph 7 gives HM Treasury the power to modify, by regulation, the application of the tax regime to the receipts brought into account under paragraphs 1 and 2 and the amounts charged to tax under paragraphs 5 and 6

CSPs that are referable to a business

Under paragraph 1(2), persons (ie companies and individuals) that are carrying on a business, whether alone or in partnership, must treat any CSP that is referable to their business as a receipt of a revenue nature for corporation tax or income tax purposes and must bring it into account in calculating the profits (or losses) of that business in the usual way (see Practice Note: Basis of calculation of corporation tax—Amount of profits to which corporation tax rates are applied—taxable total profits).

If the CSP is referable to more than one business, the recipient must allocate it between the businesses on a just and reasonable basis.

CSPs that are not referable to activities of a business that is being carried on

Paragraph 2 deals with CSPs received by persons who carried on a business but where the CSP is not referable to the business activities. It is noted in the explanatory notes that this would be because the business activities have ceased, most likely due to the effect of the pandemic. It is clear from the drafting that these payments are still treated as being ‘referable to the business’, but that they cannot be referable to activities of that business because of the particular circumstances of the pandemic. It is assumed that this is intended to prevent any concerns about whether or not a person is ‘carrying on a business’—in other circumstances, HMRC might argue that a company that owned a chain of restaurants but was not in fact open for business in any of them should not be treated as carrying on a business at all.

The treatment of the CSP depends on the type of business the person carried on:

  1. •

    if the person was carrying on a trade or property business, the CSPs should be treated as post-cessation receipts—for this purpose:

    1. ◦

      the post-cessation receipts are brought into account in accordance with the existing rules for such receipts in the income tax and corporation tax provisions, with the exception of the provisions (in each regime) that provide for the extent of the charge to tax—namely, that amounts are only chargeable as post-cessation receipts if they are not chargeable under any other provisions, and certain amounts relating to non-residents or arising from activities carried on outside the UK are not chargeable as post-cessation receipts, and

    2. ◦

      each of the post-cessation regimes has its own provision for dealing with allowable expenses during the relevant period, which broadly allows deductions for amounts that would have been allowable had the trade or business carried on, save for expenses that arise from the cessation itself

  2. •

    if the business was not a trade or property business:

    1. ◦

      the person receiving the CSP is to be treated as if they were still carrying on the business and the CSP must be treated as if it were referable to those activities and therefore brought into charge under draft paragraph 1(2), and

    2. ◦

      if the business incurs expenses that would have been deductible in calculating the profits of the business had the business been continuing, the amount brought into account in accordance with draft paragraph 1(2) is reduced by the amount of those expenses (except for amounts arising from ceasing to carry on the business, ie in line with the rules for post-cessation receipts)

What is a business and what amounts are ‘referable’ to it?

Paragraphs 1–3 of the draft legislation relate only to persons who are carrying on a ‘business’. Business is defined non-exhaustively to include a trade, profession, vocation, UK or overseas property business and a business consisting wholly or mainly of making investments. This definition is important because the way in which the CSPs are treated depends on whether the payments are referable to activities of that business.

Amounts referable to a business or business activities—interaction between paragraphs 1 and 2

Where the activities of the business have ceased at some point in the period of claim, it will be vital to consider how the provisions in paragraphs 1 and 2 interact with each other:

  1. •

    para 1(3) requires the CSP not to be brought into account under para 1(2) if the business to which the amount is referable is no longer being carried out and the amount is not referable to activities of the business undertaken at the time that the business was being carried out by the recipient. This appears to be targeting a situation where:

    1. ◦

      the business has ceased to be carried on at some point during the period to which the CSP relates (bearing in mind that some of the CSPs are one-off lump sums)

    2. ◦

      the amount, or some of it, is not referable to activities of the business that was previously being carried on, eg a company claims amounts under the CJRS for April 2020 and, for the first two weeks of April, the business was still active and only half the workforce had been furloughed, but by mid April all staff had been furloughed and the business was closed completely. The amount paid in respect of the second half of April would not be referable to activities of the business that was previously being carried on (whereas the amount for the first half of April would be)

  2. •

    in this situation, that part of the payment (ie that for the second half of April in the example above) needs to be brought into account, but:

    1. ◦

      as a post-cessation receipt under paragraph 2(3) or (4), unless

    2. ◦

      it is brought back into account under paragraph 1(2) because the ceased business was not a trade, profession, vocation or property business

Amounts referable to a business—specific situations

Paragraph 3 contains specific provisions to determine the amounts ‘referable to a business’ in certain specific situations:

  1. •

    if the CSP is made under the CJRS or CSSPRS (collectively known as ‘employment-related schemes’), it is treated as referable to the business of the person receiving the payment—this covers the situation where the person operating the pay as you earn (PAYE) scheme is a different person to the actual employer of the employees and makes it clear that the income must be brought into account in the hands of the person that receives the payment (and not another person, although note the application of paragraph 5 explained below)

  2. •

    a CSP made under the SEISS is referable only to the business of the individual to whom the payment relates and is to be treated entirely as a receipt of a revenue nature of the 2020–21 tax year (irrespective of its accounting treatment), ie it is brought into account for tax purposes in the year in which the SEISS payments are received (and no element included in the 2019–2020 tax year (even though the SEISS was announced during 2019–2020 and some of the affected trading may have taken place in that tax year)). This is a welcome simplification for many self-employed people, because no allocation needs to be made of the SEISS payments between tax returns on their self-assessments

  3. •

    where a CSP is made to a partner under the SEISS, its treatment depends on whether the partner retains the payment or distributes it among the partners. The first draft made this differentiation based on whether the payment was retained in its entirety, whereas the current version deals with each ‘amount’ of a CSP, suggesting that the partner may retain part and distribute part. The treatment is as follows:

    1. ◦

      any amount that is distributed among the partners (and not retained by the individual) is not treated as a receipt of a revenue nature of the individual partner, and

    2. ◦

      any amount that is retained by the individual partner is not treated as a receipt of the partnership or firm, in which case the amount is not included in the calculation of the firm’s profits, but rather added to the specific partner’s share of the firm’s profits (after those profits have been allocated in the usual way)

    The implication of this provision is that where a partner receives an SEISS payment and does not retain it all, it would be expected to be treated as income of the business of the partnership in accordance with draft paragraphs 1 or 2 as appropriate

Exemptions, reliefs and deductions

Under paragraph 4 of the schedule in the draft legislation, certain amounts are exempt or relieved as follows:

  1. •

    if the payment relates only to the mutual activities of a business that carries on a mutual trade, it will be treated as income of the mutual activities and therefore not taxable

  2. •

    CSPs are ignored when carrying out the calculations for income limits for charities and community amateur sports clubs; and amounts received under employment-related schemes are ignored when considering the corporation tax exemptions for trading and property income of community amateur sports clubs

  3. •

    for the purposes of applying an individual’s trading allowance for the year, any CSP received under the SEISS and brought into account under paragraph 1(2) is not included in the person’s relevant income and no relief is given against it (meaning the full trading allowances remain to be used against actual trading income) (the original version of this provision referred to property allowances as well; these were removed on the second iteration, presumably because the SEISS relates to trading income, not property income), and

  4. •

    deductions for pre-trading employment expenses are disallowed where a CSP is made under the CJRS or CSSPRS

Charge on CJRS payments where employment costs are deductible by another

Paragraph 5 of the draft schedule sets out a specific charge to income tax (rather than a requirement to bring the amount of the CSP into the profit or post-cessation receipt calculations) for CSPs under the employment related schemes where two conditions are met:

  1. •

    condition A: the amount of the CSP is not brought into account under paragraph 1(2) (in calculating the profits of a business carried on by the recipient of the CJRS or CSSPRS payment) or 2(3) or 2(4) (as a post-cessation receipt arising from the carrying on of such a business), and

  2. •

    condition B: expenses incurred by another person (ie not the person receiving the CJRS or CSSPRS payment) in respect of the same employment costs are deductible in calculating profits for income or corporation tax purposes (or post-cessation receipts)

Where the above two conditions are met, income tax is charged on the whole amount of the relevant CSP and the person liable to pay that tax is the one entitled to receive the CSP as an employer.

There is little guidance in the explanatory notes as to the target of this paragraph. It may be that this is designed to ensure that amounts paid under the CJRS to non-UK resident group members are still caught within the UK tax net. In an example: if a non-UK resident group member operates the PAYE scheme, it is that non-UK company that would be entitled to the payment under the CJRS in respect of employees working in the UK. However, as a non-UK resident company (assuming no other connection to the UK, such as a trading permanent establishment, that would bring it within the scope of the UK corporation tax or income tax net), it would not be caught by the requirements of paragraph 1 or 2. Where the employment costs for the furloughed employees are actually borne by a UK company (and therefore are deductible in calculating its trade), the UK exchequer would be losing out: they would have paid out the CJRS payment, be allowing deductions in the calculation of taxable profits of another entity, but no taxable income would be brought into account. Paragraph 5(5) states that the person liable to the income tax charge is the person entitled to receive the CSP as an employer, which would, in this example, be the non-UK recipient. If this kind of scenario is the intended target of this provision, it seems odd that HMRC have not elected to charge this income tax on the entity that is getting the related deductions, since that entity is (by definition) within the UK tax net, given the difficulties of enforcing UK tax charges on non-UK entities. It it hoped that further guidance on the intended target of paragraph 5 is forthcoming.
